In case of fire, the fire chief and his assistants shall rank in order named
and the officer of the highest rank at the fire shall take command of the fire
department and direct the management thereof for the suppression of the fire,
in the best manner possible. When it may be necessary for the protection of
other property and to prevent the spread of the conflagration, the officer in
command may cause buildings to be removed, torn down or destroyed in the best
manner possible. (1977 Code)
1-13-5: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of all officers of the fire department and all police
officers of the city to see that the provisions of this chapter are enforced
and to arrest on view, any person who shall be found violating any of the
provisions of this chapter or who shall hinder, resist or refuse to obey any
such officer in the discharge of his duty. To that end, all such officers are
hereby vested with the usual power and authority of the police officers. (1977
Code)
1-13-6: USE OF APPARATUS; INJURY:
Any person who shall use any fire engine, hose, cart or any other apparatus
belonging to the city for any private purpose, other than the extinguishment of
fires, or who shall remove the same or any part thereof from its place of
deposit, or having control thereof, shall permit such engine, hose, cart or
other apparatus to be used for any private purpose other than aforesaid, shall
upon conviction be subject to a fine as specified in section
1-4-1 of this title. (1977 Code)
1-13-7: ENTERING FIREHOUSES:
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than members of the fire department
or its auxiliary members, to enter the fire department house or any place where
the equipment and apparatus of the fire department is stored, at any time
except on business pertaining to the fire department or other city business.
The penalty for the violation of this section shall be as specified in section
1-4-1 of this title. (1977 Code)
1-13-8: FIRE INSPECTIONS:
   (A)   Authority: The fire chief or his designated assistant will conduct
fire inspections as outlined in Illinois rules and regulations for fire
prevention and safety as adopted in section
5-1-1 of this code.
   (B)   Fire Inspections; Frequency: The fire chief shall have the right,
within his area of responsibility, to enter any public building, structure or
premises at any reasonable time for the purpose of making an inspection to
determine whether or not there are any violations of these rules and
regulations for the protection of life and property from fire or other
emergency. Such inspections will be conducted annually together with follow up
inspections based on violations that have been cited for correction.
   (C)   Inspection Standards: During the inspection process, the following
requirements will be met:
      1.   General:
         (a)   Roof, overall condition, leakage, etc.
         (b)   Interior walls, holes and deteriorating plaster.
         (c)   Ceiling, holes and deteriorating plaster.
      2.   Housekeeping:
         (a)   Proper waste containers.
         (b)   Excessive combustible materials.
         (c)   General appearance.
      3.   Electrical:
         (a)   Enclosed electrical panel.
         (b)   Cover plates on junction boxes.
         (c)   Cover plates on wall outlets.
         (d)   Proper fuses.
         (e)   Proper use of extension cords.
         (f)   Presence of exposed wiring.
      4.   Heating plant:
         (a)   Type of fuel used and proper fuel storage.
         (b)   Overall condition of unit.
         (c)   Clearance and position from combustible material.
      5.   Fire protection:
         (a)   Availability of proper type fire extinguishers.
         (b)   Dates and tags on fire extinguishers.
         (c)   Sprinkler systems if available.
         (d)   Egress exits.
         (e)   Fire escapes if required.
         (f)   Emergency lighting if required. (Ord. 1182, 11-13-1979)
1-13-9: SERVICES RENDERED TO NONRESIDENTS:
   (A)   From and after the effective date hereof, there may be assessed
against all persons, businesses, and other entities who are not residents of
the Savanna fire protection district, a charge for services rendered to such
nonresidents by personnel and equipment of the Savanna fire department.
The charge shall not be assessed against persons who request fire protection
coverage for an unprotected area and who pay to the Savanna fire protection
district an amount equal to the district's fire protection tax pursuant to
section 4 of the fire protection of unprotected area act 1 . Charges shall
apply to the following services:
      1.   There may be assessed against any person, business or entity to whom
or for which technical rescue services or specialized services are rendered by
the personnel and equipment of Savanna fire protection district a charge for
such services. For purposes of this section, the term technical rescue services
shall include, but not be limited to, motorized vehicles, structural collapse,
high angle, tactical, underwater/water rescue, confined space, below grade and
trench rescue services.
      2.   There may be assessed against any responsible party, as that term is
defined in section 3(c) of the hazardous material response reimbursement act 2
, a charge for such services to reimburse the department for the services
rendered, materials expended and private contractors engaged in connection with
a hazardous materials incident.
      3.   There shall be assessed against any person who is found guilty of
violating section 11-501 of the vehicle code 3  whose operation of a motor
vehicle while in violation of that section (driving under the influence)
proximately caused any incident resulting in an emergency response by the
Savanna fire department a charge for the expense of that emergency response in
the amount of up to the state maximum.
      4.   There shall be assessed against any person who commits a violation
of the methamphetamine control and community protection act in a manner which
requires an emergency response by the Savanna fire department an amount equal
to the reasonable cost of its participation in the emergency response
including, but not limited to, regular and overtime costs and payments made to
private contractors to secure the site of the response.
      5.   There shall be assessed against any person who is liable under
section 15 of the emergency services response reimbursement for criminal
convictions act (public act 96-400) to the Savanna fire department for its
response to a fire resulting from an arson offense in an amount not less than
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and not more than ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00).
   (B)   The charge for services rendered by the Savanna fire department under
subsections (A)1, (A)2, (A)4, and (A)5 of this section shall be two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) per hour per firefighting or rescue vehicle and seventy
five dollars ($75.00) per hour per firefighter responding to a call for
assistance under those sections, provided, however, that no charge shall be
made for services rendered for which the charge would be less than fifty
dollars ($50.00). In addition to the foregoing charges, a separate charge may
be assessed for extraordinary expenses of materials used in rendering services
by the Savanna fire department to nonresidents including, but not limited to,
in connection with a hazardous material emergency response under subsection
(A)2 of this section or a methamphetamine incident under subsection (A)4 of
this section, the cost of any expendable materials used by the department in
connection with the incident, the charge of any private contractor responding
to the incident, the loss or damage to department equipment.
   (C)   All receipts from charges assessed pursuant to this section shall be
deposited to and become a part of the general fund of the city of Savanna.
   (D)   For purposes of this section, the terms used herein shall have the
meanings and definitions contained in the Illinois fire protection district act
4 , the hazardous material emergency response reimbursement act 5 , the vehicle
code 6 , the methamphetamine control and community protection act 7 , and the
emergency services response reimbursement for criminal convictions act (public
act 96-400) and it shall be interpreted in a manner consistent with those acts.
(Ord. 2128, 4-28-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 70 ILCS 715/4.
2 2. 430 ILCS 55/3(c).
3 3. 625 ILCS 5/11-501.
4 1. 70 ILCS 705.
5 2. 430 ILCS 55.
6 3. 625 ILCS 5.
7 4. 720 ILCS 646/90.
CHAPTER 14
SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
SECTION:
1-14-1: Office Created
1-14-2: Duties
1-14-3: Supervision Over Employees
1-14-4: Building Officer
1-14-5: Enforcing Regulations
1-14-6: Reports
1-14-1: OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created the office of superintendent of public works, who shall
be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the council. (1977 Code)
1-14-2: DUTIES:
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the superintendent of public works to
personally inspect, or cause to be inspected, all city connections made to the
sewer system and the water supply system of the city; further, he shall have
charge of all repairs to and maintenance of public improvements and public
works and shall work in cooperation with the consulting engineers as hired by
the city. He shall regulate and control the manner of using the streets,
alleys, highways, easements and other places of the city for the erection,
construction or installation of utilities as authorized by law or the city.
   (B)   He shall provide supervision for landfill activities and the operation
of the city's sewage treatment plant and coordinate these operations with the
environmental protection agency.
   (C)   He shall coordinate the preparation of plans, specifications, and
contract documents for public improvements with consulting engineers.
   (D)   He shall prepare specifications and contract documents for the new
procurement of capital equipment as required by the city. Such actions to be
coordinated with the mayor and council.
   (E)   He shall support consulting engineers with inspections and surveys as
required for public improvements of the city.
   (F)   He shall be responsible for the official files, for maps, charts,
plats, etc., covering installed systems and public improvements of the city.
   (G)   He shall assist the attorney in the preparation, drafting and drawing
of resolutions, ordinances and contracts for all public or special work and in
all litigation regarding public improvements or in matters wherein the city may
be interested, rendering such assistance as may be required of him by the
attorney.
   (H)   He shall make such investigations, inspections, analysis and reports
and shall perform such duties as may be required of him by the mayor and
council in connection with city planning, zoning, traffic, transportation,
buildings and structures or other administrative functions of the city.
   (I)   He shall attend all council meetings, regular and special, unless
excused by the mayor. He will also attend committee meetings upon request of
the mayor or chairmen of the individual committees. He will be given proper
notice of all such meetings.
   (J)   He shall maintain a current inventory showing all real and personal
property, including excess and surplus property, of his departments for which
the city has ownership. Such records will show storage location, acquisition
dates, cost and repair data and such other information as may be appropriate.
   (K)   He shall have the power to appoint and discharge any employee of the
department subject to the approval of the mayor.
   (L)   He shall maintain a strict chain of command procedure within the
city's organization structure. All official actions, for public works
activities, will flow through the office of the mayor. Likewise all council
members will channel their requests through the office of the mayor when action
is desired in the public works work area. (1977 Code)
1-14-3: SUPERVISION OVER EMPLOYEES:
The superintendent of public works shall be the head of the department of
public works and shall have supervision over all employees of the department
and shall be responsible for the performance of their duties and their actions
during working hours. (1977 Code)
1-14-4: BUILDING OFFICER:
The superintendent of public works shall have such duties and be bound by such
provisions as are set forth in the building code of the city. (1977 Code)
1-14-5: ENFORCING REGULATIONS:
It shall be the duty of the superintendent of public works to enforce all
regulations of this code relating to the sewer system, the water system, and
perform such other duties as may be required by the enactment of the council or
him. Upon violation of any provisions of this code herein referred to, he shall
make a complaint before the proper court against all persons that he may find
to have violated any such provisions. (1977 Code)
1-14-6: REPORTS:
The superintendent of public works shall, when required by the mayor and
council, inquire into and report upon any matter pertaining to public works and
shall from time to time communicate to the mayor and council any information or
suggestion which he may deem important in relation thereto. He shall, when
required by the mayor and council, report verbally or in writing to them on all
matters under his jurisdiction. (1977 Code)
CHAPTER 15
PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICER
(Rep. by Ord. 1847, 7-25-2006)
CHAPTER 16
ELECTIONS
SECTION:
1-16-1: Elections
1-16-2: Council Election Contests
1-16-1: ELECTIONS:
Elections for municipal offices shall be held as provided by statute and at the
time prescribed by statute 1 . (1977 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 10 ILCS.
1-16-2: COUNCIL ELECTION CONTESTS:
   (A)   Contest Of Election: The election of any council member may be
contested by any elector of the city, and the proceedings shall be in
accordance with the Illinois Compiled Statutes regulating the mode of
contesting elections of county officials, so far as the same may be applicable.
The city council shall be the tribunal before such contest shall be heard, and
its decision shall be final.
   (B)   Statement Of Contest: Whenever any person desires to contest the right
of another to hold the office of councilman, he shall, within thirty (30) days
after the person whose election is to be contested is declared elected, file
with the clerk a statement in writing, briefly stating the points on which he
will contest the election, which statement shall be verified by affidavit.
   (C)   Notice To Respondent: Upon filing such statement, the contestant shall
also serve a copy thereof upon the person whose election he intends to contest,
and in case such person is absent from the city and cannot be found, they by
leaving a copy of the statement at his usual place of abode, with some member
of his family of the age of ten (10) years or upwards, and informing such
person of the contents thereof.
   (D)   Taking The Depositions Of Witnesses: At such time either party may
proceed to take the testimony of any witness in the manner provided by law for
taking depositions in courts of record, before any judge or notary public, at
the time and place so fixed, and continue the same from day to day thereafter,
until the testimony is taken.
   (E)   Proofs Taken And Filed: In all cases of contested elections, the
proofs shall be taken and filed with the clerk within sixty (60) days from the
day fixed by the council. The council may from time to time, upon sufficient
cause shown, extend the time for taking and filing such proofs. No testimony
shall be taken or proof received or produced at the hearing before the council,
except upon the points set forth in the statement filed with the clerk.
   (F)   Council Procedure: When all the evidence has been taken, as provided
in this section, it shall be filed immediately in the office of the clerk, who
shall at once lay the same before the council, which shall, without delay,
refer the same to some appropriate committee to examine and report thereon.
Upon such report being made, the council shall hear the case, and may require
all the testimony and proofs taken to be read in open meeting, and shall, by a
majority vote, upon a call of the "yeas" and "nays", declare as elected the
person who shall appear by the evidence to have been elected; and the clerk
shall enter such decision and declaration in the journal of the council.
   (G)   Respondent Not To Act: In any election contest, the respondent or
person whose election is the subject of the contest shall not take any part in
such contest, so far as the determination thereof is concerned, nor shall he
cast any vote in connection therewith.
   (H)   Legal Disqualification: Whenever it appears that the person receiving
the highest number of votes is ineligible to the office because of any legal
disqualifications, the council shall declare such election null and void and
immediately call a special election to fill the office.
   (I)   Counting Ballots: In the case of a contested election, the parties
thereto shall be entitled to have the package or packages of ballots which have
been returned to the clerk pursuant to law opened in the presence of a
committee of the council and the officer having the custody thereof and to have
said ballots counted; or the same may be brought into open council meeting and
then and there counted by a committee of three (3) members appointed for that
purpose.
   (J)   Ballots To Be Preserved: The clerk shall preserve all ballots returned
to him by the judges of any city election for six (6) months thereafter and at
the expiration of that time, if no contest has been instituted and is still
pending, the clerk shall burn the ballots under the direction of the council.
(1977 Code)
CHAPTER 17
ELECTION WARDS
SECTION:
1-17-1: Wards Established
1-17-1: WARDS ESTABLISHED:
The city is hereby divided into four (4) wards, which shall be designated first
ward, second ward, third ward and fourth ward, as follows:
FIRST WARD: The first ward shall include all that part of the city of Savanna
lying northerly of a line commencing at the intersection of the centerline of
Madison Street with the westerly city limits; thence easterly along the
centerline of Madison Street, as projected easterly, to Diagonal Street; thence
northeasterly along the centerline of Diagonal Street to the intersection of
the centerline of Diagonal Street with the centerline of Cook Street; thence
easterly along the centerline of Cook Street to the intersection of the
centerline of Cook Street with the city limits.
SECOND WARD: The second ward shall include all that part of the city of Savanna
lying south of the first ward and easterly of a line commencing at the
intersection of the centerline of Madison Street with the westerly city limits;
thence southerly along the westerly city limits to the centerline of the main
line of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad Company; thence
easterly along the centerline of the main line of said railroad to the
intersection of said centerline of said main line with the centerline of Park
Street projected south; thence northerly along the centerline of Park Street to
the intersection of the centerline of Park Street with the centerline of
Chicago Avenue; thence westerly along the centerline of Chicago Avenue to the
intersection of the centerline of Chicago Avenue with the centerline of Sixth
Street; thence northerly along the centerline of Sixth Street, projected north,
to the city limits.
THIRD WARD: The third ward shall include all that part of the city of Savanna
lying east of the second ward and northerly of a line commencing at the
intersection of the centerline of the main line of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St.
Paul and Pacific Railroad Company with the centerline of Park Street projected
south; thence easterly along the centerline of the main line of the said
railroad to the intersection of the centerline of said main line with the
centerline of Viaduct Road; thence northerly along the centerline of Viaduct
Road to the intersection of the centerline of Viaduct Road with the centerline
of Chicago Avenue; thence easterly and northerly along the centerline of
Chicago Avenue to the intersection of the centerline of Chicago Avenue with the
centerline of Michigan Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of Michigan
Avenue, projected easterly, to the city limits.
FOURTH WARD: The fourth ward shall include all that part of the city of Savanna
lying south of the second and third wards, being south of a line commencing
with the intersection of the westerly city limits with the centerline of the
main line of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad Company;
thence easterly along the centerline of the main line of said railroad to the
intersection of the centerline of the main line of said railroad with the
centerline of Viaduct Road; thence northerly along the centerline of Viaduct
Road to the intersection of the centerline of Viaduct Road with the centerline
of Chicago Avenue; thence easterly and northerly along the centerline of
Chicago Avenue to the intersection of the centerline of Chicago Avenue with the
centerline of Michigan Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of Michigan
Avenue, projected easterly, to the city limits. (1977 Code)

CHAPTER 19
MUNICIPAL BUDGET
SECTION:
1-19-1: Adoption Of Annual Budget
1-19-2: Budget Officer
1-19-3: Computation Of Annual Budget
1-19-4: Public Inspection, Notice, Hearing
1-19-5: Revision Of Annual Budget
1-19-1: ADOPTION OF ANNUAL BUDGET:
The city hereby adopts 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.1 through and
including 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.10 providing for an annual
municipal budget in lieu of the passage of an annual appropriation ordinance.
(1977 Code)
1-19-2: BUDGET OFFICER:
The mayor, with the approval of the city council, shall appoint a budget
officer who shall have the powers, duties and responsibilities enumerated in
the above sections of the Illinois Compiled Statutes as they are now or may
hereafter be amended. The budget officer shall give a bond in such sum as may
be required by the city council; however, such bond shall not be less than
required by statutes. (1977 Code)
1-19-3: COMPUTATION OF ANNUAL BUDGET:
The budget officer shall compile a budget pursuant to the above sections of the
Illinois Compiled Statutes as they are now, or may hereafter be amended,
containing estimates of the revenues available before the beginning of the
fiscal year to which it applies together with recommended expenditures for the
city and all of its boards, commissions and departments. Said budget shall be
adopted prior to May 1 of each fiscal year. (1977 Code)
1-19-4: PUBLIC INSPECTION, NOTICE, HEARING:
Copies of the tentative annual budget shall be made available for public
inspection in printed or typewritten form in the office of the city clerk for
at least ten (10) days prior to the passage of the annual budget. Not less than
one week after the budget is available for inspection, and prior to final
action on the budget, at least one public hearing shall be held on the budget
by the city council. Notice of this hearing shall be given by publication in a
newspaper having a general circulation in the city at least one week prior to
the time of hearing. (1977 Code)
1-19-5: REVISION OF ANNUAL BUDGET:
The city council may delegate authority to heads of municipal departments,
boards or commissions to delete, add to or change items previously budgeted to
the department, board or commission, subject to such limitation or requirement
for prior approval by the budget officer or executive officer of the city as
the city council upon a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the members may establish. The
annual budget may be revised by a vote of two- thirds (2/3) of the city council
by deleting, adding to or changing budgeted items. No revision of the budget
shall be made increasing the budget in the event funds are not available to
effectuate the purpose of the revision. (1977 Code)
CHAPTER 20
COMPETITIVE BIDDING
SECTION:
1-20-1: Letting Bids
1-20-2: Laborers, Hourly Wage
1-20-3: Exceptions
1-20-4: Emergency Situation
1-20-5: Advertising For Bids
1-20-6: Disqualification Of Bidders
1-20-7: Deposit Required
1-20-8: Opening Bids Publicly
1-20-9: Purchases And Services Other Than Bids
1-20-1: LETTING BIDS:
All purchase orders or contracts, of whatever nature, for labor, service or
works, materials, equipment, supplies, or other public improvement, except
those which are to be paid for in whole or in part by special assessment or
special taxation, involving an amount in excess of twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00), made by or on behalf of the city, shall be let by free and open
competitive bidding after advertising, to the lowest responsible bidder, except
that any such contract may be entered into without advertising for bids in any
one of the following circumstances:
   (A)   Only one supplier can furnish the items required; or
   (B)   Only one vendor can supply repair parts or standardized equipment
which would be compatible with existing equipment; or
   (C)   An emergency or other extremely urgent need has arisen which precludes
the feasibility of formal bidding; or
   (D)   Equipment, materials or services are available through another
governmental agency; or
   (E)   If authorized by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all the aldermen then
holding office. (Ord. 2098, 8-12-2014)
1-20-2: LABORERS, HOURLY WAGE:
Contracts which contain the element of common labor as a part of the cost as
determined in the bid shall require that the hourly wage paid to common
laborers under such contract shall be not less than the hourly wage paid to
employees of the city for common labor. (1977 Code)
1-20-3: EXCEPTIONS:
Contracts which by their nature are not adapted to award by competitive
bidding, such as contracts for services of individuals possessing a high degree
of professional skill where the ability or fitness of the individual plays an
important part and purchases from any federal, state or local government unit
or agency thereof of materials, supplies, commodities or equipment as may be
available through the operation of any legislation heretofore or hereafter
enacted shall not be subject to the competitive bidding requirements of this
chapter. Regular employment contracts in the municipal service, whether with
respect to the classified service or otherwise, shall not be subject to the
requirements of this chapter. (1977 Code)
1-20-4: EMERGENCY SITUATION:
In the case of an emergency affecting the public health or safety, so declared
by the city council at a meeting thereof duly convened, which declaration
requires the affirmative vote of a majority of all the members thereof and
shall set forth the nature of the danger to the public health or safety;
contracts may be let to the extent necessary to resolve such emergency without
public advertisement or competitive bidding. The resolution or ordinance in
which such declaration is embodied shall fix the date upon which such emergency
shall terminate. (1977 Code)
1-20-5: ADVERTISING FOR BIDS:
All proposals to award purchase orders or contracts involving amounts in excess
of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) shall be published at least fifteen
(15) consecutive days in advance of the date announced for the receiving of
bids, in a secular newspaper published in and of general circulation in the
city. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prohibit the
municipality from placing additional announcements in recognized trade
journals. Advertisements for bids shall describe the character of the proposed
contract or agreement in sufficient detail to enable the bidders thereon to
know what their obligations will be, either in the advertisement itself, or by
reference to detailed plans and specifications on file at the time of the
publication. Such advertisement shall state the time, date and place assigned
for the opening of bids, and no bids shall be received at any time subsequent
to the time indicated in the advertisement. (Ord. 2165, 4-26-2016)
1-20-6: DISQUALIFICATION OF BIDDERS:
The city may disqualify an apparent low bidder or any vendor if, in the
judgment of the city council:
   (A)   The apparent low bidder or vendor's ability, skill, experience,
reputation or financial capacity, or the quality of his product are
substandard; or
   (B)   His business firm is delinquent in any financial obligations to the
city, including business tax, utility bill or other charges. (1977 Code)
1-20-7: DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
Cash, cashier's check or certified check, as a deposit of good faith, in a
reasonable amount, may be required of each bidder on all bids involving amounts
in excess of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) and, if so required, the
advertisement for bids shall so specify. (Ord. 2166, 4-26-2016)
1-20-8: OPENING BIDS PUBLICLY:
All sealed bids shall be publicly opened in the presence of at least two (2)
elected officials of the city at the time and place specified in the
advertisement for bids, and unless opened at a duly convened meeting of the
city council, such bids shall be available for public inspection in the office
of the city clerk for a period of at least forty eight (48) hours before award
is made. (1977 Code)
1-20-9: PURCHASES AND SERVICES OTHER THAN BIDS:
   (A)   Definitions:
    LIMITED PURCHASE ORDER: An authority to procure small and low value items
without a formal purchase order.
   PURCHASE ORDER: A document authorizing the procurement of materials,
supplies, equipment or a special service.
   REQUISITION: A demand and need for materials, supplies, equipment or a
special service.
   (B)   Determination Of Need: City department heads will assume the
responsibility to determine the need for services, supplies, materials and
equipment for their scope of operations. Purchase of items for stock, in
addition to immediate requirements, is authorized but must be based on positive
future demands and past usage experience. (Ord. 1213, 1-13-1981)
   (C)   Purchase And Service Authorization: Purchases and services exceeding
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be authorized only on city council
approval. An emergency purchase or service in excess of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) may be approved by the mayor but brought to the attention of the
city council when monthly warrants covering accounts payable are reviewed and
approved. (Ord. 1352, 4-25-1989)
   (D)   Limited Purchase Order Authorization: Purchases of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) or less may be approved by the department head. Likewise,
services of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less may be approved by the
department head. A limited purchase order is authorized for this category with
vendors on a monthly basis. The individual who consummates such a purchase must
sign the vendor's invoice. At the end of each month, the department head will
verify all statements from vendors and prepare the limited purchase order
showing appropriate cost code and process through the comptroller for payment.
   (E)   Purchase Approval: Purchases of an item or like items of over five
hundred dollars ($500.00) to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) must be approved
by the department head and are subject to review, approval and signature of the
mayor. Similar action must be taken when outside services are required which
are in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 1922, 8-25-2009)
   (F)   Price Quotes: Written price quotations should be obtained on the same
or similar items for purchase when such items are common or present a
competitive situation. The use of the telephone for city purchasing activities
must be held to an absolute minimum.
   (G)   Application Forms:
      1.   Requisition, three (3) part.
      2.   Purchase order, four (4) part, form P-433.
   (H)   Preparation Of Forms:
      1.   Department head will prepare a requisition to cover required
supplies and services and make available to the comptroller. The completion of
the form is self-explanatory and in addition to the information shown thereon,
a notation should be annotated to indicate the exact location, vehicle, etc.,
where the supplies, materials and equipment and services are needed or will be
utilized. An exception to this requirement would be repair to water and sewer
lines, minor street repair, etc. The comptroller will immediately certify the
availability of funds and assign a cost code to the requisition.
      2.   The comptroller, on a daily basis or whatever time period is
required, will present completed requisitions to the mayor for his immediate
review and signature.
      3.   The office of the comptroller will process approved requisitions by
preparing a purchase order for submission to vendor. One copy of each of the
requisitions and purchase orders will be merged together and placed in a dues-
in file awaiting arrival of shipment.
      4.   Department heads must make positive inspections of incoming
shipments peculiar to their organization, to ensure that all items are in a
serviceable condition and meet the requirements of the purchase order. They
will then provide the comptroller with certified information pertinent to
receipt of shipments. The comptroller will process the requisition and purchase
order so as to ask for payment on the next monthly city warrant for accounts
payable.
      5.   Petty cash must be used sparingly and its use is limited for
emergency onetime small purchases, fees, special postage, etc.
Any individual affiliated with the city who violates this section by
authorizing or processing any purchase of materials, supplies, equipment and
services, which are not a requirement of the city, is subject to disciplinary
action which may be recommended by the mayor and approved by the city council.
(Ord. 1213, 1-13-1981)
CHAPTER 21
CITY PROPERTY DISPOSAL
SECTION:
1-21-1: Policy Established
1-21-2: Responsibilities
1-21-3: Methods Of Disposal
1-21-4: Funds
1-21-1: POLICY ESTABLISHED:
A policy and procedure is hereby established to cover the storage, handling and
disposal of all salable, recovered scrap, excess and surplus property
accumulated as a result of city operations and activities. These actions will
apply to public works, law enforcement, fire service and administrative work
areas. (1977 Code)
1-21-2: RESPONSIBILITIES:
It will be the responsibility of each department head to take the following
actions concerning salable scrap, excess and surplus materials and equipment,
both serviceable and unserviceable, which is generated as a result of their
operations:
   (A)   Provide suitable storage until disposal action is authorized.
   (B)   Maintain appropriate records of all items and materials until disposal
action is authorized.
   (C)   Make available periodic listings to the city council of excess and
surplus materials and equipment with recommendations for method of disposal.
City council will take official action authorizing final disposal. (1977 Code)
1-21-3: METHODS OF DISPOSAL:
Based on council decisions, the following methods of disposal of equipment and
materials shall be followed:
   (A)   Through negotiated sale by the department head.
   (B)   Formal advertising for bids. Such bids to be processed and handled as
other competitive bidding as outlined in chapter 20 of this title.
   (C)   Trade in on new equipment.
   (D)   Destruction. (1977 Code)
1-21-4: FUNDS:
The administrative office of the comptroller will maintain a register of all
surplus property sales which will be cross referenced to the official action
authorizing disposal. Funds received from the sale of property will be credited
to the appropriate city operating account. All funds received from this
activity will be subject to the annual municipal audit. (1977 Code)
CHAPTER 22
CIVIL DEFENSE NATURAL DISASTER PLAN
(Rep. by Ord. 1476, 2-22-1994)
CHAPTER 23
CITY PERSONNEL REGULATIONS
SECTION:
1-23-1: Job Classifications
1-23-2: Workweek
1-23-3: Responsibilities
1-23-4: Seniority
1-23-5: Promotions And Salary Adjustments
1-23-6: Rest Periods
1-23-7: Vacations/Compensatory Time/Personal Day
1-23-8: Holidays
1-23-9: Sick Leave; Administrative Leave
1-23-10: Layoffs
1-23-11: Leave Of Absence
1-23-12: Military Service
1-23-13: Jury Duty
1-23-14: Records
1-23-15: Disciplinary Actions
1-23-16: Grievance Procedure
1-23-17: Hospitalization, Insurance
1-23-18: Clothing Allowance
1-23-19: Travel, Training, Meal And Lodging Expenses
1-23-20: Pension Plans
1-23-21: Injuries, Disability From Injuries In Line Of Duty
1-23-22: Safety Code
1-23-23: Employment Policy
1-23-24: Police Code Of Ethics
1-23-25: Drug And Alcohol Abuse Policy
1-23-26: Background Checks And License Verification
1-23-27: Part Time Police
1-23-1: JOB CLASSIFICATIONS:
   (A)   The City Comptroller shall establish and maintain an individual job
classification and personnel folder for all City employees. Personnel actions
will include, but not be limited to, the following information for each
employee:
      1.   Employment status.
      2.   Job title and rate of pay.
      3.   Vacation, sick leave and compensatory time.
      4.   Personnel citations.
      5.   Clothing allowance records.
      6.   Insurance status.
      7.   Accidents, injuries and related health documents. (Ord. 1151, 7-25-
1978; amd. Ord. 1423, 10-22-1991)
   (B)   Part time employees will receive no fringe benefits except what
benefits may be required by law. (Ord. 1423, 10-22-1991)
1-23-2: WORKWEEK:
   (A)   The normal workweek for the various City departments shall be as
follows:
 
Administrative 40 hours
Comptroller    40 hours
Fire           48 hours
Fire Chief     40 hours
Police         80 hours (2 week period)
Police Chief   40 hours
Public Works   40 hours
 
   (Ord. 2009, 5-22-2012)
   (B)   Compensation for all work performed in excess of forty (40) hours
shall be in conformance with the overtime requirements of the fair labor
standards for employees of state and local governments. Employees, except
firemen, shall be paid time and one-half (11/2) for hours worked in excess of
forty (40) hours, in a seven (7) day week, or given compensatory time at the
rate of time and one-half (11/2) for every hour of overtime worked. Police
officers will receive time and one-half (11/2) for hours worked in excess of
eighty (80) hours in a two (2) week period. This may be taken as pay or
compensatory time. Employees, other than firemen and policemen, may accumulate
compensatory time up to and including sixty (60) hours (i.e., 40 actual hours
at 11/2 times or 60 hours). Firemen and policemen may accumulate compensatory
time up to seventy two (72) hours (i.e., 48 actual hours at 11/2 times or 72
hours). Any employee who has accrued the maximum amount of compensation time
allowed herein, shall be paid overtime for all additional hours worked. An
employee with accrued compensatory time upon termination shall be paid for each
hour of compensatory time accumulated at an hourly rate calculated as the
average hourly rate of pay received by the employee during the preceding three
(3) years. (Ord. 2050, 7-23-2013)
   (C)   Regular full time police, fire, public works, and administrative
employees called to work in excess of their normal workweek shall be paid a
minimum of two (2) hours (i.e., 2 actual hours at 11/2 times) for work tasks
completed in less than two (2) hours. In the event additional calls to work
occur within the same two (2) hours, it will constitute a single call. Work
hours in excess of two (2) hours shall be computed as follows:
 
Less than 15 minutes     No pay
16 minutes to 45 minutes 1/2 hour at 11/2 times
Over 45 minutes          1 hour at 11/2 times
 
   (Ord. 2042, 6-11-2013)
   (D)   Department heads are not authorized overtime pay for the performance
of city functions. However, they are expected to attend council and committee
meetings, perform out of town travel as may be required or provide direction
and guidance, as required, to their subordinates who may be in an overtime or
other work situation. The workweek for department heads is established on a
forty (40) hour basis and this may be adjusted to compensate for their extra
efforts, providing their personnel can operate in an efficient manner.
   (E)   The normal workweek for employees, except fire department and police
personnel, will be Monday through Friday. The mayor, together with the
department head, has the authority to change an employee's workweek if city
operations so dictate.
   (F)   During duty hours, all employees will be permitted time off for lunch
as established by the department head. Such time must be deducted from their
normal work period, except police officers who will be granted a maximum of
thirty (30) minutes for lunch for each eight (8) hours of their normal workday.
   (G)   As set forth herein, the normal average workweek for firemen excluding
the fire chief shall be forty eight (48) hours. Firemen, excluding the fire
chief, shall be paid biweekly ninety six (96) hours. Hours worked in excess of
the normal scheduled workweek found to be eligible for overtime or compensatory
time will be compensated by payment of the additional time on that pay period
or crediting that employee the compensatory time due.
While it is contemplated that the average normal workweek will be forty eight
(48) hours, it is understood by the parties that hours worked per week may vary
according to the needs of the department. Where circumstances warrant,
alternate work schedules shall be established as required and determined by the
fire chief. (Ord. 1868, 4-24-2007)
1-23-3: RESPONSIBILITIES:
   (A)   All employees are directly responsible to their respective department
heads and the department heads are likewise responsible to the mayor.
   (B)   It will be the responsibility of each department head to keep the
mayor informed at all times of any significant changes in existing procedures
or budget work programs. This will include the proposed purchase of capital
equipment as well as any items or materials not included in the current budget.
The mayor will have the authority to establish guidelines and/or procedures to
be followed for the purchase of supplies, equipment and services required for
city activities and operations.
   (C)   It will be the full responsibility of all city employees to ensure
that proper check and maintenance is applied to all equipment for which the
city has ownership. The department heads will make periodic inspections to
ensure that this requirement is being complied with. Failure to comply with
this regulation will result in immediate disciplinary action. Gross negligence
by an employee in the use and handling of city equipment could result in
reimbursement by the individual to the city upon a full scale investigation by
the mayor and department head and subject to the final approval of the city
council.
   (D)   It shall be the duty of every employee to report immediately to his
supervisor, all injuries while in a working status. The department head will be
responsible that appropriate medical attention is given the employee, as
required, and provide documented information to the comptroller for inclusion
in personnel records.
   (E)   Any employee who has an accident with city equipment, not involving
another person or other property, must immediately report such incident to his
supervisor. The department head must provide a written report to the mayor
outlining the circumstances surrounding such accidents, who will determine if
an adverse personnel action is required. (Ord. 1151, 7-25-1978)
   (F)   Any employee operating a city vehicle who has an accident which
involves another person or property must immediately report such incident to
police authority. The local police will immediately contact state or county law
enforcement, who will carry out their duty in resolving said accident. The
chief of police will apprise the mayor of all such accidents involving city
employees. The driver will notify his department head as soon as possible after
the police have been advised.
   (G)   This section in no way supersedes job requirements, other
responsibilities, etc., for city employees as now established under this title.
(Ord. 1205, 10-14-1980; amd. Ord. 1423, 10-22-1991)
1-23-4: SENIORITY:
   (A)   Seniority shall be computed from the date of most recent employment.
   (B)   All new employees or employees promoted to a higher position shall
serve a twelve (12) month probationary period. (Ord. 1423, 10-22-1991)
   (C)   Seniority shall be terminated by:
      1.   Discharge for just cause.
      2.   Voluntary termination by the employee.
   (D)   Upon satisfactory completion of an employee's probationary period,
seniority will date back to the date of most recent hire. (Ord. 1151, 7-25-
1978)
1-23-5: PROMOTIONS AND SALARY ADJUSTMENTS:
   (A)   Salary Review: In the first quarter of each calendar year, a city
budget will be prepared to cover the ensuing fiscal year which commences on May
1 of each year and ends on April 30 of the following year. During the budget
preparation, the budget committee will review the wages and salaries of all
employees and make recommendations to the city council for any wage and salary
adjustments such as cost of living, promotion, wage and salary increases due to
change of duties and responsibilities, etc., in accordance with the
classification plan. (Ord. 1672, 4-24-2001)
   (B)   New Employees: The hiring of new employees to fill vacancies in the
police and fire organizations will be consummated by the police and fire
commissions. The personnel committee will recommend the starting wage or salary
for all new employees in accordance with the classification plan. No wage or
salary shall be approved that is in excess of that provided in the
classification plan. The city council will make final approval for hiring and
the starting wage or salary for new employees. (Ord. 1877, 7-10-2007)
   (C)   Regular Employee Bonuses: Each regular full time employee is eligible
for a salary bonus which is based upon the employee's work performance.
      1.   A bonus will be granted only for exceptional performance and
achievement.
      2.   Bonuses will be granted by department heads with the approval of the
mayor. Recommendations for employee bonuses shall be submitted by the
department head, in writing, to the mayor. The recommendation shall include the
name of the employee with a description of the employee's exceptional work
performance and achievement. (Ord. 1560, 4-9-1996, eff. 5-1-1996)
      3.   The aggregate amount of bonuses in any one fiscal year for each
department with five (5) or more employees shall not exceed one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00).
      4.   The aggregate amount of bonuses in any one fiscal year for each
department with less than five (5) employees shall not exceed one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00).
      5.   No regular full time employee shall receive a total bonus in excess
of eight hundred dollars ($800.00).
      6.   Any bonus will not increase the employee's base salary. (Ord. 1691,
4-9-2002)
   (D)   Department Head Bonuses: Each department head is eligible for a salary
bonus which is based upon the department head's exceptional work performance
and achievement.
      1.   Bonuses to department heads will be granted by the Mayor.
      2.   The aggregate amount of bonuses in any one fiscal year for
department heads shall not exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00).
      3.   No department head shall receive a total bonus in excess of seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) in any one fiscal year.
      4.   Any bonus will not increase the department head's base salary. (Ord.
1669, 2-13-2001)
   (E)   End Of Year Bonus: A bonus may be awarded to all regular full time
employees at the end of each calendar year. The Finance Committee shall review
such bonus at their meeting in November and forward their recommendation to the
City Council. Said recommendation shall indicate whether or not to award such
bonus, and the amount thereof. If awarded, the bonus shall be payable as part
of the first payroll in December.
   (F)   Reclassification During A Fiscal Year: At any time during a fiscal
year, an employee may seek a reclassification which might yield an increased
authorized wage or salary. An employee seeking such reclassification must first
submit to his or her department head a "request for job evaluation". The
department head shall then refer the matter to the Personnel Committee for its
consideration which may: 1) find after consideration of all available
information that the employee should be reclassified and his or her wages or
salary should be adjusted accordingly, or 2) find after consideration of all
available information that the employee should not be reclassified, or 3) find
that sufficient funds for a possible reclassification are not available in the
current budget and that the reclassification should be deferred. (Ord. 1988,
12-13-2011)
1-23-6: REST PERIODS:
All employees shall be granted one 15-minute rest period during each four (4)
hours of workday. Rest periods will be taken at such time as designated by
department heads. (Ord. 1151, 7-25-1978)
1-23-7: VACATIONS/COMPENSATORY TIME/PERSONAL DAY:
   (A)   Employees shall earn vacation time beginning with their first day of
employment. Full time employees are entitled to vacation benefits as listed
below:
 
After one year of work      80 hours
After five years of work    120 hours
After ten years of work     160 hours
After fifteen years of work 200 hours
 
Vacation hours shall accumulate per the following structure, with the final pay
period of the employee's anniversary year making the above mentioned total
hours whole:
 
First day of employment through five-year anniversary    3.0 hours/pay period
Completion of five years through ten-year anniversary    4.5 hours/pay period
Completion of ten years through fifteen-year anniversary 6.0 hours/pay period
Completion of fifteen years                              7.5 hours/pay period
 
   (B)   Accrual Cap: Employees shall be allowed to carry over a maximum of
forty (40) hours of vacation time from the preceeding anniversary year into the
next anniversary year. Employees who are unable to use their vacation due to
the nature of their employment shall be able to cash out vacation time at their
current rate of pay in lieu of losing earned vacation time. In no instance
shall an employee be able to cash out more than forty (40) hours of accrued
vacation per anniversary year.
   (C)   An employee on earned vacation shall receive the same wages and all
regular benefits as though he or she were working a normal work schedule.
Should a holiday occur while an employee is in a vacation status, such holiday
will not be charged against vacation time.
   (D)   Department heads are responsible for the approval of all vacation
leave requested by their employees. When a department head desires to enter a
vacation status, it must be brought to the attention of the Mayor. Any employee
who desires to establish his vacation leave in increments of five (5) days or
more must notify his supervisor thirty (30) days in advance of the initial date
of such leave.
   (E)   Employees requesting earned vacation/compensatory time shall notify
their department heads prior to starting of such leave and during regular
working hours. This requirement applies to leave requests for periods of less
than five (5) days. The employee's request for vacation/compensatory time shall
not be unreasonably withheld. However, the department head may take into
consideration the needs of the department and the City prior to authorizing
such leave.
   (F)   All department heads and non-union employees are granted two (2)
personal days annually. Employees requesting a personal day shall notify their
department head and such request shall not be unreasonably withheld. However,
the department head may take into consideration in approving the leave, the
needs of the department and City prior to authorizing such leave. Department
heads shall notify the Mayor of their request for a personal day and such
request shall not be unreasonably withheld subject to consideration by the
Mayor of the needs of the City. An employee's annual personal days shall accrue
on the annual anniversary day of their employment and must be used prior to
their next anniversary day of employment or the personal days shall be
forfeited. No personal days may be carried over to the next anniversary year.
   (G)   Separation Pay: Upon termination of employment, an employee shall be
compensated for vacation leave accrued up to the day of termination. If the
employee works six (6) full work days of the pay period, they shall be credited
for the entire pay period. There shall be no compensation for any unused
personal days. (Ord. 1867, 4-24-2007; amd. Ord. 2045, 6-25-2013; Ord. 2046, 6-
25-2013; Ord. 2181, 11-9-2016; Ord. 2286, 3-23-2021)
1-23-8: HOLIDAYS:
   (A)   Each employee of the City shall be granted eleven (11) paid holidays
per year. All holidays shall be observed on the date of the holiday except that
when the holiday falls on a Saturday, the employees will be scheduled off on
Friday and when the holiday falls on a Sunday, the employees will be scheduled
off on Monday. Members of the Police Department will be paid eight (8) hours
for the holiday in the pay period it occurs, and will not receive the holiday
as time off. Holiday pay will not count as overtime in the workweek. An
unexcused absence on either the day preceding or after a holiday will result in
the loss of pay for the holiday. This requirement applies to the regular
workday prior to and after any given holiday.
   (B)   In the event an employee, other than a member of the Police or Fire
Departments, is required to work a part or all of a recognized holiday, and if
such work falls within the employee's normal working hours, such employee will
be paid time and one-half (11/2) for such duty.
   (C)   The following are recognized as paid holidays for employees other than
members of the Police and Fire Departments:
New Year's Day
Presidents' Day
Good Friday
Memorial Day
Independence Day
Labor Day
Veterans Day
Thanksgiving Day
Day after Thanksgiving
Christmas Eve
Christmas Day
   (D)   Members of the Fire Department who are required to work on a holiday
will receive pay for a day in addition to their vacation leave. The Comptroller
will maintain such records.
   (E)   Employees in a probationary status will be entitled to holidays as
they occur. (Ord. 1151, 7-25-1978; Ord. 2008, 5-22-2012; amd. Ord. 2180, 11-9-
2016, eff. 1-1-2017)
1-23-9: SICK LEAVE; ADMINISTRATIVE LEAVE:
   (A)   Sick leave with full pay will be granted to all full time employees at
the rate of one workday for each full month of service, except for police
officers who will receive eight (8) hours per month. All regular employment
benefits shall be in effect while an employee is in a properly approved sick
leave status. Sick leave will be approved on account of sickness or in the
interest of the health of the employee only. Employees may use six (6) days of
their sick leave per calendar year for an illness or injury in his/her
immediate family. Immediate family shall include: spouse, child, grandchild,
stepchild, parent, step grandchild, grandparent, step grandparent, stepparent,
brother, stepbrother, sister, stepsister. Any employee who fraudulently uses
their sick leave compensations, will be subject to disciplinary action,
including dismissal. (Ord. 2010, 5-22-2012)
   (B)   Sick leave may be accrued on an unlimited basis. Upon retirement an
employee shall receive benefits equal to twenty percent (20%) of the balance of
accrued sick leave. Employees receiving Illinois Municipal retirement benefits
shall receive twenty percent (20%) of the residual remaining from pension
benefits. Benefits shall be paid at the final hourly rate received by
employees.
   (C)   Employees of the Police and Fire Departments seeking sick leave shall
notify the dispatcher no less than two (2) hours prior to the beginning of
their regularly scheduled working hours. Other employees seeking sick leave
shall notify their department heads or assistants at least one-half (1/2) hour
prior to their regularly scheduled working hours. Failure to notify the
dispatcher or department heads within the authorized time limit may result in
loss of pay for the duration for any given illness and may be subject to
disciplinary action.
   (D)   The department heads, at their discretion, may require a doctor's
certificate for any given illness. The Public Works Department employees will
be required to provide a doctor's certificate after receiving three (3)
approved sick leave events without a doctor's certificate in a calendar year.
   (E)   All full time employees of the City may have a maximum of thirty (30)
days' sick leave advanced, providing the employee makes a valid request,
supported by reasons for such requirement. All advanced sick leave must be
approved by the Mayor and Personnel Committee. Advanced sick leave will not be
granted to probationary employees.
   (F)   Any employee may be granted a maximum of three (3) days'
administrative leave, with pay, to accommodate the death of a member of the
immediate family of the employee. This is further defined as mother,
stepmother, father, stepfather, husband, wife, son, stepson, daughter,
stepdaughter, brother, stepbrother, sister, stepsister, grandparent, step
grandparent, grandchild, step grandchild, mother-in-law or father-in-law,
brother-in-law, son-in-law, sister-in-law or daughter-in-law. Such leave will
not be charged against sick or vacation leave of the employee. (Ord. 1865, 4-
10-2007; amd. Ord. 2010, 5-22-2012; amd. Ord. 2086, 2-11-2014; amd. Ord. 2249,
8-13-2019)
1-23-10: LAYOFFS:
Layoffs shall be governed by department seniority with the youngest employee in
point of service being first to be separated, provided the employees retained
on the payroll are capable of performing the tasks of the available workload
and have been given a satisfactory work performance by their supervisor. In
reemployment, the oldest employee in point of service shall be the first
recalled, provided such employee is capable and qualified in performing the
required work. (Ord. 1151, 7-25-1978)
1-23-11: LEAVE OF ABSENCE:
   (A)   Leave of absence, without pay, will be recommended by the department
head and must have the final approval of the Mayor.
   (B)   Leave of absence for more than six (6) months shall not be granted
unless approved by both the department head and the Mayor.
   (C)   Leave of absence for purposes of other employment will not be
authorized under any circumstances. (Ord. 1151, 7-25-1978)
1-23-12: MILITARY SERVICE:
   (A)   Leaves of absence without pay for military or reserve duty are granted
to full time regular and part time regular employees.
   (B)   Any employee called to active military duty or to reserve or National
Guard training, should notify the City and submit copies of military orders to
the City as soon as is practicable.
   (C)   A City employee will be granted a military leave of absence without
pay for the period of military service in accordance with applicable Federal
and State laws.
   (D)   Upon an employee's return from active military duty, they shall be
entitled to all rights of reemployment provided the employee:
      1.   Receives a certificate or other evidence of honorable discharge or
satisfactory completion of their military service under the laws of the United
States; and
      2.   Is, at the time of such discharge or completion of such military
service, still qualified to perform the duties of the position of employment
which they left (with or without accommodation); and
      3.   Makes application for reemployment within ninety (90) days after
they are relieved from such military service, or from hospitalization
continuing after discharge for a period of not more than one year.
   (E)   Employees reinstated as set forth herein by the City shall be entitled
to return to the position of employment which they left with the same increase
in status, seniority and wages that were paid during their term of military
service to employees in like positions. (Ord. 1762, 3-23-2004)
1-23-13: JURY DUTY:
   (A)   Any employee called to serve on any State or Federal jury shall be
paid the difference between his or her regular pay and compensation received
for jury duty.
   (B)   Any employee called for jury duty shall notify his or her department
head as soon as possible and upon completion of jury duty shall return to his
or her job as soon as possible. (Ord. 1151, 7-25-1978)
1-23-14: RECORDS:
All official personnel records shall be maintained as outlined in subsection
1-23-1(A) of this chapter. The Comptroller shall submit to each department
head, at the end of each month, a complete listing of their employees and
indicate sick, vacation leave and compensatory time used for that particular
period, together with the total current sick, vacation leave and compensatory
time credited to each employee. Department heads must establish and maintain
adequate records which will show technical and specialized training which has
been completed by their employees. (Ord. 1423, 10-22-1991)
1-23-15: DISCIPLINARY ACTIONS:
   (A)   Dismissal or suspension of any city employee must have the approval of
both the department head and the mayor, and further, is subject to the
requirements of section
1-23-16 of this chapter.
   (B)   City employees may be discharged for serious inefficiency, absence
without leave for three (3) consecutive days or five (5) days in a thirty (30)
day period, continual tardiness, intoxication, insubordination,
incompatibility, dishonesty, committing a felony, or for other similar reasons.
   (C)   Department heads or any city employee found guilty of intentionally
falsifying an action or a report of any type, which involves city assets or
funds, may be suspended, demoted or dismissed by the mayor, subject to the
approval of the requirements of section
1-23-16 of this chapter.
   (D)   A department head may, for less serious cause and with the approval of
the mayor, suspend an employee within his or her department for such length of
time as he considers appropriate, not to exceed two (2) weeks in any one
calendar year.
   (E)   All approved suspensions will be without pay for the employee
involved. (Ord. 1151, 7-25-1978)
1-23-16: GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE:
   (A)   Any employee, except police officers and firemen, who feels he has
received unfair treatment due to promotion, demotion, dismissal, suspension,
reprimand or for any other cause, shall present his case in writing to the city
clerk who shall notify the city council of receipt of the communication without
making public the name of the allegedly aggrieved. The council shall, at their
next regularly scheduled meeting, adjourn to executive session and consider the
matter. The council may elect to appoint a special board to inquire further and
prepare a complete written report to cover their findings. Both sides of the
grievance will be heard by either the council or a special board in a closed
session within ten (10) days after the initial action on the grievance. In the
event that the council decides that formal action is required, such action
shall be finalized at a closed meeting and all decisions shall be final and
binding for all parties concerned.
   (B)   Police and firemen who have a grievance in connection with dismissal
or suspension, or for any other cause as itemized in subsection (A) of this
section, will be brought to the attention of the mayor and city council.
Immediate action will then be taken to refer the case to the police and fire
commission for appropriate action 1 . (Ord. 1151, 7-25-1978)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 2-1-11 of this code.
1-23-17: HOSPITALIZATION, INSURANCE:
   (A)   Group Health Insurance: The city will administer a group health
insurance plan for those employees who desire to participate in the plan. The
city will pay one hundred percent (100%) of the premium cost for the
participating employee and fifty percent (50%) of the premium cost for
dependents of the participating employee. A new employee shall be eligible for
the group health insurance plan on the first day of the month following
completion of thirty (30) days of employment. (Ord. 1652, 12-14-1999)
   (B)   Rates: The mayor and department heads will negotiate with insurance
agents so as to provide the insurance coverage at the best possible rates.
(Ord. 1190, 4-8-1980)
   (C)   Termination Of Employment; Continuation Of Coverage:
      1.   An employee who terminates employment, either voluntarily or
involuntarily, is entitled to have issued to the employee a converted health
insurance policy without evidence of insurability. The cost of the converted
policy shall be solely at the former employee's expense. Written application
for the first converted policy and the first premium paid to the insurer must
be made not later than thirty one (31) days after termination of employment or
fifteen (15) days after the employee has been given written notice of the
conversion privilege, but not later than sixty (60) days after the termination
of employment. Written notice to the employee by the employer of this
conversion privilege must be sent to the last known address of the employee.
Continued coverage may be terminated if the former employee fails to make
timely premium payments or becomes covered by medicare or another health
insurance plan. Regardless of the former employee's compliance with these
conditions, continued coverage ends eighteen (18) months after the former
employee's employment has terminated. Continued coverage only is available for
employees who are covered by the healthcare plan of the city the day
immediately before the day of termination of employment.
      2.   An active employee participating in IMRF and eligible for IMRF
pension or disability benefit is entitled to have issued to the employee a
converted health insurance policy without evidence of insurability, under the
following conditions:
         (a)   The IMRF employee must be insured under the provisions of the
healthcare plan of the city on the day immediately before the day the employee
retires or becomes disabled. The IMRF employee is only eligible for
continuation coverage for that coverage which was provided to the employee on
that day.
         (b)   The IMRF employee upon termination of employment must be
entitled to an immediate receipt of an IMRF pension or disability benefit.
         (c)   Surviving spouses of IMRF employees are not eligible for
continuation coverage under this subsection (C), unless the retired or disabled
employee dies with dependent coverage and the surviving spouse is paid an IMRF
surviving spouse benefit. Any coverage for a surviving spouse ends if the
surviving spouse remarries before age fifty five (55).
         (d)   The disabled employee, retiree or surviving spouse is required
to pay the full premium of the converted policy.
         (e)   Continuation coverage ends if the retiree or disabled employee
becomes an active IMRF participant. Continuation coverage for a disabled
employee, retiree or surviving spouse ends if they are convicted of a job
related felony, die, fail to pay premiums, reach medicare age or the city
terminates insurance coverage for all employees.
         (f)   When an IMRF employee retires or becomes disabled, the city
shall give written notice to the insurance carrier within fifteen (15) days
that the employee is eligible for continued insurance coverage.
      3.   A former employee whose employment was terminated because of
dishonesty or commission of a crime is not eligible for continued coverage.
      4.   This subsection (C) is subject to the provisions of the Illinois
insurance code, the federal consolidated omnibus budget reconciliation act
(COBRA) and any other applicable state or federal laws. (Ord. 1557, 3-12-1996)
1-23-18: CLOTHING ALLOWANCE:
All full time employees in the public works, police and fire departments, and
the administrative department shall be granted a clothing allowance as follows:
   (A)   Public works department employees shall be allowed a total of three
hundred dollars ($300.00) for each individual employee for the purchase of
uniform clothing as approved by the department head and conditioned as follows:
      1.   Such allowance shall be made each fiscal year between the period May
1 through April 30. Unused balances can be carried over annually.
      2.   Such allowance shall be paid from the city financial assets upon
approval of a purchase order in accordance with chapter 20 of this title.
      3.   The comptroller shall maintain accurate records for each individual
employee and excess purchases must be paid for by the affected employee at the
time of the receipt of the merchandise.
      4.   The following items may be purchased by the public works personnel
to apply on clothing allowance:
         (a)   Shoes (in accordance with subsections
1-23-22(A)50 and (D)14(b) of this chapter);
         (b)   Trousers (long) - (in accordance with subsection
1-23-22(D)14 of this chapter);
         (c)   Shirts with sleeves - including pocket T-shirts and flannel with
company name;
         (d)   Winter coat or jacket with company name;
         (e)   Rain gear (parka and overall);
         (f)   Coveralls;
         (g)   Boots (winter snopak style);
         (h)   Sweatshirt - (basic or basic hooded zip front);
         (i)   Over the shoe boots;
         (j)   Insulated vest.
      5.   The following items shall be purchased by the city and issued to the
public works department:
         (a)   Hip boots or waders;
         (b)   Head protection - hard caps/hats;
         (c)   Caps with city logo/company name;
         (d)   Eye protection such as safety goggles or face protectors;
         (e)   Foot protectors;
         (f)   Hearing protectors.
   (B)   Police department employees shall be allowed a total of three hundred
fifty dollars ($350.00) for each individual employee for the purchase of
uniform clothing as approved by the department head. Part time employees are
not entitled to any uniform allowance. Such allowance shall be made each fiscal
year between the period May 1 through April 30, but unused balances can be
carried over annually, conditioned as follows:
      1.   A new hire shall receive a total of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
to apply for the purchase of their initial uniform clothing requirements.
      2.   Such allowance shall be paid from the city financial assets.
      3.   The comptroller shall maintain accurate records for each individual
employee and excess purchases must be paid for by the affected employee at the
time of the receipt of the merchandise.
      4.   The following items are to be purchased by the employee to apply on
clothing allowance:
         (a)   Belt, trouser;
         (b)   Necktie;
         (c)   Nameplates, shirt and coat;
         (d)   Shirts, short sleeve;
         (e)   Shirts, long sleeve;
         (f)   Trousers (short or long);
         (g)   Shoes;
         (h)   Cap;
         (i)   Cap, winter;
         (j)   Cap, strap;
         (k)   Jacket, lightweight;
         (l)   Raincoat;
         (m)   Rain cover, plastic, for summer cap;
         (n)   Jacket, winter;
         (o)   Shoulder patches;
         (p)   Sweaters;
         (q)   Uniform insignias;
         (r)   Work gloves (search and winter);
         (s)   Turtlenecks, mock and dickie.
      5.   The following items shall be purchased by the city and issued by the
police department and shall remain the property of the city and are to be
turned in upon separation from active police service:
         (a)   Service pistol or revolver;
         (b)   Pistol belt;
         (c)   Holster;
         (d)   Cartridge carrier;
         (e)   Mace;
         (f)   Mace holder;
         (g)   Handcuffs;
         (h)   Handcuff case;
         (i)   Nightstick;
         (j)   Nightstick stop;
         (k)   Nightstick carrier;
         (l)   Belt keepers, four (4) each;
         (m)   ID card;
         (n)   ID case;
         (o)   Badge for ID case;
         (p)   Badge, medium, two (2) each;
         (q)   Badge, hat emblem;
         (r)   Tie clasp;
         (s)   Hearing and eye protectors;
         (t)   Flashlight;
         (u)   Vest, bulletproof;
         (v)   CPR mask;
         (w)   Rubber glove/CPR pouch;
         (x)   Flashlight ring/carrier;
         (y)   Portable radio and portable radio case holder;
         (z)   Key holder.
   (C)   Fire department employees shall be allowed a total of three hundred
dollars ($300.00) for each individual employee for the purchase of uniform
clothing as approved by the department head. Such allowance shall be made each
fiscal year between the period May 1 through April 30, but unused balances can
be carried over annually, conditioned as follows:
      1.   A new hire shall receive a total of eight hundred dollars ($800.00)
to apply for the purchase of their initial uniform clothing requirements.
      2.   Such allowance shall be paid from city financial assets.
      3.   The comptroller shall maintain accurate records for each individual
employee and excess purchases must be paid for by the affected employee at the
time of the receipt of the merchandise or service.
      4.   The following items are to be purchased by the fire personnel to
apply to clothing allowance:
         (a)   Trousers;
         (b)   Shirts, short sleeve;
         (c)   Shirts, long sleeve;
         (d)   Belt;
         (e)   Shoes;
         (f)   Jacket, lightweight;
         (g)   Necktie;
         (h)   Winter coat;
         (i)   Shoulder patches;
         (j)   Badge, cap;
         (k)   T-shirts with maltese cross and name;
         (l)   Winter boots;
         (m)   Tie clasp;
         (n)   Collar insignia;
         (o)   Sweater;
         (p)   Nameplate coat/shirt;
         (q)   Cap;
         (r)   Cap, strap;
         (s)   Sweatshirt with maltese cross and name;
         (t)   Black shorts.
      5.   The following items shall be purchased by the City and issued to the
Fire Department and shall remain the property of the City and shall be turned
in upon separation from active fire service:
         (a)   Boots, firefighter's;
         (b)   Coat, firefighter's Nomex;
         (c)   Helmet, firefighter's;
         (d)   Badge, for shirt/coat;
         (e)   Pager;
         (f)   Light, flashing blue (vehicle mounted);
         (g)   Bunker pants, firefighter's Nomex;
         (h)   Bunker pants suspenders, firefighter's;
         (i)   Hood, Nomex;
         (j)   Gloves, firefighter's Nomex/Gore-Tex;
         (k)   CPR microshield.
   (D)   Administrative Department employees shall receive a total of one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each individual employee for the purchase
of uniform clothing, as approved by the department head and conditioned as
follows:
      1.   Such allowance shall be made each fiscal year between the period May
1 through April 30. Unused balances can be carried over annually.
      2.   Such allowance shall be paid from the City financial assets.
      3.   The Comptroller shall maintain accurate records for each individual
employee and excess purchases must be paid for by the affected employee at the
time of the receipt of the merchandise.
      4.   The following items may be purchased by Administrative Department
personnel to apply on the clothing allowance:
         (a)   Shirts (long sleeve or short sleeve) bearing an appropriate
emblem of the City of Savanna;
         (b)   Sweatshirts bearing an appropriate emblem of the City of
Savanna;
         (c)   Slacks.
   (E)   Public Works Department employees must wear the prescribed items
during working hours. Employees shall keep their uniforms and equipment in good
condition with no visible holes, tears or discoloration. Failure to wear or
maintain uniform clothing constitutes grounds for disciplinary action in
accordance with sections
1-23-15 and
1-23-16 of this chapter and may subject an employee violating this provision to
a loss of clothing allowance. (Ord. 2049, 7-9-2013)
1-23-19: TRAVEL, TRAINING, MEAL AND LODGING EXPENSES:
   (A)   Definitions:
    ENTERTAINMENT: Includes, but is not limited to, shows, amusements,
theaters, circuses, sporting events, or any other place of public or private
entertainment or amusement, unless ancillary to the purpose of the program or
event.
   PUBLIC BUSINESS: Expenses incurred in the performance of a public purpose
which is required or useful for the benefit of the City to carry out the
responsibilities of the City business.
   TRAVEL: Any expenditure directly incident to the official travel by
employees and officers of the City or by wards or charges of the City involving
reimbursement to travelers or direct payment to private agencies providing
transportation or related services.
   (B)   Reimbursement: The City shall only reimburse the following types of
travel, meal and lodging expenses incurred by its employees and officers up to
the following maximum allowable amounts:
      1.   City employees will be authorized to go on a travel status for
purposes of training, meetings, conferences, etc., when such activities are
directly related to official City business. All forms of travel will be
recommended by the department head and approved by the Mayor. Individuals who
utilize their own private conveyance for travel purposes will be paid at the
rate of fifty four cents ($0.54) per mile. Upon completion of travel, an
employee will be reimbursed for other expenses such as lodging, food, etc.,
providing proof of such expenses is made available to the City Comptroller and
the expenses are in accordance with this section. Meal reimbursement shall not
exceed twenty dollars ($20.00) per meal.
      2.   All travel authorizations as recommended by the department head must
be presented to the Mayor for final approval. A department head who must leave
the City on official business during his regular work shift should advise the
Mayor prior to his departure. Police personnel who are required to report to
the County Courthouse for law enforcement proceedings are an exception to this
requirement.
      3.   Alcohol is specifically excluded from reimbursement.
   (C)   Form Required: No reimbursement of travel, meal or lodging expenses
incurred by a City employee or officer shall be authorized unless the "Travel,
Meal and Lodging Expense Reimbursement Request Form", on file in the City, has
been submitted and approved. All documents and information submitted with the
form shall be subject to disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act 1 .
   (D)   Exceeding Maximum Reimbursement: Expenses for travel, meals and
lodging of: 1) any officer or employee that exceeds the maximum reimbursement
allowed under the regulations adopted under subsection (B) of this section or
2) any member of the Corporate Authorities of the City may only be approved by
roll call vote at an open meeting of the Corporate Authorities of the City.
However, in the event of emergency or other extraordinary circumstances, the
Corporate Authorities may approve more than the maximum allowable expenses set
forth above.
   (E)   Entertainment: The City shall not reimburse any elected official,
employee, or officer for any activities which would be considered
entertainment. Activities which would otherwise be considered entertainment,
but which are excluded from the prohibition on reimbursement due to being
