ancillary to the purpose of the program or event may be reimbursed in
accordance with the provisions of this section. (Ord. 2193, 3-14-2017, eff. 3-
14-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.
1-23-20: PENSION PLANS:
   (A)   All City employees, other than police and firemen, must participate in
the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund Program. Payroll deductions, as required
by law, will be made from employee's wages each pay period as their
contribution to the Retirement Fund.
   (B)   Police and fire personnel will participate in Policemen's and
Firemen's Pension Fund in compliance with State Statutes. Payroll deductions
will be made each pay period from wages of police and fire personnel as their
contribution to the Pension Fund 1 . (Ord. 1151, 7-25-1978)
 
Notes
1 2. See title 2, chapters 2 and 3 of this Code.
1-23-21: INJURIES, DISABILITY FROM INJURIES IN LINE OF DUTY:
   (A)   Continuing Compensation For City Employees: Whenever any City employee
who is employed on a full time basis by the City suffers any injury in the line
of duty which causes him to be unable to perform his duties, he shall continue
to be paid by the City on the same basis as he was paid before the injury, with
no deduction from his sick leave credits, compensatory time for overtime
accumulations or vacation, or service credits in a public employee pension fund
during the time he is unable to perform his duties due to the result of the
injury, but not longer than one year in relation to the same injury.
   (B)   Order Examinations: At any time during the period for which continuing
compensation is required by this chapter, the City may order, at the expense of
the City, physical or medical examinations of the injured person to determine
the degree of disability.
   (C)   Forfeit Of Compensation: During this period of disability, the injured
person shall not be employed in any other manner, with or without monetary
compensation. Any person who is employed in violation of this paragraph
forfeits the continuing compensation provided by this chapter from the time
such employment begins. Any salary compensation due the injured person from
workers' compensation or any salary due him from any type of insurance which
may be carried by the City shall revert to the City during the time for which
continuing compensation is paid him under this chapter. Any disabled person
receiving compensation under the provisions of this chapter shall not be
entitled to any benefits for which he would qualify because of his disability
under the provisions of the Illinois Pension Code, as amended, before or after
this chapter becomes a law. (Ord. 1154, 10-10-1978)
1-23-22: SAFETY CODE:
   (A)   Rules: The rules included in this section were developed as a result
of injuries or accidents experienced by City employees. The rules cannot tell
every step to take, but they do enumerate a few steps that must always be taken
and a few steps that must never be taken.
      1.   Employees do not have special traffic rights. Employees operating
equipment on streets or highways shall obey all State and City traffic laws and
department policies.
      2.   The number of employees permitted to ride in a car or truck shall
not exceed the seat space and seat belts as provided by the manufacturer.
      3.   It is the operator's responsibility to report all vehicle and
equipment malfunctions and defective parts at once.
      4.   Safety seat belts installed in vehicles and mobile equipment shall
be used by the operator and passengers while the vehicle or mobile equipment is
in use.
      5.   Riding on the outside of equipment is prohibited except where
provision is made for the operator or others while performing an operation for
which the equipment is designed.
      6.   Do not mount or dismount moving vehicles or equipment.
      7.   Operators shall not operate vehicles or mobile equipment in reverse
unless they are certain the backing movement can be made safely. When the
vision to the rear is limited and a fellow employee is available, such employee
shall be utilized by the operator to assist with the backing movement. The
person assisting the operator shall take a position outside the vehicle so as
not to be exposed to oncoming traffic or the backing vehicle.
      8.   Employees shall not operate motorcycles, scooters or motorized bikes
in the course of employment nor at city expense.
      9.   When stopped or parked on the shoulder, as much clearance as
possible shall be maintained between the edge of the pavement and the near side
of the vehicles. If less than two feet (2') or approximately two-thirds (2/3)
meter clearance is provided, the four-way flashers and/or revolving light shall
be used.
      10.   Do not smoke where flammable or combustible liquids are being
handled, stored or used.
      11.   Do not use gasoline to start fires.
      12.   Do not store or transport gasoline in open or unmarked containers.
Use only containers manufactured for such purpose. All containers shall be
properly labeled.
      13.   Do not use gasoline as a cleaning solvent. Use commercial cleaner
or kerosene to wash parts and equipment.
      14.   Horseplay is prohibited.
      15.   Extension and office equipment cords shall be in good condition and
secured so that they will not be under foot.
      16.   Always keep file drawers and desk drawers closed when not in use.
      17.   Do not open more than one drawer of a file cabinet at any time.
      18.   Use red/orange flags (red light or lantern at night that is visible
for a minimum of 500 feet or 150 meters to the sides and rear) to mark the end
of any loaded material extending four feet (4') or approximately one and one-
third (11/3) meters beyond the rear of the bed or body of the vehicle.
      19.   When leaving equipment unattended at any location, block all
blades, buckets, booms, beds, plows and devices or lower to down positions;
remove ignition or starter switch key.
      20.   Do not operate, adjust or repair gasoline or diesel powered
equipment when it is running in a closed area without adequate ventilation or
facilities for removing exhaust fumes.
      21.   Do not use a tractor with defective safety starting system.
      22.   No one shall ride in any end loader bucket at any time.
      23.   Do not start a tractor unless seated in the operator's seat.
      24.   After mounting a tire on a demountable rim, a safety cage or other
safety devices shall be used when inflating truck or off the road equipment
type tires.
      25.   When towing towed type equipment, in addition to securing the
hooking device, the driver of the vehicle shall make certain that two (2)
safety chains are securely attached or hooked to the towing vehicle and towed
unit.
      26.   Never reach, crawl or work under any raised or suspended equipment
without using cribbing, solid blocks or approved safety devices to prevent the
raised or suspended equipment from falling.
      27.   Only electrically powered tools and equipment which have been
grounded or are double insulated shall be used.
      28.   Before changing attachments, repairing or adjusting electrically or
pneumatically powered tools and/or equipment, they shall be unplugged or
disconnected. Lock and tag electrical breaker box if directly wired.
      29.   When operating a power saw, observe the following precautions:
         (a)   All guards shall be in place.
         (b)   Use only sharp blades in good repair.
         (c)   Wear eye and/or face protection.
         (d)   Table saw - Use a stick to push narrow or short pieces of lumber
through power saws when making a rip cut.
      30.   The following precautions shall be observed when operating a
grinder:
         (a)   Make certain the grinding wheels are tight on the shaft.
         (b)   Check grinding wheels for cracks, chips, uneven wear or other
defects. If wheel is cracked, replace it. If uneven or chipped, dress with a
dressing wheel or replace.
         (c)   Use only grinding wheels designed for the size and speed of the
grinder.
         (d)   Tool rests shall be properly adjusted (not more than 1/8 inch or
3.17 millimeters from grinding wheel).
         (e)   Wheel guards shall be in place.
         (f)   Do not use side of wheel for grinding.
         (g)   Even though grinder is equipped with fixed face shield, eye
protection shall also be used.
      31.   Except when riding on self-propelled equipment, all employees
engaged in activities on or within fifteen feet (15') or approximately four and
one-half (41/2) meters of the edge of the pavement which normally do not
require flagmen shall wear high visibility vests.
      32.   Maintenance operations or other work on or within two feet (2') or
approximately two-thirds (2/3) meter of the pavement requiring the diversion or
stopping of traffic shall be conducted with the protection of a flagman. When
the work activity, continuous or intermittent, exceeds fifteen (15) minutes,
advance warning signs shall also be used.
      33.   Do not stand on or within two feet (2') or approximately two-thirds
(2/3) meter of an open traffic lane to talk with the driver of a vehicle parked
on the road shoulder.
      34.   It shall be the responsibility of the employee in charge to ensure
that traffic control devices used in daily operation for the protection of the
workers and the public be removed at the end of the day's work. All temporary
warning signs shall be removed as soon as the hazard has been eliminated.
      35.   The flagman shall be:
         (a)   Stationed at least one hundred feet (100') or approximately
thirty (30) meters from work site and workers.
         (b)   Stationed away from equipment.
         (c)   Stationed so they can be seen at least five hundred feet (500')
or approximately one hundred fifty (150) meters by oncoming traffic. (Avoid
stationing flagman in shaded areas where they will not be visible to
approaching traffic.)
         (d)   Stationed at an effective location other than the open traffic
lane.
         (e)   Always alert for oncoming traffic and not turn their back on
traffic in the lane under control until traffic responds.
      36.   Flagmen shall be equipped with and required to wear or use the
following:
         (a)   Hard caps or hard hats.
         (b)   High visibility vests (reflectorized for night work).
         (c)   Flagman traffic control signs.
         (d)   For night operations, a red lantern or flashlight with red wand
shall be used. (Note: The flagman station should be illuminated.)
      37.   When using distributors or asphalt kettles, the following must be
observed:
         (a)   Do not use the unit until you have been instructed in its proper
operation.
         (b)   Do not light burner with a match held in the hand. Use a stiff
wire or stick lighting torch.
         (c)   Lowering chains shall be used to add a full drum (drum shall be
punctured on sides and ends) of asphalt to a heating kettle.
         (d)   To prevent hot asphalt from being splashed, do not throw chunks
of asphalt into heated kettle.
         (e)   Do not heat asphalt when there is evidence of accumulated
moisture in the asphalt, kettle or distributor tank.
         (f)   Do not allow the level of the heated asphalt to get below the
heating flues or coils.
      38.   Pavements cracks and joints are to be poured in a direction moving
from the centerline to the shoulder. Never cross centerline or lane line into
an open traffic lane.
      39.   Never operate a tractor mower on a slope with the sickle bar
operating on the down slope side.
      40.   Mowers operating in the same direction shall maintain an interval
of at least three hundred feet (300') or approximately ninety (90) meters.
      41.   Always face the ladder when climbing up or down.
      42.   Never use metallic ladders when making electrical repairs or when
working near electrical lines and power sources.
      43.   No one shall work in trenches or excavations five feet (5') or
approximately one and one-half (11/2) meters or deeper unless OSHA standards
pertaining to protective procedures are followed. (Consult your supervisor.)
      44.   All personnel shall wear lifelines when entering a manhole. At
least two (2) workers shall remain on the surface in such a position that they
can observe and assist in the removal of those in the manhole.
      45.   Open flames, torches, lighted cigars, cigarettes, pipes, flame or
spark producing devices shall not be brought into or near an open manhole.
      46.   Operators of boom equipment and workers handling long pieces of
conductive material shall be constantly on the alert for overhead power and
telephone lines.
      47.   Do not stand or walk under suspended loads or so near a cable under
tension that you can be struck should the cable break or load shift.
      48.   All LP (liquified petroleum), acetylene and oxygen gas cylinders
whether empty or full shall be securely fastened at all times in an upright
position to prevent falling. The cylinder valves shall be turned off when the
cylinders are not being utilized.
      49.   Head protection in the form of hard caps/hats shall be worn by all
city employees involved in field activities where there is possible danger of
head injury from falling objects, impact from flying or swinging objects,
contact with fixed objects, or from electrical shock and burns and at locations
or sites designated as hard cap/hat areas.
Head protection in the form of a bump cap is to be worn by employees whose
normal duties are that of performing automotive and/or equipment repairs where
there is danger of bumping and/or lacerations to the head.
The employee in charge has the authority and responsibility to order the
wearing of head protection where there is danger of head injury due to a hazard
not covered elsewhere in the safety code.
      50.   Safety toe footwear shall be worn by employees engaged in
operations where the danger of injury to the foot may occur.
      51.   All air hammer operations shall wear foot protection capable of
providing protection to the toes and metatarsal arch. (Ord. 1179, 11-13-1979)
      52.   Eye protection, such as safety goggles, glasses or face protectors,
shall be worn when observing, performing or assisting with any operation where
danger of injury to the eye or face may occur and which shall include, but not
be limited to, the following:
         (a)   Grinders.
         (b)   Lathes.
         (c)   Drill presses.
         (d)   Sanders.
         (e)   Power saws.
         (f)   Welding.
         (g)   Sandblasting.
         (h)   When using compressed air for cleaning.
         (i)   When making repairs under equipment.
         (j)   When using cold chisels or star drills.
         (k)   Pavement breaking or drilling.
         (l)   When using handheld weed burning equipment.
         (m)   When working with wet cell batteries.
         (n)   Chemicals.
         (o)   When striking metal objects of any type with a hammer or maul.
(Ord. 1186, 1-8-1980)
   (B)   General Safety Requirements: The practices outlined in this subsection
apply to all employees regardless of position or job assignment.
      1.   Hazards And Emergencies:
         (a)   Every employee should watch constantly for hazards along the
streets, highways or their place of employment. If one is noted, it should be
removed or proper protection provided by placing appropriate warnings such as
signs, cones, flags, torches or barricades. Employees not prepared to perform
this type of work shall notify their superior.
         (b)   Employees who see or learn of any damage to city property shall
report the damage to their superior or to the office to which the employee is
assigned.
         (c)   Reasonable assistance in emergencies should be offered to anyone
involved in an accident along the highway or in obvious distress whether or not
city equipment is involved and no other aid is on the scene.
         (d)   If any employee observes a motor vehicle or other equipment of a
utility company, contractor or others parked upon the roadway, or workers
working on or adjacent to the pavement without being protected by adequate
signs, flags or personnel directing traffic, the employee should notify their
superior.
      2.   Accident Reporting: Failure to follow reporting procedures may
disqualify an employee from receiving workers' compensation benefits.
         (a)   All accidents (including physical collapse) occurring in the
course of employment involving city personnel and/or equipment shall be
reported as soon as possible to the office to which the employee is assigned.
(Ord. 1179, 11-13-1979)
         (b)   It shall be the duty of every employee to report all accidents
in accordance with the following:
            (1)   Accidents which involve city personnel and/or equipment shall
be reported on the proper form within twenty four (24) hours after occurrence.
            (2)   All vehicle and equipment accidents shall be reported on
forms supplied by the police department (form-SR 1733).
            (3)   All personnel injury accidents shall be reported on forms
supplied by the business office (form 45).
            (4)   All accidents, including vehicular, equipment and personnel
injuries, shall be reviewed by a board of accident investigation. Said board,
when used in this chapter, shall consist of the department head for the
department involved and two (2) city council members appointed by the mayor.
The mayor shall serve as a board member when an accident involves a department
head.
The board shall conduct a thorough investigation to determine the cause,
negligence and responsibility for the accident and shall submit a written
report to the city council for further consideration.
            (5)   Vehicle accidents involving Savanna police department
vehicles shall be investigated by the Carroll County sheriff's department or by
the Illinois state police.
            (6)   A copy of all completed accident reports will be made
available to the mayor for subsequent board action. (Ord. 1224, 7-14-1981)
         (c)   Injuries incurred during working hours but resulting from
horseplay, altercations, or while engaged in activities for personal benefit,
may deprive the employee of benefits provided by the workers' compensation act
and the Illinois municipal retirement system.
         (d)   The operator of a vehicle or mobile equipment operated at city
expense having been involved in an accident shall immediately notify the
nearest local police, sheriff department or state police.
         (e)   No oral or written statement is to be made by an employee
regarding an accident involving city property or employees, except reports to a
police officer, unless approved by the employee's department head.
         (f)   Incidents involving loss or damage to city buildings and
equipment resulting from explosives, fire, theft, vandalism and storm shall be
reported immediately to the department head.
      3.   Safe Driving Practices:
         (a)   Select overnight parking locations that will present the least
hazard to the traveling public and city vehicles and equipment.
         (b)   When visibility is reduced during daylight operations, use
headlights with beams depressed.
         (c)   Do not shift the vehicle into neutral or disengage the clutch
when traveling downgrade.
         (d)   To minimize skidding when stopping on wet or icy pavement, apply
the brakes with a pumping action. Avoid sudden application of brakes.
         (e)   Drive cautiously and be prepared to stop when approaching a
child, pedestrian, or person riding a bicycle on the street or highway.
         (f)   Should disabled equipment, either city or privately owned, be
parked on the pavement without proper protection, it is the duty of employees
to protect traffic by placing fusees, reflectors or torches. In the case of
privately owned vehicles, the matter should then be referred to the nearest
police agency as soon as possible.
         (g)   All city owned cars and trucks shall be equipped with fully
stocked first aid kits.
         (h)   Always signal a turning movement or a lane change.
         (i)   Special attention should be given to keeping windshields,
windows, headlamps and tail lamp lenses clean.
         (j)   Damaged glass and lenses of vehicles shall be replaced as soon
as practical.
         (k)   For a safe following distance, always allow a minimum of two (2)
seconds counting time between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead.
         (l)   While refueling vehicles and equipment:
            (1)   Turn off engine.
            (2)   Do not smoke or permit an open flame.
            (3)   Read instructions for the operations of gasoline dispensing
equipment posted at each self-service station before refueling.
            (4)   To avoid backsplash, stand to one side or far enough away to
avoid getting gasoline on clothing.
            (5)   Replace gas tank cap when finished.
         (m)   Caution shall always be used when removing radiator cap from
equipment or vehicles. Never remove the radiator cap from equipment or vehicles
when the motor is overheated.
         (n)   When it is necessary to stop a city vehicle at locations where
traffic does not normally stop, the city operator shall give warning to
following vehicles by flashing his brake lights and slowing down gradually.
         (o)   Exercise care in attempting to start a vehicle with a "booster
battery". See your supervisor for proper instructions.
         (p)   To prevent the overflow of gasoline and possible fire, leave
sufficient space at the top of the tanks and/or containers for expansion.
      4.   Fire Prevention:
         (a)   All employee occupied buildings shall be adequately equipped
with fire extinguishers. The fire extinguisher shall be selected and placed
according to hazards.
            (1)   All fire extinguishers shall be visually inspected every
thirty (30) days by the employees in charge to:
   A. Ensure that they are in their designated places.
   B. Ensure they have not been actuated or tampered with.
   C. Detect any obvious physical or chemical change.
            (2)   All fire extinguishers are to be:
   A. Serviced at least once each year by an approved service agency.
   B. Tagged to show date of last inspection and recharge.
   C. Labeled to provide immediate identification as to its type.
         (b)   Vehicles and mobile equipment which carry fire extinguishers
shall have extinguishers: 1) bracket mounted, 2) located as to be accessible,
and 3) periodically inspected (see subsection (B)4(a) of this section for
inspection schedule and requirements).
         (c)   If a fire extinguisher has been used or damaged, report the use
or damage immediately to the individual in charge so that it will be replaced
by a serviceable unit.
         (d)   "No smoking" signs shall be conspicuously posted in areas where
combustible and flammable materials are stored and distributed and this warning
shall be strictly enforced.
         (e)   Do not throw matches or cigarette butts directly into waste
baskets; use ashtrays. Check ashtrays for any signs of smoldering materials
before emptying into trash containers.
         (f)   When a fire is discovered, an employee should do three (3)
things:
            (1)   Alert fellow workers.
            (2)   Turn in the alarm (no matter how small the fire appears to
be).
            (3)   If trained, use the proper firefighting equipment.
         (g)   In case of fire, all personnel shall be evacuated to an area of
safety and away from firefighter's arena of activity.
      5.   Firefighting Emergencies: A minimum of two (2) firefighting
personnel shall conduct firefighting operations within any building.
   (C)   Office Activities: The practices outlined in this subsection apply to
personnel assigned to an office, or to personnel who may at some time during a
normal work day perform an office activity.
      1.   Tripping Hazards, Slips And Falls:
         (a)   Chairs shall not be used as ladders. Use stepladders, step
stools or similar devices for reaching high places.
         (b)   Be alert for slipping hazards such as freshly mopped floors and
stairs. Wet or slippery stairs and floors shall be reported immediately.
         (c)   Use handrails when going up or down stairways.
         (d)   When going around corners, keep to the right and be alert for
other employees, handcarts and hand trucks and other objects.
         (e)   Open doors with caution; another person may be approaching from
the other side.
         (f)   Remove objects such as pencils, paperclips and rubber bands from
floors whenever noticed as they may contribute to falls resulting in serious
injury.
         (g)   All chairs and equipment shall be kept in good repair; report
defects immediately.
      2.   Housekeeping And Building Maintenance:
         (a)   Broken glass and other sharp objects shall be wrapped in heavy
paper, marked "broken glass" or "sharp objects" and placed beside, not in, the
waste basket.
         (b)   Aisles, halls and stairways shall be kept clear of objects that
may cause employees to fall.
         (c)   Keep exits clear at all times. Fire doors shall not be blocked
at any time or made inoperative.
         (d)   Keep work and storage areas clean and orderly.
         (e)   Precautionary measures shall be taken when disposing of used
pressurized containers. Follow the instructions given on the containers.
         (f)   Good housekeeping practices shall be followed at all times.
      3.   General Office Safety:
         (a)   Distribute weight in file cabinets to prevent top heavy
conditions.
         (b)   When emptying drawers of file cabinets, empty top drawers first.
         (c)   Electric fans and other equipment with exposed rotating parts
shall be equipped with proper guarding. (Fans shall be guarded with 1/2 inch
mesh or finer to prevent fingers from coming into contact with blades.)
         (d)   Avoid sitting on the front edge of a swivel base chair or
tipping any chair.
         (e)   Do not use pins to fasten papers.
         (f)   Glass desk tops shall be free of breaks and sharp edges.
   (D)   Field Activities, Shops And Storages: The practices outlined in this
subsection apply to personnel working at a location (other than an office) to
which the employee reports or is assigned.
      1.   Trucks And Mobile Equipment:
         (a)   All trucks shall have the proper emergency warning kits, in
addition to the required number of fusees, which must be maintained in a
serviceable condition for emergency use.
         (b)   When mounting or dismounting vehicles or equipment, use hand
holds and ladders to prevent injury from slips and falls.
         (c)   When changing tires on motor vehicles and equipment, set
emergency brake and use blocks to prevent vehicle from rolling and do not stand
or work on the pavement.
         (d)   Trucks shall be loaded in such a way that the cargo will not
spill or fall off the truck. All ledges and rubrails shall be free of stones
and other material that could drop off and hit other property or persons.
         (e)   All trucks shall have the proper lights and reflectors.
         (f)   Proper use of rotating oscillating lights. The revolving warning
lights on vehicles so equipped must be used during the following operations:
            (1)   When plowing snow or spreading chemicals and/or abrasives.
            (2)   When traveling with mounted snowplows or other over width
attachments.
            (3)   When performing slow moving operations.
            (4)   When temporarily stopped on roadway surface during an
emergency operation.
            (5)   When towing equipment.
            (6)   Red lights shall be activated whenever emergency vehicles are
operated in excess of posted speed limits or such other circumstances as may be
required to provide for safety to persons and/or property.
         (g)   Take all other precautions necessary to assure that no one,
especially children, can start, operate or cause any movement of parked
equipment.
         (h)   A truck may be operated with the endgate or liftgate in the open
or horizontal position only when necessary or for load situation.
         (i)   Select parking locations for city vehicles and equipment that
will not hide any traffic sign or signal.
         (j)   While refueling vehicles and equipment:
            (1)   Turn off engine.
            (2)   Keep nozzle or spout in direct contact with the tank.
            (3)   Do not smoke.
            (4)   Extinguish all open flames or burners.
            (5)   Have not less than twenty (20) BC fire extinguisher
available.
         (k)   A "slow moving vehicle emblem" shall be properly displayed on
all mobile equipment designed to travel less than twenty five (25) mph so
traffic to the rear may see the emblem.
         (l)   City employees must comply with posted speed limits except under
the following conditions:
            (1)   When performing slow moving operations.
            (2)   When reduced speed is necessary for safe operation of the
vehicle.
            (3)   When working on the roadway surface with the protection of
signs, barricades, escort vehicles and/or flagmen.
            (4)   When performing emergency police and fire operations. Maximum
speeds shall be posted in the emergency vehicles by the department head.
         (m)   When traveling in traffic, do not operate the vehicle at such a
slow rate of speed as to cause an accumulation of other vehicles behind. If a
slow rate of speed is unavoidable, occasionally pull off the road and wait in
order that traffic may clear.
         (n)   All culvert headwall openings and other hazards shall be marked
with a post to indicate such hazards to employees.
         (o)   Equipment designed to be towed, having light systems installed,
shall be properly electrically connected to the towing vehicle and the lights
shall be operational before moving onto the highway.
      2.   Shops And Storages:
         (a)   All employee occupied buildings shall have first aid kits which
shall be stocked with the minimum requirements for the number of people working
in and around that particular building.
         (b)   Good housekeeping practices shall be followed at all times.
         (c)   Used oily and paint rags shall be placed in an approved metal
container equipped with a self-closing lid.
         (d)   Precautionary measures shall be taken when disposing of used
pressurized containers. Follow the instructions given on the container.
         (e)   Spilled substances and materials shall be cleaned from floors
and loading ramps immediately to prevent slips and falls.
         (f)   Compressed air used in shops and storages for cleaning shall be
limited to less than thirty (30) psi and the nozzle shall be equipped with a
chip guard.
         (g)   Do not use extension cords which have faulty insulation or
connections.
         (h)   Tools shall not be left lying where employees are likely to trip
or fall over them.
         (i)   Use tools for their intended purpose.
      3.   Welding:
         (a)   Should it be necessary to weld, cut, solder or do other hot work
on a tank or container which previously contained gasoline, flammable material
or other chemicals, the welder/solderer shall make certain such tank or
container has been thoroughly steamed cleaned inside and that the cap or lid is
removed so as to prevent production of flammable or toxic vapors.
         (b)   Cutting and welding operations shall be performed in adequately
ventilated areas.
         (c)   Never leave heating or cutting torches unattended when lighted.
Whenever practicable, all arc welding and cutting operations shall be shielded
by noncombustible or flameproof screens to protect employees and other persons
working in the vicinity from the direct rays of the arc.
      4.   Tools; Power And Hand:
         (a)   Power saws shall not be left running unattended.
         (b)   When working with chisels, star drills and/or wedges, the
following shall be observed:
            (1)   Maintain sharp cutting edge.
            (2)   Striking surfaces should not be mushroomed or have an
overhang (dress or replace).
            (3)   Use only tools that are free of cracks or checks.
            (4)   Employees required to face the work shall wear eye
protection.
            (5)   Wood chisels shall have a tight handle and sharp cutting
edge.
         (c)   Observe the following when using lift jacks:
            (1)   Make certain lift jacks are properly placed before making
lift.
            (2)   Make certain the lifting capacity of jack is adequate for
load to be raised.
            (3)   Do not lean over a jack handle while jack is under load.
            (4)   Removable jack handles shall be removed when lifting
operations are completed.
            (5)   When working under a raised load, use blocks or cribbing to
support the load.
         (d)   Handles, sockets and rivets of all shovels shall be smooth and
securely fastened. Shovels shall never be used in place of a lever or pry bar.
         (e)   Proper spacing of workers shall be given attention at all times,
especially when using hand tools, since it is not uncommon for workers to be
injured by a tool in the hands of a fellow worker.
         (f)   Faulty, damaged or broken tools shall be kept separately or
properly disposed of in accordance with city policy.
         (g)   Axes, hammers, picks and sledges shall be properly balanced and
have a tight and securely wedged smooth straight grained handle. All such tools
with battered, mushroomed or cracked striking faces or taped handles shall not
be used.
         (h)   While using a wrench, take a position to prevent striking an
adjacent object should the nut release suddenly.
         (i)   Powder actuated hand tools, such as "ramset" type guns, shall be
used only by certified operators who have been instructed in the safety
precautions and limitations recommended by the manufacturer.
         (j)   Do not operate any equipment until all protective guards are in
place.
      5.   Worksite Protection And Flagging Traffic: (Note: In this subsection
(D)5, it is not possible to prescribe detailed signing diagrams for all
situations that may arise; therefor, refer to the current standards for
construction and maintenance signing. In the event questions arise in respect
to required signing, consult with your immediate superior.)
         (a)   Replacement Of Signs: Permanent signs temporarily removed
because of maintenance or construction operations along the roadway shall be
replaced immediately upon completion of the work. In the meantime, work crews
and traffic shall be protected by appropriate signs placed upon temporary
stands.
         (b)   Vehicles Or Mobil Equipment Used As Barricades: Do not use
vehicles or mobile equipment as barricade(s) unless specifically designed for
that purpose, such as escort vehicles, emergency patrol vehicles and towed
arrow boards.
         (c)   Extraordinary Conditions: Should extraordinary conditions
require facing of equipment in the wrong direction for loading or unloading,
ample protection must be provided with additional flagmen by the employee in
charge.
         (d)   Pothole Patching, Debris Or Dead Animal Removal: Emergency
single pothole patching, debris or dead animal removal may be performed by an
employee without a flagman providing sufficient gaps in traffic are available
to accomplish the work without diverting or stopping traffic. Also, the
employee shall wear a hard cap or hat, a high visibility vest and must perform
such emergency task with extreme care. When it is necessary to stop the vehicle
within two feet (2') or approximately two-thirds (2/3) meter of the pavement,
the four- way emergency flashers and revolving light shall be used if vehicle
is so equipped.
         (e)   Orange Flags Displayed: It is the responsibility of the employee
in charge to ensure that high visibility orange flags are displayed on all
single warning signs and on at least the first of a series of warning signs.
         (f)   Legible Signs: For the protection of the working crew and
traveling public, do not use signs that are so badly defaced that their
legibility is affected. Poorly maintained signs are ineffective and may
contribute to accidents. Request new signs as needed.
         (g)   Erection Of Signs: Barricades and warning signs on temporary
stands shall be erected in such a manner that they will withstand other forces
such as passing vehicles and anticipated winds. If necessary, use filled
sandbags or stakes to hold the devices in place. Sandbags, should they be
necessary, shall be suspended or placed on the lowest support of the barricade
or sign stand. Never place a sandbag on the top of a barricade or sign so as to
hide part of the device. Do not use concrete blocks, pieces of steel or similar
items that could become a flying missile if hit by a vehicle.
         (h)   Flagging Traffic: Supervisory personnel shall familiarize
themselves and personnel assigned to flagging traffic with the procedures
outlined in chapter 6, section 6-5, entitled "control of traffic through work
areas", as contained in the "Illinois Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices
For Streets And Highways".
         (i)   Qualifications: Flagmen shall possess the following
qualifications:
            (1)   Average intelligence.
            (2)   Good physical condition, including sight and hearing.
            (3)   Mental alertness.
            (4)   Courteous but firm manner.
            (5)   Neat appearance.
            (6)   Pleasing personality.
            (7)   Sense of responsibility for safety of public and crew.
         (j)   Warn Of Danger: It shall be the duty of the flagmen to warn the
workers of danger should the driver of a vehicle fail to heed the flagman's
signals.
         (k)   Stationing Of Flagman: A flagman shall be stationed at least one
hundred feet (100') or approximately thirty (30) meters in advance of the work
crew.
      6.   Asphalt Work:
         (a)   When using hot asphalt, employees shall wear garments that cover
the body completely, tightfitting around the neck, sleeves reaching over the
wrists and trousers over the shoe tops. Gloves, other than gauntlet type, shall
be worn continuously.
         (b)   Inoperative temperature gauges or safety valves are to be
repaired or replaced promptly.
         (c)   Never turn the flame so low in an asphalt heating device that
there will be danger of the flame being extinguished which will permit gas to
accumulate.
         (d)   To prevent fire, do not heat asphalt material beyond the
recommended maximum working temperature for the type asphalt being heated.
         (e)   When adding material to an asphalt heating kettle, always have
five inches (5") to six inches (6") from the top unfilled to minimize the
possibility of spillage and to allow space for expansion when heating.
         (f)   To prevent hot asphalt from splashing on employees when
attaching or detaching a two (2) wheeled kettle or distributor filled with hot
asphalt to or from a truck, have sufficient assistance to prevent the unit from
tipping.
         (g)   To minimize the possibility of fire, clean excess asphalt from
heating kettles and distributors.
         (h)   To prevent fire, do not allow the level of the liquid to get
below the hot coils of an asphalt distributor.
         (i)   Do not use water to extinguish an asphalt kettle fire. Lower the
lid and use a dry chemical fire extinguisher or loose sand or dirt to smother
the fire.
         (j)   To prevent spilling hot asphalt, do not fill the pouring can
over three-fourths (3/4) full.
         (k)   Do not attempt to clean the spout of a pouring can while the can
contains hot asphalt unless special tools are provided.
         (l)   Caution should be taken during crack pouring operations so that
hot asphalt will not be blown onto yourself or fellow employees.
         (m)   When commercial trucks hauling flammable liquids are directed
past hole drying and bump burning operations, the burner flame shall be
directed away from the passing truck.
         (n)   Caps shall be placed on LP gas containers at all times except
when the containers are properly connected to a burner.
      7.   Vegetation Control:
         (a)   Drivers of tractor mowers shall operate at all times in such
manner as not to endanger traffic, being constantly on the alert for a motor
vehicle which might unexpectedly leave the roadway and cause a collision. In
certain areas, such as on shoulders having guard fences, slopes back of gutters
and shoulders of high fills, it is permissible for the mower to operate on the
pavement in the direction of traffic movements in mowing the first swath.
         (b)   Make daily inspections of rotary mower guards, chains, shields,
blades and bolts in order to ensure maximum protection to the tractor operator
and the traveling public. Prompt replacement of missing or defective guards,
shields and blades shall be made. Always use factory approved replacement
parts.
         (c)   Do not use rotary mower blades that have been heated or welded.
         (d)   A slow moving vehicle emblem shall be properly mounted on upper
left corner of rollover protection structure.
         (e)   Operators of tractor mowers shall be alert and watch for hazards
such as hidden logs, stumps, right of way markers, culvert headwalls, rocks,
holes or dirt piles that can cause a tractor to overturn or stall. When a
hazard is observed, slow down and proceed with caution.
         (f)   Tractor mower operators shall allow sufficient clearance when
mowing around signs.
         (g)   Operators of rotary mowers must raise the mower when passing
over side roads, intersections and driveways to reduce the danger of the mower
throwing foreign objects. Adjust mower to recommended cutting length and mow in
such a manner as not to scalp.
         (h)   To minimize the throwing of debris by rotary mowers, police the
right of way prior to first mowing of the season; caution, pressurized cans
must be picked up by hand.
         (i)   All culvert headwalls, openings and other hazards shall be
marked with a post to show the location of such hazards to employees engaged in
vegetation control.
         (j)   When traveling, avoid traffic by driving on the shoulder with
tractor mower when possible.
         (k)   Employees engaged in cutting vegetation with hand sickles or in
other work requiring exposure to high weeds or brush shall cleanse parts of the
body exposed with a strong soap solution after completing the day's work in
order to lessen the chances of weed poisoning. Weed poisoning preventatives are
available for employees.
         (l)   When necessary to observe or adjust a sickle bar mower while in
operation, always stand in back of the sickle bar.
         (m)   When removing growth or foreign objects from the sickle bar or
rotary mower housing, always stop the tractor, turn off the ignition, put the
tractor transmission in low or reverse gear and wait until the rotary mower
blade has stopped. To prevent the amputation of fingers, use a stick or similar
object to remove foreign material from the sickle bar or movable parts.
         (n)   Employees engaged in field activities should learn to recognize
poisonous vegetation such as poison ivy, poison oak and poison sumac.
         (o)   Mower operators shall let traffic clear before turning onto the
pavement. When necessary to cross a bridge, the mower operator shall first
raise the sickle bar or rotary mower and then proceed across the bridge in the
right hand traffic lane when it is safe to do so.
         (p)   All weed and brush control chemicals (pesticides) shall be used
only by employees authorized, instructed and licensed in its use.
         (q)   Avoid direct contact with and the breathing of dust or vapor of
weed and brush control chemicals (pesticides). Always wash hands, arms and face
with strong soap solution after the use of such chemicals before eating.
         (r)   Never mow with front end loader bucket and/or bucket arms
mounted on the tractor mower.
         (s)   Employees engaged in cutting vegetation with hand scythes,
sickles, machete and brush hook shall be spaced to prevent fellow employees
from being struck by such tools.
         (t)   Employees cutting down trees shall make certain that a clear
path for retreat is available when the tree begins to fall.
         (u)   Before cutting limbs and branches from a felled tree with chain
saw, clear away stones, earth and bark so chains cannot throw them in the
direction of the operator.
         (v)   Employees engaged in tree trimming shall be constantly on the
alert for power lines.
      8.   Ladders And Scaffolds:
         (a)   Use linseed oil or other clear preservative to preserve wooden
ladders. Do not paint ladders because paint covers defects.
         (b)   Do not leave tools or materials on top of ladders or scaffolds
where they may be knocked off and injure someone below.
         (c)   Ladders in need of repair shall not be used. Those beyond repair
shall be disposed of according to current policies and procedures.
         (d)   Never climb a ladder while carrying tools or materials in your
hands. Use a bucket and/or rope to lift and lower tools and/or materials.
         (e)   While working from a ladder, never reach too far out in any
direction.
         (f)   All straight ladders shall be equipped with safety "shoes" or
spikes.
         (g)   Place bottom of ladder out from the surface of which such ladder
leans, a distance equal to approximately one-fourth (1/4) the ladder length.
         (h)   No ladder shall be used to gain access to a roof or higher level
unless the top of the ladder shall extend at least three feet (3') or
approximately one meter (1 m) above the point of support, at eave, gutter, roof
or surface line.
      9.   Snow And Ice Control Operations:
         (a)   If it becomes necessary to stop a truck in the traffic lane for
any delay when plowing snow or spreading abrasives or chemicals, additional
warning shall be given as follows:
            (1)   First turn on simultaneous turn signal flashers.
            (2)   If sight distance is limited, lighted fusees shall be used.
         (b)   All lights, windows and wiper blades shall be frequently cleaned
during snow and ice control operations.
         (c)   Always wear gloves and eye protection while handling snow fence,
tie wires and brace wires.
         (d)   When stretching and tying snow fence, stand on the post side as
it is not uncommon for the wire to break and the fence to roll back.
         (e)   Do not use fingers to align holes when mounting snowplow blades,
spreaders or other attachments. Use punch, drift pin or similar devices to
align holes.
      10.   Laboratory And Special Equipment Safety:
         (a)   All chemical containers shall be labeled so their contents may
be determined at a glance.
         (b)   Cracked glassware or glassware with sharp or cracked edges
should either be fire polished or, if this is impossible, destroyed.
         (c)   Keep adequate protection between you and apparatus in which
there is any chance of flash or explosion.
         (d)   Where the eyes or body of any person may be exposed to injurious
corrosive materials, suitable facilities for quick drenching or flushing of the
eyes and body shall be provided within the work area for immediate emergency
use.
         (e)   Keep hazardous fumes and vapors confined to hoods and provide
supplemental ventilation.
         (f)   Do not drink from beakers, since they may have contained
hazardous substances.
         (g)   Keep waste in refuse containers, empty daily.
         (h)   Where devices using radioactive materials are utilized, all
personnel shall be trained in their proper use. Such devices shall be used with
caution and only for the purpose intended.
         (i)   The requirements regarding radioactive material imposed by the
atomic energy commission and state regulations shall be followed. (Also see
OSHA part 1910.96 and department policies on "radiation safety and accident
procedures".)
         (j)   Employees whose assignment requires exposure to laser beams
shall be furnished suitable laser safety goggles which will protect for the
specific wavelength of the laser and be of optical density adequate for the
energy involved.
      11.   Trenching, Excavating And Underground Facilities:
         (a)   Sides and banks of trenches in excess of five feet (5') deep or
approximately one and one-half meters (11/2 m) shall be shored, sheeted, braced
or laid back to a stable slope.
         (b)   When employees are required to be in trenches four feet (4') or
approximately one and one-half meters (11/2 m) deep or more, an adequate means
of exit such as ladders or steps shall be provided and located so as to require
no more than twenty five feet (25') or approximately seven and two-thirds
meters (72/3 m) of lateral travel.
         (c)   Be alert for underground utility services when digging,
trenching, drilling and driving posts. Check with all utility companies in the
area before commencing work.
         (d)   Never work under an overhang bank of gravel, earth, cinders or
rock.
         (e)   No entry to a confined area or underground facility having
limited ventilation shall be permitted unless forced ventilation is provided or
the atmosphere is found to be safe by testing for oxygen deficiency and the
presence of explosive gases, fumes or liquids. If in doubt, check with your
supervisor or safety office.
         (f)   If any irritation to the eyes, nose or throat is experienced or
any difficulty in breathing is encountered while entering or working in the
manhole, leave at once and report the condition to your immediate superior. Do
not reenter until proper tests have been conducted. (See rule 20.5.)
      12.   Handling Of Supplies And Materials:
         (a)   When using hooks for loading or unloading material, be sure the
hook is equipped with a safety latch. Be careful not to catch hands between the
hook and the load.
         (b)   Always use a tag line to control the load and stand clear of the
load when it is being moved.
         (c)   Employees handling materials such as reinforcing steel, cables,
castings and rough lumber shall wear heavy gloves.
         (d)   When lifting heavy objects, lifting shall be done with the legs,
arms and shoulders, not with the back. Keep the back as nearly perpendicular
with the ground as possible. (Obtain assistance when the objects are awkward or
too heavy to handle by oneself.)
         (e)   If any rope becomes wet, it shall be dried after being used in
order to prevent deterioration. All ropes shall be checked for broken strands
before use.
      13.   Oxygen, Acetylene, LP Gas And Explosives:
         (a)   Oxygen, acetylene and LP gas cylinders shall not be stored
inside a building. Empty cylinders shall be so marked or tagged and stored
separate from full units.
         (b)   Caps shall be placed on LP gas containers at all times except
when the containers are properly connected.
         (c)   No explosives are to be secured, stored or used without the
permission of proper authority. Employees, as well as the public, shall be
properly warned and kept at a safe distance before a charge of explosives is
detonated. Blasting shall be done only under the supervision of a person
trained and experienced in blasting procedures.
      14.   Employee Personal Protection:
         (a)   All field employees must be properly clothed (long trousers,
shirts with sleeves or coveralls and other necessary appropriate outerwear) to
minimize exposure to the elements and hazards resulting from city operations.
         (b)   Footwear of sturdy construction shall be worn so as to minimize
the chance of injury from the hazards of one's normal duty assignment. Casual
style footwear such as canvas, slip ons and loafers are not acceptable footwear
for normal maintenance, construction, material testing and material handling
activities. (The aforementioned is not intended to cover all activities where
casual shoes are not to be worn.)
         (c)   Where it is not feasible to reduce the noise level or duration
of exposure at work areas exceeding published standards, personal protective
equipment such as earmuffs or earplugs shall be used. (Check with superior for
OSHA requirements.)
   (E)   Safety Code Receipt: Each employee of the city shall be issued a copy
of the safety code. The signed safety code receipt will be attached to
employee's personnel file which is maintained by the city comptroller.
   (F)   City Safety Policy: The following safety concepts are the fundamentals
of the city safety policy and as such shall continue to be a part of the
overall employee safety and accident prevention program:
      1.   It shall be the duty of every employee in a supervisory capacity to
carry on the operation under their jurisdiction in such a manner as to afford
the maximum protection for all employees and the public. Supervisory personnel
shall be responsible for the correction of unsafe conditions, unsafe driving
practices and the continued maintenance of good housekeeping practices.
      2.   It shall be the duty of every employee in a supervisory capacity to
see that each individual employee under their supervision receives all
necessary instruction and such training as may be required to perform work in
the safest manner possible. In addition, the person in charge shall see that
the job instructions, safe driving practices, safe work practices, good
housekeeping and the rules of the city's safety code are fully complied with by
the employee.
      3.   The city will expect the individual employee to cooperate in every
respect with the safety program so that the operations may be carried on in
such a manner as to ensure the safety of themselves, fellow workers and the
public.
      4.   It shall be the duty of each employee to consider no job so
important and no service so urgent that time cannot be taken to work and drive
safely.
   (G)   Accountability: Every employee of the department is required to know,
understand and obey all city safety rules and practices as they pertain to the
employee's job assignment.
      1.   Supervisory personnel are required to implement all safety rules,
practices and policies of the city and to provide the necessary training and
direction to ensure compliance.
The violations of city safety rules and practices have resulted in injury to
employees, damage to city equipment and third party lawsuits; therefore, the
failure to comply with safety rules and practices outlined in this chapter may
result in disciplinary action.
   (H)   Safety Suggestions And Hazard Observations: As an aid to locating and
correcting unsafe conditions and unsafe practices, every employee is encouraged
to report hazards observed (see subsection (B), "General Safety Requirements",
of this section). Those conditions noted which may not justify an immediate
call to a superior or which may require a more complete investigation can be
reported on the forms available from your department head or may be reported in
any written form.

1-23-23: EMPLOYMENT POLICY:
   (A)   The organizational departments are hereby established for the city as
follows:
      1.   Administrative.
      2.   Public works.
      3.   Police.
      4.   Fire.
The mayor shall conduct an annual performance review during the first quarter
of each calendar year. Reviews are set to allow the mayor and the department
head to discuss past job performance and offer suggestions on how to improve in
job performance. Said annual review shall be in writing, signed by the
department head, and placed in the employee's personnel file. A signature page
shall be provided to committee members showing evidence that the review has
been completed. The signature page shall include a summary of ratings for each
performance criteria. (Ord. 2085, 2-11-2014)
   (B)   Any person employed by the city and who is the recipient of a
certificate of technical competency, issued by the Illinois environmental
protection agency for a water or wastewater treatment or pretreatment facility
will not be permitted to perform services for another government entity,
corporation, industry or a privately owned activity which requires this
certification except by requests to the city council from another government
entity, corporation, industry or privately owned activity, which requests may
be approved by the city council and services to be performed on a contractual
basis.
Failure to comply with this policy will be cause of immediate disciplinary
action by the mayor with the approval of the city council. (Ord. 1255, 7-26-
1983; amd. Ord. 1689, 4-9-2002)
1-23-24: POLICE CODE OF ETHICS:
   (A)   All police officers who are permanently assigned for duty with the
city must familiarize themselves and sign a police code of ethics as follows:
   POLICE CODE OF ETHICS Date:
As a Law Enforcement Officer, my fundamental duty is to serve mankind; to
safeguard lives and property; to protect the innocent against deception, the
weak against oppression or intimidation, and the peaceful against violence or
disorder; and to respect the constitutional rights of all men to liberty,
equality and justice.
I will keep my private life unsullied as an example to all; maintain courageous
calm in the face of danger, scorn, or ridicule; develop self-restraint; and be
constantly mindful of the welfare of others, honest in thought and deed in both
my personal and official life. I will be exemplary in obeying the laws of the
land and the regulations of my department. Whatever I see or hear of a
confidential nature or that is confided to me in my official capacity will be
kept ever secret unless revelation is necessary in the performance of my duty.
I will never act officiously or permit personal feelings, prejudices,
animosities, or friendship to influence my decisions. With no compromises for
crime and with relentless prosection of criminals, I will enforce the law
courteously and appropriately without fear or favor, malice or ill will, never
employing unnecessary force or violence and never accepting gratuities.
I recognize the badge of my office as a symbol of public faith, and I accept it
as a public trust to be held so long as I am true to the ethics of police
service. I will constantly strive to achieve these objectives and ideals,
dedicating myself before God to my chosen profession....law enforcement.
   (B)   A completed code of ethics statement for each officer will be filed in
the permanent personnel file in the office of the comptroller. (Ord. 1195, 6-
10-1980)
1-23-25: DRUG AND ALCOHOL ABUSE POLICY:
   (A)   Purpose: The purpose of this policy is to perform the necessary drug
and alcohol testing pursuant to the federally mandated requirements under 49
CFR part 40 and part 382. The drug related requirements of this policy become
effective February 13, 1996. The alcohol related requirements under this policy
become effective February 13, 1996.
   (B)   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the words and terms
defined in this subsection shall have the meaning therein given, unless the
context otherwise clearly requires.
    DRIVER: Any person who operates a commercial motor vehicle as defined in 49
CFR part 382.107. This includes, but is not limited to: full time, regularly
employed drivers; casual, intermittent or occasional drivers; leased drivers
and independent, owner-operator contractors who are either directly employed by
or under lease to an employer or who operate a commercial motor vehicle at the
direction of or with the consent of an employer. For the purpose of
preemployment/preduty testing only, the term "driver" includes a person
applying to an employer to drive a commercial motor vehicle.
   SAFETY SENSITIVE FUNCTION: Any of those on duty functions set forth in 49
CFR part 395.2, paragraphs (1) through (7).
   (C)   Use Prohibited: The unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensation,
possession or use of a controlled substance or alcohol is prohibited on all
municipal premises, in any municipally owned or leased motor vehicle, or other
location at which the driver is to perform work. Nor will this municipality
hire or retain any individual who uses or possesses any illegal drug, in any
amount, regardless of frequency, or any individual who engages in prohibited
alcohol related conduct.
      1.   The municipality will maintain a preemployment screening program
designed to prevent hiring anyone who uses any illegal drugs, or engages in
prohibited alcohol related conduct.
      2.   No driver will consume any schedule 1 drug of the schedule of
controlled substance of the drug enforcement administration or any
amphetamines, narcotics, opiates, hallucinogenic substances, depressants,
stimulants, or any other habit forming drug while on or off duty, except as
provided in subsection (C)4 of this section.
      3.   No driver shall report for work or drive while impaired by any drug,
controlled substance or with an alcohol breath concentration of 0.02 or
greater.
      4.   A driver may use a substance administered by or under direction of a
physician who has advised the driver that the substance will not affect the
driver's ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
      5.   No driver may operate any motor vehicle whose motor senses, sight,
hearing, balance, reaction, reflexes or judgment are or may be presumed
affected or who has consumed any alcohol within four (4) hours.
      6.   Any driver who sells or otherwise dispenses illegal drugs or alcohol
to others on municipal premises, in or from a municipally owned or leased motor
vehicle is subject to immediate termination.
   (D)   Drug And Alcohol Testing:
      1.   Drug Testing: This municipality will require drug testing in
accordance with federal motor carrier safety requirements as set forth in part
40. Effective August 15, 1994, all urine samples shall be split samples. The
"primary sample" shall be at least thirty milliliters (30 ml) of urine; the
"split sample" shall be at least fifteen milliliters (15 ml). Failure of the
driver to provide that quantity even after a two (2) hour second opportunity
following drinking up to twenty four (24) ounces of water, will cause the
driver to be referred for a medical evaluation to develop pertinent information
whether the driver's inability to provide a specimen is genuine or constitutes
a refusal to test. The medical evaluation shall go to the medical review
officer (MRO) who will make a conclusion in writing to the employer. While this
process is being accomplished the driver shall be placed out of service.
      2.   Alcohol Testing: The municipality will require alcohol testing in
accordance with federal motor carrier safety requirements as set forth in part
40. Two (2) breath tests are required to determine if a person has a prohibited
alcohol concentration. A "screen test" shall be conducted first. Any result
less than 0.02 alcohol concentration is considered a "negative test". If the
alcohol concentration is 0.02 or greater, a second or "confirmation test" must
be conducted. This test shall be by an "evidential breath testing" (EBT)
device, that prints out the results, date, time, a sequential test number, name
and serial number of the EBT. The alcohol test must be conducted by a "breath
alcohol technician" (BAT) who is trained to operate that EBT and is proficient
in all breath alcohol testing procedures.
Drivers shall only be tested for alcohol while performing a safety sensitive
function, just before performing a safety sensitive function, or just after
performing a safety sensitive function. Any test 0.02 or greater but less than
0.04 shall cause the driver to immediately be removed from driving or any other
safety sensitive function for at least twenty four (24) hours. Failure of the
driver to provide an adequate amount of breath will cause the driver to be
immediately referred for a medical evaluation to develop pertinent information
concerning the driver's inability to provide the adequate amount of breath is
genuine or constitutes a refusal to test. The physician shall submit a written
medical evaluation to the MRO who will make a conclusion in writing to the
employer. While this process is being accomplished the driver shall be placed
out of service.
      3.   Drug Test Required: For the purposes of compliance with the federal
motor carrier safety regulations, all drivers will be required to take and
successfully pass urine drug testing and breath alcohol testing. Refusal to
submit to such screenings is considered a positive test.
      4.   Preemployment: Applicants for positions as drivers will also be
required to take and successfully pass urine drug tests and alcohol breath
tests before they can be used as drivers; except, applicants that have taken
part in qualified programs in the last thirty (30) days and tested in the last
six (6) months or in a random program in the last twelve (12) months with no
positive results.
      5.   Drug Test Records: The following information must be obtained on any
new driver from previous employers for the past two (2) years: any positive
drug test or alcohol test of 0.04 or greater, including any refusals to be
tested. Every new employee shall provide to this municipality a written release
which authorizes this municipality to obtain the driver's past drug and alcohol
test results. No driver shall be used for more than fourteen (14) days while
these test results are being secured. Regulations prohibit the use of any
driver after fourteen (14) days if these test results have not been obtained.
Any driver found to have had a positive test result in these two (2) years
shall cause the employer to further obtain information on the subsequent
substance abuse professional's evaluation and/or determination under section
382.605 and determine if there was compliance with sections 382.309 and
382.311. If not, the driver cannot be used until in full compliance.
      6.   Periodic Testing: All drivers may be required to submit to a urine
drug test and breath alcohol test at least every two (2) years at the same time
as the biennial medical examination occurs.
      7.   Reasonable Cause: Any driver suspected of drug or alcohol use as a
result of reasonable evidence upon reporting to work, during the work day, or
upon completion of his day's work activity may be subjected to a reasonable
cause urine drug or breath alcohol test. Refusal to submit to such screening
will be considered a positive test. A reasonable cause observation form must be
completed and signed by at least one qualified supervisor within twenty four
(24) hours of the observation that led to a reasonable cause test.
      8.   Random Testing:
         (a)   All employees covered by this section will be included as a part
of the Mid-West Truckers Association Drug And Alcohol Test Consortium group
from which the consortium will randomly select fifty percent (50%) each year
for drug testing and twenty five percent (25%) each year for breath alcohol
testing per the requirements of section 382.305 and 49 CFR part 40.
         (b)   On a monthly basis our MRO will from the total group select
randomly on his computer a number to be tested that on an annual basis will
equal fifty percent (50%) of that total group for random drug testing and
twenty five percent (25%) for breath alcohol testing. This same process will be
repeated each month.
         (c)   Once the MRO makes the monthly selections, he will forward that
list to the consortium which will notify the employer under whose drug policies
those selected are covered. The municipality will be given a date before which
the individual must be tested per these random selection processes. The person
to be tested shall not be informed of the need to be tested except just prior
to the actual test being performed.
         (d)   Failure of the municipality to accomplish the above requirements
in the time allotted will cause them to be out of compliance with the random
testing requirements of 49 CFR part 40.
      9.   Post-Accident Testing:
         (a)   This municipality will require post-accident urine drug and
breath alcohol testing of all employees covered by this section as required by
section 382.303 and 49 CFR part 40.
         (b)   Post-accident urine drug and breath alcohol testing will be
required of those employees who are involved in an accident if the driver
receives a citation for a moving traffic violation arising from the accident or
there is a fatality.
         (c)   The post-accident urine drug test shall be conducted as soon as
possible but not later than thirty two (32) hours after the reportable or fatal
accident. If the test is not administered, the employer shall prepare and
maintain on file a record stating the reasons the test was not promptly
completed. If a breath alcohol test is not conducted within two (2) hours, a
record shall be prepared and retained stating why. If in eight (8) hours a test
is still not conducted, all attempts shall cease and a complete record made of
why it was not accomplished. In addition, the driver shall not consume any
alcohol for at least eight (8) hours following an accident or until a breath
alcohol test has been accomplished.
         (d)   A driver who is seriously injured and cannot provide a urine
specimen or breath alcohol test at the time of the accident shall provide the
necessary authorization for obtaining medical records and reports that would
indicate if a controlled substance or alcohol was in the driver's system and
the level present.
         (e)   The employer shall provide the driver with sufficient procedures
so that the driver can meet the requirements of subsections (D)9(a), (D)9(b),
(D)9(c), (D)9(d) of this section, and comply with all provisions of 49 CFR part
40.
         (f)   Failure of the driver to be readily available or refusal to give
a urine sample or breath alcohol test when the driver has been involved in a
fatal accident, or received a citation for a moving violation, except for a
driver who meets the conditions of subsection (D)9(d) of this section, shall be
considered a refusal to take a test and a positive test result.
   (E)   Test Results:
      1.   Drug Test Results: Test results will be reviewed to determine
whether there is any indication of a controlled substance abuse.
         (a)   The test results will be reviewed by an MRO. If there is any
evidence of a positive result the MRO will give the person tested an
opportunity to discuss the results and provide documentation of legally
prescribed medication.
         (b)   The results will be released to the MRO, who will then release
the results to the Mid-West Truckers Association (our drug test consortium),
which will forward them to the Illinois municipal league, which will forward
those results to this municipality, which will maintain them in a secure
location with controlled access.
      2.   Alcohol Test Results:
         (a)   The test results shall be provided on forms established by
subpart C 40.59 appendix A. Copy 1 (white) will be retained by the BATs, copy 2
(green) shall go to the employee, copy 3 (blue) shall be transmitted to the
employer.
      3.   General:
         (a)   The test results from all drug and alcohol tests will become a
part of the driver's qualification file which shall be in a secured location
with controlled access and retained as specified in section 382.401 or in this
section.
         (b)   The results will not be released to any unauthorized party
without written consent. Every driver upon termination is required to permit in
writing the release of their urine drug and breath alcohol test results for at
least two (2) years to any future employer. Every employer is required upon the
receipt of a written request of a driver to provide copies of all his or her
urine drug and breath alcohol test results promptly to any other possible
employer at no charge.
   (F)   Assistance Program: An employee assistance program will be conducted
by this municipality to provide educational information concerning the effects
and consequences of drug or alcohol use on personal health, safety and work
environment.
      1.   Every driver will be required to take at least one hour of training
each year on substance abuse and alcohol use, and sign form IML-10 certifying
their attendance.
      2.   Written notice will be given when this training is available.
   (G)   Laws And Regulations:
      1.   Compliance: This municipality will comply with all federal, state
and local laws and regulations concerning any violations of criminal drug and
alcohol use status in the work place.
      2.   Record Keeping: All records will be retained as listed in section
382.401.
      3.   Driver Access To Records: A driver is entitled, upon written
request, to obtain copies of any records pertaining to the driver's use of
drugs or alcohol, and test results. Access shall not be contingent upon payment
for records other than those requested.
      4.   Employer Access To Records: Records shall be made available to a
subsequent employer upon receipt of a written request from a driver.
      5.   Disclosure: An employer may disclose information required to be
maintained under this section on a driver, to the decision maker in a lawsuit,
grievance, or other proceeding initiated by or on behalf of that driver and
arising from the results of an alcohol or controlled substance test required by
this section, or from the employer's determination that the driver engaged in
conduct prohibited by this section (including, but not limited to, worker's
compensation, unemployment compensation, or other proceeding related to
benefits sought by the driver).
   (H)   Disciplinary Action:
      1.   Violations of this section will result in termination.
      2.   Every driver who has engaged in violations of this section will be
advised by the employer of resources available to the driver in evaluating and
resolving problems associated with the misuse of drugs or alcohol, even though
the driver is terminated. (Ord. 1549, 2-13-1996)
1-23-26: BACKGROUND CHECKS AND LICENSE VERIFICATION:
   (A)   All city job applicants authorize the city, or its designee to conduct
a background check. To that end all such applicants shall sign a consent form
provided by the city.
   (B)   All employees who drive a city vehicle in the course of their duties
must maintain a valid driver's license. Biannually, the chief of police is
authorized to conduct a driver's license check with the secretary of state to
verify that such employees have a valid driver's license. (Ord. 1981, 8-23-
2011)
1-23-27: PART TIME POLICE:
   (A)   Employment: The city of Savanna may employ part time police officers
from time to time as they deem necessary.
   (B)   Duties: A part time police officer shall have all the responsibilities
of a full time police officer and such specific duties as delineated in the
general orders of the Savanna police department, but the number of hours a part
time officer may work within a calendar year is restricted. Part time police
officers shall not be assigned to supervise or direct full time police
officers. Part time police officers shall be trained in accordance with the
Illinois police training act 1  and the rules and requirements of the ILETSB.
   (C)   Hiring Standards: Any person employed as a part time police officer
must meet the following standards:
      1.   Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of sound health,
and physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties.
      2.   Be at least twenty one (21) years of age.
      3.   Pass a medical examination.
      4.   Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate.
      5.   Possess a valid state of Illinois driver's license.
      6.   Possess no prior felony convictions.
      7.   Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must have been
honorably discharged.
   (D)   Discipline: Part time police officers shall be under the disciplinary
jurisdiction of the chief of police. Part time police officers serve at the
discretion of the city authorities, shall not have any property rights in said
employment, and may be removed by the city authorities at any time. Part time
police officers shall comply with all applicable rules and general orders
issued by the police department. (Ord. 1998, 2-28-2012)
