3-4-4: RESTAURANTS:
3-4-4-1: DEFINITION:
RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised or held out to
the public as a place where meals, sandwiches, coffee or other goods are
offered for sale, sold, served or supplied to the general public
indiscriminately at any time or hour, to be consumed on or off the premises.
(1977 Code)
3-4-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall exercise the business of keeping a
restaurant without first having obtained a license therefor. Each license
issued hereunder shall terminate on April 30 following the issuance thereof.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the city council, at its discretion, may issue
one restaurant license annually, without fee, to a not for profit corporation
operating a restaurant in Savanna, Illinois. (Ord. 1882, 10-23-2007)
3-4-4-3: APPLICATION:
No person, firm or corporation shall receive a license or the renewal of a
license to operate a restaurant unless the premises upon which the food is to
be served and prepared complies with the building regulations of title 4 of
this code and the fire regulations of title 5 of this code. The city fire
marshal, building official and a licensed plumber shall inspect the premises to
determine compliance with this section prior to the issuance of the license and
within ninety (90) days prior to the renewal thereof. (Ord. 1688, 3-12-2002)
3-4-4-4: FEE:
The fee for subject license shall be set forth heretofore in the "schedule of
fees 1 ". (1977 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2 of this title.
3-4-4-5: SPECIFICATIONS:
   (A)   Lighting; Construction: All rooms or places in the restaurant shall be
properly and adequately lighted so that all parts may be inspected readily.
The walls and ceilings shall be of smooth, hard material, and must be kept
clean and sanitary and in good repair.
Floors shall be smooth and of hard material, and must be kept clean and
sanitary and in good repair at all times.
   (B)   Counters, Shelves, Towels To Be Clean: All show or display cases or
windows, counters or shelves used in keeping and displaying food and drink
shall be kept clean and sanitary, free from dust, dirt and other contaminating
material, and in good repair. All food containers shall be elevated at least
two feet (2') from the floor.
All towels used for drying dishes, receptacles and utensils shall be clean.
   (C)   Sinks; Grease Traps: Sinks with an adequate supply of running hot and
cold water shall be provided and each sink shall be provided with a metallic
splashboard approved by the health officer. All sinks shall be constructed of
nonabsorbent material.
Each restaurant shall be provided with a grease trap installed in strict
compliance with all regulations of the city; provided, however, upon a written
agreement not to do cooking requiring any extensive washing of greasy
equipment, pans, dishes or other utensils, the health officer, in his
discretion may waive the requirement of this subsection relative to grease
traps, such waiver to be conditional upon compliance with the aforesaid written
agreement.
   (D)   Insanitary Rooms; Screens: No restaurant shall be conducted in a room
or rooms used for sleeping purposes; or in any room or place that is damp,
dark, poorly ventilated or insanitary. All doors, windows and other openings
shall be properly screened from May 1 of each year. Screen doors shall be
provided with self- closing devices.
   (E)   Refrigerators: All refrigerators, iceboxes and other appurtenances
thereof used for the storage of food and drink shall be kept clean and sanitary
and in good repair, and the compartments used for storage of ice shall be lined
with some proper metallic substance so as to be watertight. No food shall be
placed directly on ice or ice coils.
   (F)   Water Closets: Suitable lavatories shall be provided and installed in
strict compliance with the plumbing regulations of the city.
   (G)   Serving Milk: All milk intended for service to patrons of restaurants,
hotels, schools, boarding houses and other public eating places shall be served
in the individual bottles filled at the dairy or pasteurizing plant.
   (H)   Handled Food: No hotel, restaurant, lunch counter or other place where
food is sold shall resell any food which has been sold to or handled by any
customer.
   (I)   Arrangement Of Stoves: All stoves, ranges, heaters and hot water tanks
shall be elevated and placed far enough from the wall to assure easy access for
cleaning, and all stoves shall be equipped with proper ventilation by suction
or hood as approved by the health officer.
   (J)   Garbage Cans: Regulation, watertight, properly covered, galvanized
iron, metal cans for receiving and holding, without leakage, all garbage and
other waste material shall be provided. A tightfitting cover shall be provided
for each can, and the cans shall be kept covered. All garbage and other waste
material shall be removed from the premises daily and shall not be allowed to
become a nuisance.
   (K)   Soiled Linens; Utensils: A special covered container shall be provided
for the storing of all soiled linen.
All utensils used in the preparation, service and sale of food and drink shall
be properly cleaned and sterilized with hot water, steam or approved chemicals
after use, and no utensil shall, under any circumstances be used a second time
unless it shall have been, after previous use thereof, so cleaned and
sterilized, and in such cleaning the use of water, which has become insanitary
by previous use, is prohibited.
   (L)   Steam Tables: All steam tables shall be maintained at a temperature of
at least one hundred fifty five degrees Fahrenheit (155°F) while containing
food, and shall be cleaned daily.
   (M)   General Cleanliness: The use of any utensil used in the preparation,
service and sale of food or drink which is badly worn or rusted, or the use of
cracked dishes or glassware in such condition that it cannot be rendered clean
and sanitary, is prohibited.
Equipment or utensils made of crockery, pottery, porcelain, enamelware or other
material, the surface of which may become chipped or otherwise damaged to such
an extent that dirt, grease, verdigris or where disease causing germs may
collect or stick to the damaged edges, or whose damaged edges may chip or
become loose (and get into the food, or endanger life or health) shall not be
used after such damage or breakage of the inside surface is present, but shall
at once be discarded or repaired. The presence in any restaurant of any bugs,
cockroaches or other vermin is expressly prohibited and if found, shall be
promptly exterminated therefrom.
All food shall be arranged and displayed in an orderly and systematic manner so
as to improve the general appearance of the restaurant and to facilitate easy
inspection.
The use of tobacco in any form is prohibited in the kitchen.
The presence of any food, drink or raw material in any part of the restaurant
shall be deemed prima facie evidence of its use for human food.
No domestic animals shall be permitted anywhere in a restaurant. (1977 Code)
3-4-4-6: EMPLOYEES:
No person who has any infectious or venereal disease shall be permitted to
handle food and drink or any utensil used in dispensing food. (1977 Code)
3-4-4-7: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
No licensee hereunder, exercising the business of keeping a restaurant, shall
permit any person or persons to frequent the same who are under the influence
of liquor, nor shall such person offer for sale, sell or give away any
intoxicating liquor in such place of business unless licensed so to do; nor
shall such licensee permit any person to engage in disorderly conduct or in any
lewd or lascivious behavior in such place of business. (1977 Code)
3-4-4-8: POLICE ASSISTANCE:
It shall be the duty of the police to assist the health officer in serving any
and all notices which he may issue hereunder, and to report to him any
violation hereof, and to aid in every necessary manner in the enforcement of
these health regulations. (1977 Code)
3-4-4-9: LICENSE REVOCATION:
Any license so granted may be revoked by the mayor by notice in writing,
whenever it shall appear to his satisfaction that the person so licensed shall
have violated the provisions of any law of this state or of the provisions of
this code relative to the keeping of restaurants. (1977 Code)

3-5-1: AUCTIONEERS:
3-5-1-1: DEFINITION:
The term "auctioneer", when used in this section shall mean any person who
sells real estate or personal property at public or private auction for another
or for himself, regardless of who owns such property. (1977 Code)
3-5-1-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct an auction or engage in the business of an auctioneer
in the city without first having obtained a license therefor.
It shall also be unlawful for any employee of an auctioneer to conduct an
auction in the city without first having obtained a license therefor, and it
shall be unlawful for any auctioneer to permit an auction to be conducted by an
unlicensed employee.
The auctioneer's license shall state the name and residence address of the
person, if any, authorized by the auctioneer to conduct auctions on his behalf,
if such person meets the prerequisites of a licensee hereunder, and such
auctioneer's license shall constitute a license for such named person. (1977
Code)
3-5-1-3: APPLICATION:
An application for an auctioneer's license shall be made in conformity with the
general requirements of this code relating to applications for licenses. An
auctioneer shall use the same application form in obtaining a license for not
more than two (2) of his employees by stating in such application, in addition
to the other information required, the name and residence address of any
employee who is to be authorized by the applicant to conduct auctions on
applicant's behalf. (1977 Code)
3-5-1-4: INVESTIGATION:
The chief of police, or any other city official designated by the mayor, shall
make or cause to be made such investigation as he deems necessary to determine
the character and reputation of the applicant for an auctioneer's license and
the character and reputation of any employee of the applicant designated to
conduct auctions on the applicant's behalf. No license shall be issued to any
applicant or for any employee of an applicant who is not found to be a person
of good character and reputation. The city official, charged with making said
investigation, shall indicate on the application for license the results of his
investigation and his approval or disapproval of said application. (1977 Code)
3-5-1-5: FEE:
The fee for subject license shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) per day or an
annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and shall be set forth heretofore
in "schedule of fees 1 ". (Ord. 1727, 5-13-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2 of this title.
3-5-1-6: LICENSED EMPLOYEE:
All the provisions of this code relating to an auctioneer shall apply equally
to any licensed employee of an auctioneer, and should any licensed employee of
an auctioneer violate any of the provisions of this code concerning
auctioneers, such licensed employee shall be subject to all the penalties
herein imposed upon licensed auctioneers for violating any of the provisions of
this section.
If any licensed auctioneer shall permit any person other than the one
authorized by him and licensed hereunder to conduct an auction on his behalf,
such auctioneer shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this section. In
addition, his license shall forthwith be revoked and no other license shall be
issued to him for a period of one year. (1977 Code)
3-5-1-7: TERMS OF SALE:
It shall be the duty of every auctioneer, before beginning any auction sale of
real or personal property of any kind whatever, to state fully the terms and
conditions upon which the sale will be made and to announce to the persons
present the character, quality and description of the property offered for
sale. (1977 Code)
3-5-1-8: FALSE REPRESENTATIONS:
No auctioneer or person being present when any real or personal property is
offered for sale shall knowingly, with intent to induce any person to purchase
the same or any part thereof, make any false representations or statement as to
the ownership of, or the character or quality of, the property so offered for
sale, or as to the poverty or circumstances of the owner or pretended owner of
such property; and if such false representation is made by the auctioneer, or
by any other person with such auctioneer's knowledge and consent or connivance,
the license of such auctioneer shall be revoked. (1977 Code)
3-5-1-9: RETURN OF ARTICLES PURCHASED:
(Rep. by Ord. 1118, 5-10-1977)
3-5-1-10: SUBSTITUTION:
No auctioneer shall exhibit and offer for sale at auction any article and
induce its purchase by any bidder, and then afterwards substitute any article
in lieu of that offered to and purchased by the bidder. (1977 Code)
3-5-1-11: FICTITIOUS BIDS:
No auctioneer shall procure any person to make a fictitious bid, or shall
conspire with any person to make a fictitious bid, or shall himself
fictitiously raise any bids at any auction sale of real or personal property.
(1977 Code)
3-5-1-12: SPECIAL PERMIT FOR AUCTION SALES:
(Rep. by Ord. 1118, 5-10-1977)
3-5-1-13: ADDITION OR SUBSTITUTION OF PROPERTY:
Said special permit shall be valid only for the sale of the particular property
described in the application therefor, and at the particular time and place
stated herein. Any renewal, addition or substitution of property, or change of
time or place for such sale shall be unlawful. (1977 Code)
3-5-1-14: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
No license granted under the provisions of this section shall be transferred to
another person. (1977 Code)
3-5-1-15: AUCTIONS ON PUBLIC WAYS:
No real or personal property shall be sold at auction, or exposed for sale, by
any person in any public way in the city, unless approved by the mayor and
chief of police. (Ord. 1118, 5-10-1977)
3-5-1-16: EXEMPTIONS:
Nothing in this section shall apply to any public auction or sale made or
conducted by a public officer by virtue of any jurisdictional order or process
or by virtue of any power of authority contained in a mortgage or trust deed.
(1977 Code)
3-5-2: TRANSIENT MERCHANTS; ITINERANT VENDORS:
3-5-2-0: INTENT:
It is the intent of the city council to provide standards and licensing
procedures for the regulation of transient merchants and itinerant vendors for
the following reasons:
   (A)   To protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Savanna
and protect the character and quality of the community;
   (B)   To protect the needs and interests of permanent businesses located
within the city;
   (C)   To accommodate special events and festivals that provide added
attraction to the city;
   (D)   To support local not for profit charitable events; and
   (E)   To provide a means by which the city can enforce this section
3-5-2. (Ord. 1831, 3-28-2006)
3-5-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter:
ITINERANT VENDOR: Any person who transports tangible personal property for
retail sale within the municipal limits who does not maintain an established
office, distribution house, sales house, warehouse, service center or residence
from which such business is conducted.
Exception: This chapter does not apply to any person who delivers tangible
property within the municipal limits who is fulfilling an order for such
property which was solicited or placed by mail or other means. This chapter
does not apply to any person holding a valid license, issued by a county or
municipality, to engage in retail sales.
NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION: An organization which is legally chartered as nonprofit
and charitable or educational in nature.
PERSON: Any individual, corporation, partnership, trust, firm, association or
other entity.
TRANSIENT MERCHANT: Any person who is engaged temporarily in the retail sale of
goods, wares or merchandise in this state and who, for the purpose of
conducting such business, occupies any building, room, vehicle, structure of
any kind, or vacant lot within the municipal limits for periods of fewer than
five (5) days.
Exception: This chapter does not apply to any person selling goods, wares or
merchandise which are raised, produced or manufactured by him, to any person
selling vegetables, fruit or perishable farm products at an established city or
village market, to any person operating a store or refreshment stand at a
resort, or to any person operating a stand or booth on or adjacent to property
owned by him or upon which he resides. This chapter does not apply to any
person holding a valid license, issued by a county or municipality, to engage
in retail sales. (Ord. 1370, 1-23-1990; amd. Ord. 1831, 3-28-2006)
3-5-2-2: PREREQUISITES TO CONDUCT BUSINESS:
It is a violation of this chapter for any person, either as principal or agent,
to conduct business as a transient merchant or itinerant vendor within the city
without first complying with the requirements of section 2a of the Illinois
retailers' occupation tax act by obtaining a certificate of registration and by
posting bond or other approved security and without having obtained a license
under this chapter. (Ord. 1370, 1-23-1990)
3-5-2-3: LICENSE:
   (A)   Application Must Be Filed: Any person who wishes to obtain a license
as a transient merchant or itinerant vendor shall file a written license
application with the city, as provided in this section. (Ord. 1370, 1-23-1990)
   (B)   Application Contents: The license application shall include the
applicant's name, permanent business address (which must include a street
address), residence address of the principal (and, if the applicant is a
corporation, the residence addresses of its officers), the location at which
the applicant intends to do business, the nature of the business the applicant
intends to conduct, a copy of the applicant's certificate of registration under
the Illinois retailers' occupation tax act, a complete inventory of the goods
the applicant intends to offer for sale, and a list of all licenses to conduct
business as a transient merchant or an itinerant vendor obtained by the
applicant in this state in the twelve (12) months preceding the date of filing
of the application, such additional information as may be needed for the proper
guidance of the municipal officials in the evaluation of such application.
   (C)   Approval Or Disapproval Of License Application: If the information
contained within the application is unsatisfactory or after due consideration
of the information contained within the application it is determined that
matters concerning the application are unsatisfactory, then the city clerk
shall notify the applicant that the application has been rejected. If the
information contained within the application is acceptable, the applicant shall
be informed that their request for a license has been approved.
   (D)   Insurance Certificate Required: No city license shall be issued for
special events that take place wholly or in part upon city owned property
unless the application is accompanied by a certificate establishing that the
applicant has sufficient liability insurance in place to protect and indemnify
the city from any liability. (Ord. 1831, 3-28-2006)
3-5-2-4: BOND OR DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
(Rep. by Ord. 1831, 3-28-2006)
3-5-2-5: LICENSE EXPIRATION:
A license or permit issued under this chapter shall expire on December 31 of
the year it was issued, except a license or permit which is issued for a daily
fee which would expire at the end of the day on which it was issued. (Ord.
1542, 10-10-1995)
3-5-2-6: LICENSE FEE:
The license fee for any person wishing to conduct a business as either a
transient merchant or itinerant vendor shall be set forth heretofore in
"schedule of fees 1 ". (Ord. 1457, 6-22-1993)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2 of this title.
3-5-2-7: HOLDING INVENTORY:
If any person makes retail sales as a transient merchant or itinerant vendor
without having obtained a license under section
3-5-2-3 of this chapter, the city may hold the inventory, truck or personal
property of the person until he obtains a license to conduct business as a
transient merchant or itinerant vendor. If the property has been held by the
city for more than sixty (60) days and the person whose property is being held
has not obtained a license under section
3-5-2-3 of this chapter, the city may petition the circuit court for an order
for the sale of the property being held. If the court finds that the person
whose property is held has not obtained a license under section
3-5-2-3 of this chapter, the court may order the city to sell the property.
Proceeds of the sale of the property, less reimbursement to the city of the
reasonable expenses of storage and sale of the property, shall be deposited in
the treasury of the city. (Ord. 1370, 1-23-1990)
3-5-2-8: PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE:
It shall be prima facie evidence that a person is a transient merchant or
itinerant vendor under this chapter if the person does not transact business
from a fixed location or if the person does not own, or lease for a term of at
least six (6) months, the property from which business is conducted. (Ord.
1370, 1-23-1990)
3-5-2-9: EXEMPTIONS:
   (A)   Prior Invitation: Any person who, for the purpose of selling or taking
orders for the sale of merchandise or services, has been invited by the
occupant of a residence to call thereon is exempt.
   (B)   Nonprofit Organizations: Any person selling, peddling, soliciting or
taking orders for any goods not prohibited by law on behalf of a charitable,
religious or other nonprofit organization sponsored by or participated in by a
local chapter of such organization; or by a national organization not
represented locally but which has filed a statement of registration with the
city clerk specifying the name of the nonprofit organization, its permanent
address, the names of its principal officers, and the names of those persons
who are authorized to sell, peddle or solicit or take orders for goods and
services within the city.
   (C)   Farmers: Any person whose principal occupation is that of farmer who
sells the produce of his own farm, vineyard, orchard or garden, provided he
does not obstruct streets, sidewalks or other public places within the city;
provided, however, that nothing contained herein shall be construed to
authorize the sale of alcoholic, spirituous, malt or other intoxicating
liquors, or peddling of any kind whatsoever in any public park.
   (D)   Newspaper Vendors: Any person who, on behalf of the publisher of any
newspaper of general circulation within the city, peddles the same in any
public place. (Ord. 1370, 1-23-1990)
3-5-2-10: POSSESSION OF LICENSE REQUIRED:
Any person licensed pursuant to this chapter shall, at all times while engaged
in the activities defined in section
3-5-2-1 of this chapter, keep said license in his possession and shall display
the same upon the demand of any police officer or upon the request of any
person whose premises he seeks to enter. (Ord. 1370, 1-23-1990)
3-5-2-11: VEHICLES TO BE MARKED:
Every vehicle or conveyance used by a person licensed hereunder shall be
conspicuously marked, as may be prescribed by the city clerk, with the name of
such person or his employer and the number of his license. (Ord. 1370, 1-23-
1990)
3-5-2-12: NUISANCES DECLARED:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and welfare and a nuisance
for any person licensed hereunder to be in the habit of or to continue the
practice of entering in and upon private premises in disregard of the express
wish of the owner or occupant, for the purpose of selling, peddling or
soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise. (Ord. 1370, 1-
23-1990)
3-5-2-13: PUBLIC STREETS, WAYS; RESTRICTIONS:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to permit any person licensed
hereunder, unless expressly stated to the contrary upon said license:
   (A)   To erect or place any temporary or permanent stand upon any street,
alley, sidewalk or other public place within the city for the purpose of
dispensing or displaying his goods, wares or merchandise; or
   (B)   To go about the city or upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other
public place while making any noise, blowing any horn, or using any like device
to call attention to his goods, wares or merchandise. (Ord. 1370, 1-23-1990)
3-5-2-14: FRAUD:
Any licensed transient merchant or itinerant vendor who shall be guilty of any
fraud, cheating, misrepresentation or imposition, whether himself or through an
employee, while engaged in this trade within the city, or who shall act as a
broker for, sell or peddle any goods other than those specified in his
application for a license, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this
chapter. (Ord. 1370, 1-23-1990)
3-5-2-15: VIOLATIONS:
Any person who is convicted of violating any provisions of this section
3-5-2 is guilty of a class B misdemeanor. (Ord. 1370, 1-23-1990)
3-5-3: RESERVED:
(Ord. 1607, 10-28-1997)
3-5-4: PHOTOGRAPHERS:
(Rep. by Ord. 1728, 5-13-2003)
3-5-5: TAXICABS:
3-5-5-1: DEFINITION:
For the purposes of this chapter, the term "taxicab" shall mean any vehicle
hauling or carrying passengers for hire, except that it shall not include any
buses now operating or to be operated on regularly scheduled routes in the city
or any vehicles which carry seven (7) or more passengers. (1977 Code)
3-5-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate a taxicab within the city without having first obtained
a license therefor. (1977 Code)
3-5-5-3: VEHICLE INSPECTION:
No license for any taxicab shall be issued until the vehicle has been
thoroughly inspected by the chief of police, or such other official that the
city council may direct, and found to be in safe and satisfactory condition for
the transportation of passengers, he shall check the vehicle to see that the
brakes on the vehicle are in good workable condition, that the vehicle is in
good running order, that there is no broken glass in any of the windows of the
vehicle, that there is nothing about the vehicle or located within as to cause
harm or danger to any passenger or other vehicle. The vehicle shall be equipped
with good tires, shall have good headlights and two (2) working taillights, and
shall be in a clean condition. (1977 Code)
All licensed taxicabs shall be inspected biannually between the first and the
seventh of April and October of each year. If any vehicle licensed as a taxicab
is involved in an automobile collision or any other accident, an inspection
shall be made of it before it is again placed in service. (1977 Code; amd. Ord.
1654, 4-25-2000)
3-5-5-4: LIABILITY INSURANCE:
No vehicle shall be licensed as a taxicab until the owner thereof has first
furnished satisfactory evidence that the vehicle is covered for the period of
the license by bodily injury liability insurance in the amount of twenty five
thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for each person, and fifty thousand dollars
($50,000.00) for each accident, and property damage insurance in the amount of
fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) for each accident. (1977 Code)
3-5-5-5: APPLICATION:
Written applications for taxicab permits must be filed at the city offices and
they shall set forth the owner of the vehicle, the make and model of the
vehicle, and the motor number thereof. (1977 Code)
3-5-5-6: FEE:
The fee for subject license shall be as set forth heretofore in the "schedule
of fees 1 ". (1977 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2 of this title.
3-5-5-7: LICENSE NONTRANSFERABLE:
The license for any taxicab is not assignable or transferable, except that the
owner may use the license on a replacement vehicle after making written
application for such transfer, and after the chief of police or such other
official as the city council may direct, has inspected the replacement vehicle
to see that the same complies with all the provisions of this chapter. (1977
Code)
3-5-5-8: NAME ON VEHICLE:
All taxicabs licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall have the name
of the owner or company operating such taxicab, plainly printed on the side of
the vehicle. (1977 Code)
3-5-5-9: CITY LICENSE NUMBER, CARD:
Upon a license being granted, there shall be delivered to the licensee a card
of such size and form as may be determined by the chief of police. Such card
shall contain the official city license number of the taxicab and shall be
signed by the chief of police.
The license card above referred to shall be affixed in a place in the said
taxicab so that same is visible to any passenger. (1977 Code)
3-5-5-10: LIST OF DRIVERS:
Every owner of a taxicab shall furnish to the chief of police a certified list
of all the drivers of its taxicab or taxicabs. (1977 Code)
3-5-5-11: LICENSE REVOCATION:
A taxicab license shall be revoked by the chief of police when he has held a
hearing, after first giving ten (10) days' notice thereof, to the holder of the
license, and at such hearing has found that the holder of the license is
violating any of the provisions of this chapter or the traffic laws of the
state. (1977 Code)
3-5-5-12: DRIVER QUALIFICATIONS:
An applicant for a taxicab driver's license must be in sound physical
condition, possess good eyesight, good hearing, must be a licensed driver under
the laws of the state, be of sound mind, show that he is familiar with the
traffic laws of the state, and the traffic ordinances of the city, and shall
show to the satisfaction of the chief of police that he can properly and safely
handle a vehicle under crowded traffic conditions. Applicant must not have been
convicted of a crime rendering him infamous, and cannot be addicted to the use
of alcohol or drugs. (1977 Code; amd. Ord. 1654, 4-25-2000)
3-5-5-13: OPERATOR'S LICENSE:
   (A)   Taxicab drivers' licenses shall be issued by the chief of police after
he has been furnished with a written application which shows to the
satisfaction of the chief of police that the requirements as set forth in this
chapter have been met and complied with by the applicant. Provided that if any
applicant is refused a license to drive a taxicab by the chief of police, the
applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief of police to the city
council for the issuance of a license. (1977 Code)
   (B)   (Rep. by Ord. 1303, 10-14-1986)
   (C)   A taxicab driver's license shall be revoked by the chief of police
when he has held a hearing, after having first given ten (10) days' notice
thereof, and at such hearing he finds the driver's Illinois driver's license
has expired, or that it has been suspended or revoked by the state of Illinois,
or that the driver is addicted to the use of alcohol or drugs. (Ord. 1654, 4-
25-2000)
3-5-5-14: PARKING SPACES:
Any person shall be entitled to parking stands or spaces in the city where
taxicabs may sit while awaiting calls or passengers. Such parking spaces shall
be limited to two (2) parking spaces, which parking spaces will be assigned by
the city council. No other space may be used for stands other than those
assigned by the city council. (1977 Code)
3-5-6: MOBILE HOME PARKS:
3-5-6-1: MODEL CODE ADOPTED:
That certain act of the state of Illinois entitled "an act to provide for,
license and regulate mobile homes and mobile home parks" being in particular
210 Illinois Compiled Statutes 115/1 et seq., as amended, is hereby adopted and
incorporated by reference as the regulations of the city for mobile homes and
mobile home parks. (1977 Code)
3-5-6-2: FEE:
The fee for subject license shall be as set forth heretofore in "schedule of
fees 1 ". (1977 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2 of this title.
3-5-7: GARAGE SALES:
3-5-7-1: FREQUENCY AND DURATION:
No person or entity shall have or cause to have more than three (3) garage
sales per calendar year. No garage sale may exceed three (3) consecutive days
in duration. (Ord. 1817, 10-11-2005)
3-5-8: RAFFLES:
3-5-8-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct a raffle without having first obtained a license
therefor pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 1208, 11-11-1980)
3-5-8-2: ELIGIBILITY:
Raffle licenses shall be issued only to bona fide religious, charitable, labor,
business, fraternal, educational or veterans' organizations that operate
without profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously
for a period of five (5) years immediately before application for a license and
which have had during that entire five (5) year period a bona fide membership
engaged in carrying out their objects, or to a nonprofit fundraising
organization that the licensing authority determines is organized for the sole
purpose of providing financial assistance to an identified individual or group
of individuals suffering extreme financial hardship as the result of an
illness, disability, accident or disaster. (Ord. 1347, 2-21-1989)
3-5-8-3: INELIGIBILITY:
The following are ineligible for any license under this chapter:
   (A)   Any person who has been convicted of a felony.
   (B)   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling
promoter.
   (C)   Any person who is not of good moral character.
   (D)   Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection (A),
(B) or (C) of this section has a proprietary, equitable, or credit interest, or
in which such a person is active or employed.
   (E)   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (A), (B) or
(C) of this section is an officer, director, or employee, whether compensated
or not.
   (F)   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (A), (B) or
(C) of this section is to participate in the management or operation of a
"raffle" as defined in this chapter. (Ord. 1208, 11-11-1980)
3-5-8-4: DEFINITIONS:
BUSINESS: A voluntary organization composed of individuals and businesses who
have joined together to advance the commercial, financial, industrial and civic
interest of the community.
CHARITABLE: An organization or institution organized and operated to benefit an
indefinite number of the public. The service rendered to those eligible for
benefits must also confer some benefit on the public.
EDUCATIONAL: An organization or institution organized and operated to provide
systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by methods common to
schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably in their scope and
intensity with the course of study presented in tax supported schools.
FRATERNAL: An organization of persons having a common interest, the primary
interest of which is to both promote the welfare of its members and to provide
assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the burdens of
government by caring for those that otherwise would be cared for by the
government.
LABOR: An organization composed of workers organized with the objective of
betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit and the
development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective occupations.
NET PROCEEDS: Gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less reasonable sums
expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable operating expenses
incurred operating a raffle.
NONPROFIT: An organization or institution organized and conducted on a not for
profit basis with no personal profit inuring to anyone as a result of the
operation.
RAFFLE: A form of lottery conducted by an organization licensed hereunder, in
which the player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance,
represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by
some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning
chance determined through a drawing or by some other method based on an element
of chance by an act or set of acts on the part of persons conducting or
connected with the lottery, except that the winning chance shall not be
determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting contest.
RELIGIOUS: Any church, congregation, society, or organization founded for the
purpose of religious worship.
VETERANS: An organization or association comprised of members of which
substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses, widows, or
widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of
its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to
confer a public benefit. (Ord. 1208, 11-11-1980; amd. Ord. 1347, 2-21-1989)
3-5-8-5: LICENSES:
All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall:
   (A)   Be valid for one raffle only.
   (B)   Be sold only within the corporate limits of the city.
   (C)   Limit aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise awarded in a
single raffle to thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00).
   (D)   Limit maximum retail value of each prize awarded in a single raffle to
thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00).
   (E)   Limit the maximum price charged for each raffle ticket or chance
issued or sold to one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   (F)   Limit the maximum number of days during which raffle tickets or
chances may be issued or sold to one hundred eighty (180) days.
   (G)   The cost payable in cash in advance when said license is issued shall
be:
      1.   Five dollars ($5.00) if aggregate value of prize(s) is five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00) or under.
      2.   Fifteen dollars ($15.00) if aggregate value of prize(s) is between
five thousand one dollars ($5,001.00) to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
      3.   Twenty five dollars ($25.00) if aggregate value of prize(s) is over
ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
   (H)   Be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter. (Ord. 1661,
10-24-2000)
3-5-8-6: APPLICATIONS:
Applications for all licenses herein shall be made in writing to the city clerk
and must include the following:
   (A)   The name of the not for profit organization requesting the license.
   (B)   A sworn statement attesting to the not for profit character of the
prospective licensee organization, signed by the presiding officer and
secretary of that organization.
   (C)   The name of the raffle manager, the amount of his or her bond and the
name and address of the bonding company.
   (D)   The area or areas within the city in which raffle tickets or chances
will be sold or issued.
   (E)   The time period during which raffle tickets or chances will be sold or
issued.
   (F)   The day and hour winning tickets or chances will be determined.
   (G)   The address of the location or locations at which winning tickets or
chances will be determined.
   (H)   The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise awarded in the
raffle to be conducted.
   (I)   The maximum retail value of each prize.
   (J)   The price of each ticket or chance.
   (K)   The number of days tickets or chances will be sold. (Ord. 1208, 11-11-
1980)
3-5-8-7: FORMS AND SIGNATURES:
Forms for all licenses, and applications therefor, shall be prepared and kept
on file by the city clerk. Each license shall bear the signature of the mayor
and the city clerk. (Ord. 1208, 11-11-1980)
3-5-8-8: INVESTIGATION:
   (A)   Upon receipt of an application for a raffle license the city clerk
shall within forty eight (48) hours of such receipt refer the application to
the chief of police for investigation.
   (B)   The chief of police shall investigate the application and make a
report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within ten (10) days after receiving
such application and file same with the city clerk. (Ord. 1208, 11-11-1980)
   (C)   Upon receipt of said report the city clerk shall present said report,
together with the application, to the mayor for evaluation and determination.
(Ord. 1363, 10-10-1989)
3-5-8-9: MAYOR ACTION:
   (A)   If, after due consideration of the information contained within the
application and the investigative report, the mayor shall determine that the
matters concerning the application are unsatisfactory, he shall deny the
application, indicating the reasons therefor. The mayor shall promptly notify
the applicant that its application is not approved, and that no license will be
issued.
   (B)   If, after due consideration of the information contained within the
application and the investigative report, the mayor shall determine that the
matters concerning the application are satisfactory, he shall approve the
application. The mayor shall promptly notify the applicant that its application
is approved, and the license may be issued.
   (C)   The mayor shall act upon a license application within thirty (30) days
from the date of the application. (Ord. 1363, 10-10-1989)
3-5-8-10: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
The conducting of raffles is subject to the following restrictions:
   (A)   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to
the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game.
   (B)   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may
participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
   (C)   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in
the management or operation of the raffle.
   (D)   A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning
chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed
under this act.
   (E)   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on
the license and winning chances may be determined only at those locations
specified on the license.
   (F)   No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the
conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years
may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when
accompanied by his or her parent or guardian. (Ord. 1208, 11-11-1980)
3-5-8-11: RAFFLES MANAGER'S BOND:
All operation of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a
single raffles manager designated by the organization licensed. The manager
shall give a fidelity bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in
favor of the organization conditioned upon his honesty in the performance of
his duties. Said bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to
the city council not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation.
(Ord. 1208, 11-11-1980)
The city may waive this bond requirement by including a waiver provision in the
license issued to an organization provided that a license containing such
waiver provision be granted only by unanimous vote of the members of the
licensed organization. (Ord. 1347, 2-21-1989)
3-5-8-12: RECORDS:
   (A)   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep
records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single
gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions
from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented
with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the
purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient.
The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount
and date of payment.
   (B)   Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross
receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization
pursuant to license therefor issued by the department of revenue of the state
and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have separate records
of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net
proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who
accounts for other revenues of the organization.
   (C)   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report monthly to
its membership, and to the city council, its gross receipts, expenses and net
proceeds from raffles and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as required
in this section.
   (D)   Records required by this section shall be preserved for three (3)
years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to
operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places.
(Ord. 1208, 11-11-1980)
CHAPTER 6
REGISTRATION OF SOLICITORS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Definitions
3-6-2: Certificate Of Registration
3-6-3: Application For Certificate Of Registration
3-6-4: Issuance And Revocation Of Certificate
3-6-5: Soliciting Without Certificate Of Registration Prohibited
3-6-6: Time Limit On Soliciting
3-6-7: Exemptions
3-6-8: Street Solicitation
3-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words as used herein shall be
construed to have the meanings herein ascribed thereto:
RESIDENCE: Shall mean and include every separate living unit occupied for
residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of
building or structure.
SOLICITOR: Shall mean and include any person who engages in one or more of the
following activities within the city:
(A) Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise,
foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or description whatever, for any
kind of consideration whatever.
(B) Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of
insurance of any type, kind or character.
(C) Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers and every other type or kind of publication.
(D) Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other
valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit
association, organization, corporation or project. (1977 Code)
3-6-2: CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION:
Every "solicitor" as herein defined is hereby required to make written
application for a certificate of registration as hereinafter provided. (1977
Code)
3-6-3: APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION:
Application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a form
provided by the chief of police and filed in the police department. The
applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the
application:
   (A)   Name of applicant and his current residence address.
   (B)   Social security number.
   (C)   Business address, if other than residence address.
   (D)   Age of applicant and date and place of birth.
   (E)   Physical description of the applicant.
   (F)   Name and address of the person, firm, corporation or organization by
whom the applicant is employed or represents.
   (G)   Description sufficient for identification of the subject matter for
which the applicant will solicit.
   (H)   Has a certificate of registration issued to the applicant under this
chapter ever been revoked, suspended or canceled?
   (I)   Has the applicant ever been convicted of a violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter or the ordinance of any other municipality
regulating soliciting?
   (J)   Has the applicant ever been convicted of the commission of a felony?
   (K)   Description and registration of the motor vehicle that the applicant
is using.
   (L)   Such other information and proof of identification as the chief of
police may require.
The chief of police shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate record of
every application received and acted upon together with all other information
and data pertaining thereto and all certificates of registration issued under
the provisions of this chapter, and of the denial of applications.
No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has been
convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois
or any other state or federal law of the United States within five (5) years of
the date of the application; nor to any person who has been convicted of a
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter; nor to any person whose
certificate of registration issued hereunder has previously been revoked as
herein provided. (1977 Code)
3-6-4: ISSUANCE AND REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE:
The chief of police, after consideration of the application and all information
obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if the applicant does not
possess the qualifications for such certificate as herein required, or that the
issuance of a certificate of registration to the applicant would not be in
accord with the intent and purpose of this chapter. Endorsement shall be made
by the chief of police upon the application of the denial of the application.
When the applicant is found to be fully qualified and payment of the
registration fee is made to the city clerk, the certificate of registration
shall be issued forthwith.
Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the chief
of police if the holder of the certificate is convicted of a violation of any
of the provisions of this chapter or has made a false material statement in the
application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a
certificate of registration under the terms of this chapter. Immediately upon
such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police
to the holder of the certificate in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed
to the applicant at his residence or business address set forth in the
application.
Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the certificate of registration
shall become null and void.
The certificate of registration shall state the expiration date thereof. (1977
Code)
3-6-5: SOLICITING WITHOUT CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION PROHIBITED:
Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for anyone to engage in
soliciting without a valid certificate of registration in his possession. Such
certificate of registration shall be presented by the solicitor upon demand to
any police officer or occupant of the premises whereon the soliciting occurs
for examination. The certificate of registration is valid only for the person
to whom it is issued. (1977 Code)
3-6-6: TIME LIMIT ON SOLICITING:
A certificate of registration for a solicitor shall expire at nine o'clock (9:
00) P.M. on the same day that it is issued. It shall be unlawful to engage in
soliciting prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M.
of any weekday or at any time on a Sunday or on a holiday. (1977 Code)
3-6-7: EXEMPTIONS:
   (A)   Prior Invitation: Any person who, for the purpose of selling or taking
orders for the sale of merchandise or services, has been previously invited by
the occupant of a residence to call thereon.
   (B)   Farmers: Any person whose principal occupation is that of a farmer,
who sells the produce of his own farm, vineyard, orchard or garden, provided he
does not obstruct streets, sidewalks or other public places or solicit in any
public park.
   (C)   Newspaper Vendors: Any person who, on behalf of the publisher of any
newspaper of general circulation within the city, solicits to sell such
newspapers. (1977 Code)
3-6-8: STREET SOLICITATION:
   (A)   No person shall stand on a highway for the purpose of soliciting
contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except with express written
authority by the city.
Written application for street solicitation shall be requested on a form to be
provided by the city which shall require the applicant to warrant that:
      1.   The solicitation is on behalf of a soliciting agency registered with
the attorney general as a charitable organization as provided by "an act to
regulate solicitation and collection of funds for charitable purposes" approved
January 26, 1963, and as amended;
      2.   The soliciting agency is part of a statewide fundraising activity;
      3.   The soliciting agency will be liable for any injuries to any person
or property during the solicitation which is causally related to an act of
ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent;
      4.   The soliciting agency will require that all parties soliciting be
sixteen (16) years of age or more and wear a high visibility vest;
      5.   The soliciting agency will indemnify, defend and hold harmless the
city of Savanna from any injury to persons or property occurring during the
solicitation which is causally related to the soliciting activity. (Ord. 1761,
3-23-2004)
CHAPTER 7
LIQUOR REGULATIONS

3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms as used in this
chapter shall be construed according to the definitions given below:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Includes alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, and every liquid or
solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, and capable
of being consumed as a beverage by a human being; however, the provisions of
this chapter shall not apply to alcohol used in the manufacture of denatured
alcohol, produced in accordance with acts of Congress, nor to any liquid or
solid containing one- half of one percent (0.5%) or less of alcohol by volume.
BOWLING ALLEY: Every establishment or building, or part of an establishment or
building, as the case may be, wherein the game of bowling, played with
composition balls and ten (10) pins, is played.
CITY: The City of Savanna, Carroll County, Illinois, including all the
territory bounded by the limits of the said City.
CLUB: A corporation organized under the laws of this State, not for pecuniary
profit, solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or
consumption of alcoholic liquors, kept, used and maintained by its members
through the payment of annual dues, and owning, hiring or leasing a building or
space in a building of such extent and character as may be suitable and
adequate for the reasonable and comfortable use and accommodation of its
members and their guests and provided with suitable and adequate kitchen and
dining room space and equipment and maintaining a sufficient number of servants
and employees for cooking, preparing and serving food and meals for its members
and their guests; provided, that such club files with the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner of the City at the time of its application for license under this
chapter, the list required under the classification of Class B licenses; and
provided further that the affairs and management of such club are conducted by
a board of directors, executive committee or similar body chosen by the members
at their annual meeting, and that no member or any officer, agent or employee
of the club is paid or directly or indirectly receives in the form of salary or
other compensation any profits from the distribution or sale of alcoholic
liquor to the club or the members of the club or its guests introduced by
members, beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed and voted at any
annual meeting by the members or by a board of directors or other governing
body out of the general revenue of the club.
HOTEL: Any building or other structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and
held out to the public to be a place where food is actually served and consumed
and where sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers and
guests, whether transient, permanent or residential, in which twenty five (25)
or more rooms are used for the sleeping accommodations of such guests, and
having one or more public dining rooms where meals are served to such guests,
such sleeping accommodations and dining rooms being conducted in the same
building or buildings in connection therewith and such building or buildings,
structure or structures being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and
dining room equipment and capacity.
LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER: The mayor of the city and the person charged
with the administration of the appropriate provisions of the Illinois liquor
control act and of such ordinances and resolutions relating to alcoholic liquor
as may be enacted. The mayor may appoint a person or persons to assist him in
exercise of the powers and the performance of the duties set forth in the
Illinois liquor control act and in this chapter.
PREMISES: Shall generally be construed as the structure upon which the business
is housed as well as appurtenances thereto. Enclosed porches, fences, decks and
private grounds and facilities surrounding said structure may also be
considered the appurtenances, provided the city council grants licensee express
approval for use of same.
RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to
the public as a place where meals are served and where meals are actually and
regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being provided
with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity, and
having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare,
cook and serve suitable food for its guests.
RETAIL SALE: The sale for use or consumption, and not for resale. (Ord. 2090,
3-25-2014)
3-7-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall sell or offer for sale at retail in the city any alcoholic
liquor without having a retail liquor dealer's license, or in violation of the
terms of such license, or in violation of this chapter.
No person, firm or corporation shall receive a liquor license, or the renewal
of a liquor license, unless the premises upon which the liquor is sold complies
with the building regulations of title 4 of this code and the fire regulations
of title 5 of this code. The city fire marshal, building official and a
licensed plumber shall inspect the premises to determine compliance with this
section prior to the issuance of the license and within ninety (90) days prior
to the renewal thereof. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-2014)
3-7-3: APPLICATION:
Applications for such licenses shall be made to the local liquor control
commissioner, in writing, signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by a
duly authorized agent thereof if a club or corporation, verified by oath or
affidavit, and shall contain the following statements and information:
   (A)   The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an
individual; in the case of a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in
the profits thereof; in the case of a corporation, the objects for which
organized, the names and addresses of the officers and directors, and if a
majority interest of the stock of such corporation is owned by one person or
his nominee, the name and address of such person.
   (B)   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and if a
naturalized citizen the time and place of his naturalization.
   (C)   The character of business of the applicant, and in the case of a
corporation, the objects for which it was formed.
   (D)   The length of time said applicant has been in business of that
character, or in the case of a corporation, the date when its charter was
issued.
   (E)   The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time
application is made.
   (F)   The location and description of the premises or place of business
which is to be operated under such license.
   (G)   A statement whether applicant has made application for a similar or
other license on premises other than described in this application, and the
disposition of such application.
   (H)   A statement that applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is
not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing
contained in this chapter, laws of this State or the provisions of this Code.
   (I)   Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, or by
the Federal government has been revoked, and the reasons therefor.
   (J)   A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the
State of Illinois, or of the United States, or any of the provisions of this
Code in the conduct of his place of business. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-2014)
   (K)   A statement that the applicant authorizes a background check to be
conducted on the applicant. First time applicants must pay a seventy five
dollar ($75.00) fee for a background check. Fingerprints must be provided by
going to a professional live-scan (electronic) fingerprinting service, approved
by the City to be processed. Background checks are completed by the State of
Illinois police. This process can take up to eight (8) weeks to complete. Once
the results of the background checks are received from the State of Illinois
police, the liquor license application will be approved/denied. All fees must
be paid prior to review of the application. (Ord. 2227, 7-24-2018)
3-7-4: RESTRICTION ON ISSUANCE OR RENEWAL OF LICENSES:
No such liquor license shall be issued or reissued to:
   (A)   A person who is not a resident of the City.
   (B)   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community
in which he resides.
   (C)   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   (D)   A person who has been convicted of a felony under any Federal or State
law, unless the commission determines that such person has been sufficiently
rehabilitated to warrant the public trust after considering matters set forth
in such person’s application and the commission’s investigation. The burden of
proof of sufficient rehabilitation shall be on the applicant.
   (E)   A person who has been convicted of keeping a place of prostitution or
keeping a place of juvenile prostitution, promoting prostitution that involves
keeping a place of prostitution, or promoting juvenile prostitution that
involves keeping a place of juvenile prostitution.
   (F)   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
   (G)   A person whose license under this chapter has been revoked for cause.
   (H)   A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
   (I)   A copartnership, if any general partnership thereof, or any limited
partnership thereof, owning more than five percent (5%) of the aggregate
limited partner interest in such copartnership would not be eligible to receive
a license hereunder; and unless at least one member owning more than five
percent (5%) of the aggregate limited partner interest in such copartnership is
a resident of the City.
   (J)   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%)
of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license
hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the
political subdivision.
   (K)   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
   (L)   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any Federal or State
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, or who
shall have forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such
violation.
   (M)   A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a
license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for
which the license is issued.
   (N)   Any law enforcing public official, any Mayor or member of the City
Council and no such official shall be interested in any way, either directly or
indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor,
except that a license may be granted to any Alderman, or the Mayor in relation
to premises that are located within Savanna if: 1) the sale of alcoholic liquor
pursuant to the license is incidental to the selling of food, 2) the issuance
of the license is approved by the State Commission, 3) the issuance of the
license is in accordance with all applicable local ordinances in effect where
the premises are located, and 4) the official granted a license does not vote
on alcoholic liquor issues pending before the board or Council to which the
license holder is elected and if a license is granted to the Mayor he or she
has appointed another to serve as Local Liquor Control Commissioner.
   (O)   Any person, firm or corporation not eligible for a State liquor
dealer’s license.
   (P)   Any person, firm or corporation who is delinquent in the payment of
any money due the City.
   (Q)   In the instance of a Class A, B or C license, to any person, firm or
corporation unless the premises upon which alcoholic beverages are to be served
and kept comply with the building regulations of title 4 of this Code and the
fire regulations of title 5 of this Code. The City Fire Marshal, the building
official and a licensed plumber shall inspect the premises to determine
compliance with this section prior to the issuance of the license and within
one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the renewal thereof. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-
2014; amd. Ord. 2231, 8-14-2018)
3-7-5: TERM OF LICENSE:
Each license issued hereunder shall terminate on April 30 following the
issuance thereof. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-2014)
3-7-6: EXAMINATION, LOCAL LICENSE:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall have the right to examine, or cause
to be examined, under oath, any application for a local license or for a
renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or suspension
has been served as provided by statute, and to examine or cause to be examined,
the books and records of any such applicant or licensee; to hear testimony and
take proof for his information in the performance of his duties, and for such
purpose to issue subpoenas which shall be effective in any part of this State.
For the purpose of obtaining any of the information desired by the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner under this section, he may authorize his agent to act on
his behalf, as provided by statute. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-2014)
3-7-7: CLASSIFICATION AND FEES:
Liquor licenses issued by the City shall be and they hereby are divided into
the following classes:
   (A)   Class A Licenses: Class A licenses shall authorize the retail sale on
the premises specified in such license of alcoholic liquor for consumption on
the premises, as well as other retail sales of such liquor. The annual fee for
such license shall be one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). For the
fiscal year beginning May 1, 2020 through April 30, 2021, Class A license fees
shall be reduced to seven-hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   (B)   Class B Licenses: Class B licenses shall authorize the retail sale by
a club, on premises specified in such license, of alcoholic liquor for
consumption on the premises, as well as other retail sales of such liquor by a
club; but such license shall not authorize the sale of alcoholic liquors to
anyone other than a member of such club or a bona fide guest of any member of
such club. The annual fee for such license shall be seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). With the application for a Class B license, there shall be filed a
true and complete list, in duplicate, containing all the names and addresses of
the members of the club, which list shall be supplemented every four (4) months
during the term of the license, with the names of new members elected to the
club. For the fiscal year beginning May 1, 2020 through April 30, 2021, Class B
license fees shall be reduced to three-hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00).
   No Class B license shall be issued until the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner has satisfied himself that the club applying for the license was
actually and in fact organized for some purpose or object other than the sale
or consumption of alcoholic liquor.
   (C)   Class C Licenses: Class C licenses shall authorize the retail sale of
beer and wine in connection with the operation of an established food serving
facility during times when food is dispensed for consumption upon the premises,
and such sales may be made only:
      1.   With food served to the customer, and
      2.   At a dining table and not across a bar.
The annual fee for such license shall be seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   (D)   Class D Licenses: Class D licenses shall authorize the retail sale of
only beer and wine for consumption off the premises. The annual fee for such
license shall be seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   (E)   Class E Licenses: Class E licenses shall authorize the retail sale of
packaged alcoholic liquor for consumption off the premises. The annual fee for
such license shall be one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00).
   (F)   Class F Licenses: The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall have the
power to issue a temporary permit for the sale or delivery of beer and wine
only, to be consumed at a banquet, picnic, fair or similar private or public
assembly where food or drink is sold, served or dispensed on specifically
designated enclosed or fenced off private premises or in a specifically
designated building belonging to or under the control of the City.
Said premises or building shall be fully and clearly defined in the application
for a Class F license and such licensed premises or building shall be clearly
marked and enclosed so that the general public and law enforcement officers can
easily and without difficulty determine the limits of the licensed area. All
beer and wine must be consumed within the limits of the licensed area and shall
be dispensed by disposable plastic or paper cups, and adequate and suitable
containers shall be provided for disposal of all cups.
Such temporary permit shall be issued only to a legally recognized club,
society, fraternal, charitable, benevolent organization, not for pecuniary
profit, or an existing liquor license holder and shall be for a specified
period of not more than three (3) consecutive days. Not more than one temporary
permit shall be granted to any one organization in any one period of thirty
(30) days.
Class F licenses shall be issued to an applicant meeting the qualifications
stated above and only in connection with a fair, carnival, street dance,
bazaar, picnic, reception, outing or similar event. Such events shall be the
principal reason for the gathering, and the consumption of beer and wine shall
be incidental thereto.
Each Class F license in a specifically designated building belonging to or
under the control of the City shall provide dramshop liability in maximum
insurance coverage limits so as to save harmless the City from all financial
loss, damage or harm.
All regulations that are part of this chapter shall apply in the same manner
and degree as they apply to all other classes of licenses described herein.
The permit fee for such license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for each day the
license is in force.
   (G)   Class G Licenses: Class G licenses shall authorize the consumption of
beer and wine which has been brought onto the premises of a business operating
as a public accommodation as defined in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-42-
10.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code by a patron or patrons for their personal
consumption while being served a meal in said establishment. The annual license
fee for a Class G license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00).
      1.   Only beer and wine are allowed to be consumed on the premises of the
holder of a Class G license;
      2.   The license holder is only allowed to provide glasses, ice and an
ice holder for the patrons;
      3.   The license holder, its agents, and/or its employees may open, but
shall be prohibited from serving, pouring, and/or storing any wine or beer for
its patrons;
      4.   It shall be unlawful for the license holder, its agents and/or its
employees to permit any patron to leave the licensed premises with open wine or
beer, and the license holder shall require the patrons who leave with such of
their own beer and wine that has not been consumed do so only in sealed or
unopened containers in compliance with Illinois law;
      5.   No consumption of wine or beer shall be permitted on the premises
unless it is served as a complement to the sale of food; or it is served as a
complement of food or ancillary to another activity whose primary purpose is
not the consumption of alcohol;
      6.   A certificate of insurance, reflecting coverage for general
liability purposes in such minimum amounts as the Liquor Commissioner may deem
necessary from time to time, shall be presented to the City by the applicant
for the Class G establishment and the City shall be named as an additional
insured on the license holder's insurance. Further, the license holder shall
agree in writing to save and hold harmless the City's agents, employees,
elected and appointed officials from any and all claims or causes of action
arising out of the consumption of alcoholic liquor on the premises as a
condition of the license;
      7.   The hours during which a Class G license holder may permit
consumption of beer and wine on its premises shall conform identically to the
hours set forth in section
3-7-23 of this chapter.
All licenses issued hereunder shall be designated by classification letter
herein provided. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-2014; amd. Ord. 2270, 5-26-2020)
3-7-8: LIMITATION OF LICENSES:
There shall be no limitation of liquor licenses issued by the City. The Liquor
Control Commission shall have the power to issue liquor licenses to any person
who fully qualifies under the requirements of this chapter. Application for
liquor licenses must meet the requirements of title 10 of this Code. (Ord.
2090, 3-25-2014)
3-7-9: PAYMENT AND DISPOSITION OF FEES:
All license fees may be paid in two (2) installments, but each installment
shall be paid semiannually in advance. The fee to be paid shall be reduced in
proration to the full calendar months which have expired in the license year
prior to issuing such license. All such fees shall be paid to the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner of the City, who shall forthwith deliver the same to the
City Treasurer. No license fee shall be refunded, except as provided under
section
3-7-13 of this chapter. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-2014)
3-7-10: ALCOHOL SELLERS AND SERVERS EDUCATION REQUIRED:
   (A)   Sellers and servers of alcoholic beverages must complete a course of
instruction approved by the Illinois Liquor Commission on the effects of
alcohol and drug abuse and which teaches how to identify and/or intervene so as
to reduce the incidence of alcohol misuse amongst patrons.
   (B)   All liquor licenses sought on or after May 1, 2018 whether original or
renewal shall be accompanied by proof of completion of the State Certified
Beverage Alcohol Sellers and Servers Education and Training Program (BASSET)
training certification.
   (C)   For each liquor establishment, a minimum of two (2) employees or all
employees, whichever is less, must be "BASSET" certified.
   (D)   The licensee shall provide documentation when requested showing that
BASSET information was provided to all employees serving alcohol.
   (E)   A photocopy of the certificates of completion of the BASSET program
and the BASSET materials provided to employees shall be on file with the City
Police Department and maintained on the premises of the licensee.
   (F)   BASSET training certification cards are to be carried on the person
certified or exhibited in the establishment and produced for inspection by the
licensing authority when requested by a City police officer or the Liquor
Commissioner.
   (G)   The Liquor Commissioner may, in their sole discretion, extend the time
for completion of the BASSET training up to ninety (90) days. Said extension
shall only be for good cause and on a case by case basis. Any request for
extension shall be in writing.
   (H)   This section shall apply to all liquor license holders including those
who hold a temporary or special permit. (Ord. 2220, 3-27-2018)
3-7-11: REISSUE:
The Local Liquor Control Commission shall have the power of reissuing a
license. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-2014)
3-7-12: RECORDS:
The Comptroller or City Clerk shall keep a complete record of all such licenses
issued and shall furnish the Chief of Police with a copy thereof; upon
revocation or suspension of any license, the Comptroller or City Clerk shall
immediately give written notice thereof to the Chief of Police. (Ord. 2090, 3-
25-2014)
3-7-13: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed one year
after issuance, unless sooner revoked as in this chapter provided, and shall
not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or
execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or
involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license
shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution, but it shall
cease upon the death of the licensee, provided that executors or administrators
of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the trustee of any insolvent or
bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may
continue the business of the sale of alcoholic liquor under order of the
appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent
or bankrupt licensee after the death of said decedent, or such insolvency or
bankruptcy, until the expiration of such license but not longer than six (6)
months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. A refund
shall be made of that portion of the license fee paid for any period in which
the licensee shall be prevented from operating under such license, in
accordance with the provisions of this section. A licensee may renew his
license at the expiration thereof, provided he is then qualified to receive a
license and the premises for which such renewal license is sought is suitable
for such purposes; and, provided further, that the renewal privilege herein
provided for shall not be construed as a vested right. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-2014)
3-7-14: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
A license issued hereunder shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only in
the premises described in the application and license. Such location may be
changed only when, and upon the written permit to make such change issued by
the Mayor. No change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed new
location is in compliance with the provisions and regulations of this chapter.
(Ord. 2090, 3-25-2014)
3-7-15: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof, provided that he
is then qualified to receive a license and the premises for which such renewal
license is sought is suitable for such purpose; provided further, that the
renewal privilege herein provided for shall not be construed as a vested right
which shall in any case prevent the local liquor control commissioner from
decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within his jurisdiction.
The local liquor control commission may refer a renewal license to the council
for approval if previous license(s) have been suspended or revoked for any
violation(s) of this chapter or for any violation(s) of any state law
pertaining to the sale of alcoholic liquor. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-2014)
3-7-16: EMPLOYEES:
No persons under the age of sixteen (16) years shall be employed in or allowed
to work in and about any premises in which alcoholic liquor is sold at retail
during the hours alcoholic liquor is sold in said premises. (Ord. 2090, 3-25-
2014)
3-7-17: LOCAL RESTRICTIONS:
No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor
within one hundred feet (100') of any church, school, hospital, home for aged
or indigent persons, or for veterans, their wives or children or any military
or naval station; provided, that this prohibition shall not apply to hotels
offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to restaurants, food
shops or other places where sale of alcoholic liquor is not the principal
business carried on, nor to the renewal of a license for the sale at retail of
alcoholic liquor on the premises within one hundred feet (100') of a church
where such church has been established within one hundred feet (100') since the
