   (F)   Applications for refund shall be on such forms as the comptroller may
prescribe and shall be completed prior to the last business day in March of the
year in which the taxes would be due.
   (G)   If the comptroller is satisfied that the applicant for a refund under
this chapter is entitled to receive the refund, the comptroller shall bring the
matter before the city council which shall authorize the refund if it finds the
requirements of this chapter have been met.
   (H)   If the city council approves an application for refund, the applicant
shall have paid the full amount of taxes imposed as if there were to be no
refund. Upon proof of that payment to the comptroller, the comptroller shall
then refund to the owner the authorized refund. (Ord. 1690, 4-9-2002)
CHAPTER 8
EXTERIOR BEAUTIFICATION PAINT PROGRAM
SECTION:
4-8-1: Program For Reimbursement Of Exterior Paint Expenses
4-8-1: PROGRAM FOR REIMBURSEMENT OF EXTERIOR PAINT EXPENSES:
   (A)   Application: The owner of the structure may make application to the
city on an application form as provided by the city seeking partial
reimbursement of exterior paint in accordance with the following:
      1.   The applicant must be the owner of all rights, title, and interest
in the structure and have the complete authority to paint the structure.
      2.   The applicant must state the start and completion date of the
painting project, identify all exterior areas to be painted (square footage if
known), state exterior surface preparation to be completed (prior to starting
the project), state the number of gallons requested, and provide a paint chip
sample of color(s) to be used.
      3.   The applicant is required to purchase the exterior paint locally
within Savanna, Illinois.
      4.   The maximum reimbursement will be up to ten (10) gallons (primer
and/or exterior paint).
      5.   The exterior beautification and painting must all be completed
within ninety (90) days of the approval of the application.
   (B)   Review And Approval: The mayor or designee will review all
applications for completeness in accordance with the following:
      1.   Prior to approval, the mayor shall review the budget to ensure there
are sufficient funds to cover the cost of reimbursement for each application.
If there are insufficient funds to cover the cost of any application, the mayor
may take said application to the finance committee and city council for
approval to expend additional funds.
      2.   Upon approval, the application shall be signed and dated by the
mayor or designee and the applicant notified that their application has been
accepted and approved for the program.
   (C)   Reimbursement: After completion of the project the applicant must
contact the city to inspect the property to ensure that all of the work has
been satisfactorily completed. Failure to satisfactorily complete said project
will result in the applicant being invoiced for all primer and/or paint
purchased by the city of Savanna. Failure to pay said invoice will result in
the invoice balance being added to the undersigned applicant's water bill.
Failure to pay said water bill may result in penalties and/or termination of
services. (Ord. 2063, 10-22-2013)
TITLE 5
FIRE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
FIRE PREVENTION CODE
SECTION:
5-1-1: Code Adopted
5-1-2: Enforcement; Chief Of Fire Department
5-1-3: Penalty
5-1-1: CODE ADOPTED:
The provisions of the current abbreviated edition of the fire prevention code
recommended by the National Fire Protection Association, as amended, are hereby
adopted and incorporated herein as fully as if set out at length.
Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the code hereby adopted, it shall
be held to mean the city of Savanna, Illinois. (Ord. 1206, 10-14-1980)
5-1-2: ENFORCEMENT; CHIEF OF FIRE DEPARTMENT:
   (A)   The code hereby adopted shall be enforced by the chief of the fire
department.
   (B)   The chief of the fire department shall have power to modify any of the
provisions of the code hereby adopted upon application in writing by the owner
or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties
in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the
spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial
justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and
the decision of the chief of the fire department thereon shall be entered upon
the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished the
applicant. (1977 Code)
5-1-3: PENALTY:
The penalty prescribed for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter,
or for any rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, shall be as set out in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (1977 Code)
CHAPTER 2
FIRE LIMITS; GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
5-2-1: Fire Limits Established
5-2-2: Moving Wooden Buildings
5-2-3: Damaged Buildings
5-2-4: Junkyards
5-2-5: Condition Of Structures
5-2-6: Open Burning; Bonfires (Rep. by Ord. 1247, 11-9-1982)
5-2-7: Notice Of Violation
5-2-8: False Alarms
5-2-9: Penalty
5-2-1: FIRE LIMITS ESTABLISHED:
All that part of the city embraced within the following described territory is
constituted and declared to be the fire limits of the city:
Beginning at the northwest corner of Chicago Avenue and Third Street and
extending northerly along the westerly line of Third Street to the south line
of Webster Street, thence westerly along the south line of Webster Street to
the east bank of the Mississippi River, thence southerly along the east bank of
the Mississippi River to the north line of Chicago Avenue, thence easterly
along said north line of Chicago Avenue to the place of beginning.
(1977 Code)
5-2-2: MOVING WOODEN BUILDINGS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to build, repair or replace any wooden
building or any part thereof from one place within the above described fire
limits to any other place therein, or to move a wooden building, or any part
thereof, from without said limits to any place therein, without permission
therefor from the city council. Provided, that no such permission shall be
required in the making of repairs, whether external or internal which do not
increase the size of the building concerned or increase its condition as a fire
hazard; provided further, that all roof replacements shall be made of fire
resistant material. No such permission shall be granted by the council unless
it is satisfied that the person desiring the same will comply with all city and
state fire regulations in relation to buildings so as not to increase the
calamities of fire. (1977 Code)
5-2-3: DAMAGED BUILDINGS:
No wooden building within the fire limits which may become damaged to the
extent of fifty percent (50%) of the value thereof by fire, decay or otherwise,
shall be repaired or rebuilt. The extent of the damage that may be done to any
such building as aforesaid shall be determined by three (3) disinterested
persons, residents of the city, one appointed by the mayor, and another who may
be appointed by the owner or agent of such building and the two (2) chosen
shall elect the third. Upon failure of the said owner or agent to select such
person within five (5) days after the mayor has made his selection, it shall
then be lawful for the mayor to select a second person and the two (2) so
appointed shall select the third as in other cases. The persons so chosen shall
first be duly sworn to fairly and impartially estimate such damages and their
decision shall be final. (1977 Code)
5-2-4: JUNKYARDS:
   (A)   It shall not be lawful for any person to establish or locate any
junkyard or similar place within the fire limits of the city or to locate or
establish any junk store therein; neither shall it be lawful for any junkyard
or junk store to be located within three hundred feet (300') of any church,
public or private school, hospital, theater or other place designed for public
assemblages; nor within any block or other section encompassed by streets or
public roads, without the written consent of a majority of the owners of all
real estate therein, used either for residence or retail business purposes, or
both; nor within three hundred feet (300') of any such property fronting on any
street or public road in any other part of the property or both sides thereof;
provided that, before any junkyard or junk store shall be located as to front
on any street or public road adjacent to any block or other section where
permission as aforesaid is required, the written consent of a majority of the
same class of real estate owners on the opposite side of the street or public
road shall also be obtained.
   (B)   The written consent herein required shall be filed with the city
clerk, whose duty it shall be to present the same to the city council at the
next regular meeting thereafter, to the end that such consent may be spread at
large upon the records of such meeting and be made a matter of permanent
record. The regulations herein contained in regard to junkyards and junk
stores, including that of location, shall apply to all such enterprises,
whether retail or wholesale, and to all such businesses as may now be located
in any place within the city contrary to the provisions of this chapter, to
remove the same so as to conform to the requirements thereof. (Ord. 1434, 4-14-
1992)
5-2-5: CONDITION OF STRUCTURES:
No person shall keep or maintain any building or other structures in the city
in such a manner as to endanger persons or property because of faulty
construction, age, lack of repair or in such condition as to become especially
liable to fire, or liable to cause injury or damage by collapse or otherwise,
and no person shall permit or allow any combustible, explosive or inflammable
conditions to exist in or around any such building or structure to the extent
of endangering the same or other property. (1977 Code)
5-2-6: OPEN BURNING; BONFIRES:
(Rep. by Ord. 1247, 11-9-1982)
5-2-7: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
All buildings, structures, businesses or premises constructed, built, located
or maintained in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
held to be and are hereby declared to be nuisances and shall be abated as such
as provided by ordinances pertaining to nuisances in general, in addition to
any other penalty herein provided for. Provided, however, that before any
prosecution shall be instituted hereunder, the fire chief or any policeman, in
all cases where circumstances will permit, shall give a five (5) day written
notice to the owner of the premises involved or other person in charge of same
demanding that the nuisance complained of be abated within that time. In all
cases of urgent necessity where delay may endanger life or property, the fire
chief or any policeman may, by himself or with the help or aid of others, enter
upon the premises in question and abate the nuisance summarily in the interest
of the public welfare. (1977 Code)
5-2-8: FALSE ALARMS:
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to transmit in any manner to the Savanna
fire department a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such transmission
that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such fire exists.
   (B)   The following is a schedule of charges for false fire alarm calls
received within a one year time period:
 
0–5 false alarm$ 0.00
6th false alarm  50.00
7th false alarm  100.00
8th false alarm  500.00
 
The Savanna fire department, at the discretion of the fire chief, may not
respond to subsequent calls after the eighth false alarm unless the alarm
company certifies that the unit has been repaired. (Ord. 1571, 7-9-1996)
5-2-9: PENALTY:
The penalty prescribed for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter,
unless otherwise specified, shall be as set out under section
1-4-1 of this code. (1977 Code; amd. Ord. 1571, 7-9-1996)
CHAPTER 3
FIREWORKS
SECTION:
5-3-1: Fireworks Defined
5-3-2: Fireworks Unlawful
5-3-3: Exception
5-3-1: FIREWORKS DEFINED:
The term "fireworks" shall mean and include any explosive composition, or any
substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the purpose of
producing an audible effect by explosion, deflagration or deterioration, or for
the purpose of producing visual effects, and shall include blank cartridges,
toy cannons, in which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require
fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman
candles, bombs, or other fireworks of like construction and any fireworks
containing any explosive compound, or any tablets or device containing any
explosive substance, or compound, or any tablets or other device containing any
explosive substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual
effects; provided, however, that the term "fireworks" shall not include toy
pistols, toy canes, toy guns, rockets, or other devices in which paper caps
containing twenty five hundredths (0.25) grains or less of explosive compound
are used, providing they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in
contact with the cap when in place for the explosion and toy pistol paper caps
which contain less than twenty hundredths (0.20) grains of explosive mixture,
the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times. (1977 Code)
5-3-2: FIREWORKS UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, use, display, ignite, sell or
offer for sale any fireworks, firecrackers, torpedoes, Roman candles, sky
rockets, cap pistols or other pyrotechnics within the city.
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or keep with intent to sell
explosive compounds for use as rocket fuels. (1977 Code)
5-3-3: EXCEPTION:
Public exhibitions or displays of fireworks or pyrotechnics shall be permitted
when such display or exhibition is under expert supervision; provided, however,
that no public exhibition or display of pyrotechnics shall be had without first
obtaining the approval of the fire chief of the place of exhibition, the
consent of the council and the payment of a permit fee of one dollar ($1.00) to
the clerk. (1977 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GASOLINE, VOLATILE OILS AND LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES
SECTION:
5-4-1: Codes Adopted
5-4-2: Permit Required
5-4-3: Fees
5-4-4: Underground Tanks
5-4-1: CODES ADOPTED:
To the extent not inconsistent with this chapter, the current National Fire
Protection Association laws, rules and regulations relating to the storage,
transportation, sale and use of gasoline, volatile oils and use of liquefied
petroleum gases are hereby adopted by reference as though fully set forth
herein. (1977 Code)
5-4-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate in the city a
gasoline service station or a bulk station for the storage and sale or
distribution of gasoline or petroleum or any of its products, or to store at
any location in the city, gasoline or any other petroleum product or products,
for the purpose of distributing or dispensing to, or for the use as fuel in,
any motor vehicle or motor vehicles without first securing from the city
council a permit therefor, which permit, if granted, shall designate the
location of such station or place of storage. (1977 Code)
5-4-3: FEES:
   (A)   Each person maintaining or operating any such gasoline service
station, to whom a permit shall be granted pursuant to this chapter, shall pay
the city an annual fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per year.
   (B)   Each person operating any gasoline bulk station or other place of
storage, other than as a service station, to whom a permit shall be granted
pursuant to this chapter, shall pay to the city an annual fee of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) per year.
   (C)   Fees paid pursuant to this section shall be due and payable to the
city clerk on or before the third Tuesday of April of each year.
   (D)   If any service station, bulk station or place of storage is not used
or operated for any of the purposes specified in subsection (A) or (B) of this
section at any time following the third Tuesday of April, and prior to the
third Tuesday of October in any year, but is used or operated for any purpose
subsequent to the third Tuesday in October in any year and prior to the third
Tuesday of April in the year following, the license fee for the remainder of
the period until the third Tuesday in April next following, shall be fifty
percent (50%) of the annual fee prescribed by this section, payable upon the
commencement of such use or operation. (1977 Code)
5-4-4: UNDERGROUND TANKS:
   (A)   New Or Replacement Installation:
      1.   Underground flammable liquid storage tanks shall be installed and
tested in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association flammable
and combustible liquids code no. 30-1965, chapter 2, tank storage and chapter
7, service stations; and in accordance with the recommended practice of NFPA
no. 320-1965. Installations incorporating submersible pumps shall be equipped
with a pump actuated leak detector.
      2.   Before the installation of any tank intended for the use of storage
of flammable liquids is covered from sight, the fire chief, or such member of
his department as he shall direct, shall inspect the installation and give
approval. The installer, in the presence of an inspector from the fire
department, shall subject the tank and its piping to a leak test in accordance
with NFPA no. 30-1969, section 26. The test shall be conducted after the tank
has been set in place and all piping has been permanently connected but before
the tank or piping are covered. The test shall be run with air pressure if the
water table permits. When air tested, all joints shall be examined for leakage
detected and there shall be no drop in indicated gauge pressure in thirty (30)
minutes. Hydrostatic leak testing may be conducted with the product.
   (B)   Tanks In Service:
      1.   Accurate inventory control records shall be maintained by the
operator or operator licensee for each underground tank in accordance with NFPA
no. 30-1969, chapter 7, paragraph 7017, and NFPA 329-1965, chapter 2. The
licensee shall promptly report abnormal loss of stock to the fire department.
He shall make his stock control records available for checking by the fire
department.
      2.   Retesting of the installed system shall be conducted in accordance
with either of the following: NFPA 329-1965, chapter 3; or tests approved by
the American Petroleum Institute; or, a test of equal reliability or
sensitivity when approved by the fire department. When testing is required,
such tests shall be made by a person, firm or corporation qualified to test
such underground flammable storage systems and shall be conducted in the
presence of an inspector from the fire department.
      3.   The fire department shall require retesting at any time when it is
suspected that an underground tank or its connected piping may be leaking or
when stock control records indicate an abnormal loss.
      4.   Station owners shall conduct periodic (at least monthly) tests for
the presence of water in submerged tanks in accordance with NFPA 329-1965,
chapter 2.
   (C)   Filing Of Codes And Technical Documents: There shall be on file with
the city clerk three (3) copies of the codes and other technical documents
referred to in subsections (A) and (B) of this section.
   (D)   Report Of Tests; Issuance Of Certificate Of Inspection: A report of
the test made pursuant to subsection (A) of this section shall be made to the
fire department and if the report of the test indicates that the storage tank
is found to be in a satisfactory condition, the tanks shall be approved by the
fire department and a certificate of inspection issued by the fire department.
   (E)   Defective Tanks, Report; Notice Prohibiting Use: Should an underground
flammable liquid storage tank be found defective as a result of such test, the
fire department shall report that fact to the owner or lessee of the premises
on which it is maintained, and it shall be the duty of the fire department to
post a notice prohibiting the use of such defective storage tank until the
defect or defects are eliminated and corrected. If repairs will not overcome
the defects, the future use of the underground flammable storage tanks and
equipment shall be prohibited.
   (F)   Use Prohibited Until Correction Of Defects; Removal Of Notice: After
the posting of a notice pursuant to subsection (E) of this section, it shall be
unlawful for any person to use the defective tank until such time as the
defects are eliminated and corrected to the satisfaction of the fire
department, and the notice so posted removed by the fire department. (1977
Code)
CHAPTER 5
OPEN BURNING
SECTION:
5-5-1: Definitions
5-5-2: General
5-5-3: Exceptions To Provisions
5-5-4: Violation
5-5-5: Penalty
5-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
LANDSCAPE WASTE: Any vegetable or plant refuse including, but not limited to,
tree trimmings, weeds, leaves, grass, yard trimmings and crop residues.
OPEN BURNING: The combustion of any matter in such a way that the products of
the combustion are emitted to the open air. (Ord. 1247, 11-9-1982)
5-5-2: GENERAL:
The use of burn barrels and the burning of any garbage, waste, refuse, rubbish
or substance of any kind within the city limits are prohibited. (Ord. 1844, 6-
27-2006)
The terms of this chapter shall not be construed to prohibit the burning of
fuels for cooking purposes in a domestic fireplace in areas where such burning
is consistent with other laws, provided no garbage shall be burned in such
cases.
Open burning shall be prohibited within the corporate limits of the city except
as permitted under the following conditions and subject to any pollution laws
adopted by the city. (Ord. 1247, 11-9-1982)
5-5-3: EXCEPTIONS TO PROVISIONS:
The following activities are not in violation of section
5-5-2 of this chapter: (Ord. 1247, 11-9-1982)
   (A)   The open burning of landscape waste, but only:
      1.   Between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M., prevailing time, and
sunset on the second and fourth Friday and following Saturday of the month, and
      2.   When atmospheric conditions will readily dissipate contaminants, and
      3.   On the premises on which such waste is generated, and
      4.   When such burning does not create a visibility hazard on streets,
alleys and public sidewalks, and
      5.   When it can be affirmatively demonstrated that no economically
reasonable alternative method of disposal is available, and
      6.   When such burning does not become a nuisance, annoyance or
discomfort to any other person by reason of the emission of smoke, fumes, fly
ash, dust or soot or noxious odor, and
      7.   When such burning is constantly attended by a competent person until
such burning is extinguished. Such person shall have fire extinguishing
equipment readily available for use as deemed necessary by the fire official,
and
      8.   When the location of the burning is a safe distance from any
structure and adequate provisions are made to prevent fire from spreading to
any structure or the fire is contained in an approved burner located safely not
less than fifteen feet (15') from any structure. (Ord. 2017, 10-23-2012)
5-5-4: VIOLATION:
Violation of any of the conditions shall be the basis for issuance of a
citation to the violator by the police department and imposition of a fine.
(Ord. 2017, 10-23-2012)
5-5-5: PENALTY:
The penalty prescribed for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter
or for any rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, shall be as set forth
in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 1247, 11-9-1982)
CHAPTER 6
WOOD BURNING FURNACES
SECTION:
5-6-1: Definitions
5-6-2: Outdoor Wood Burning Furnace
5-6-3: Indoor Wood Burning Furnace
5-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
INDOOR WOOD BURNING FURNACES: For purposes of this chapter, "indoor wood
burning furnace" means an appliance designed to be located inside living space
ordinarily used for human habitation and designed to transfer or provide heat,
through the burning of wood, pellets, corn and the like. An indoor wood burning
furnace does not include a wood burning, gas or electric fireplace.
OUTDOOR WOOD BURNING FURNACES: For purposes of this chapter, "outdoor wood
burning furnace" means an accessory structure or appliance designed to be
located outside living space ordinarily used for human habitation and designed
to transfer or provide heat, through the burning of wood, pellets, corn and the
like. An outdoor wood burning furnace does not include a fire pit, wood fired
barbecue or chimney. (Ord. 1864, 1-9-2007)
5-6-2: OUTDOOR WOOD BURNING FURNACE:
No person shall construct, install, operate or use an outdoor wood burning
furnace, unless it complies with the following:
   (A)   Installation of the outdoor wood burning furnace is not less than two
hundred feet (200') from the nearest residence not serviced by the outdoor wood
burning furnace;
   (B)   Installation of the chimney of the outdoor wood burning furnace is
less than fifty five feet (55') in height but taller than the height of the
roof peaks of the residences located within two hundred feet (200') of the
outdoor wood burning furnace;
   (C)   Installation and operation of the outdoor wood burning furnace must be
in accordance with the manufacturer's written instructions, provided such
instructions do not conflict with the provisions of this section;
   (D)   An inspection of the furnace has been performed by the city and a
permit for its use issued;
   (E)   Burning of household waste and the like is prohibited. (Ord. 1864, 1-
9-2007)
5-6-3: INDOOR WOOD BURNING FURNACE:
No person shall construct, install, operate or use an indoor wood burning
furnace, unless it complies with the following:
   (A)   The indoor wood burning furnace chimney must have a height that
extends above the rooftop of the structure;
   (B)   Installation and operation of the indoor wood burning furnace must be
in accordance with the manufacturer's written instructions, provided such
instructions not conflict with the provisions of this section;
   (C)   Burning of household waste and the like is prohibited. (Ord. 1864, 1-
9-2007)
TITLE 6
POLICE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
MISDEMEANORS
SECTION:
6-1-1: Circuses, Carnivals Prohibited
6-1-2: Disorderly Conduct
6-1-3: Weapons, Discharge Of
6-1-4: Homeland Security
6-1-1: CIRCUSES, CARNIVALS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any unlicensed traveling circus, carnival, menagerie,
sideshow, medicine show, minstrel show and any and all other traveling
exhibitions, performances and entertainments from outside the city to give,
conduct, produce, present or offer any exhibition, performance or entertainment
in or upon any public street, alley or other public place within the corporate
limits of the city. (Ord. 1832, 4-11-2006)
6-1-2: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly:
   (A)   Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb
another and to provoke a breach of the peace; or
   (B)   With intent to annoy another, makes a telephone call, whether or not
conversation thereby ensues; or
   (C)   Transmits in any manner to the fire department a false alarm of fire,
knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for
believing that such fire exists; or
   (D)   Transmits in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that a
bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in such place that its
explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission
that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such a bomb or explosive
is concealed in such place. (1977 Code)
6-1-3: WEAPONS, DISCHARGE OF:
It shall be unlawful to discharge any weapon (firearm, air gun, bow and arrow,
or any missile that could be construed as a weapon) within the city; provided
that this section shall not be construed to prohibit any officer of the law
from discharging a weapon in the performance of his duty; nor to any citizen
from discharging a weapon when lawfully defending person or property; nor to
any properly enclosed and supervised pistol or archery range, provided that
such ranges have a backstop capable of stopping projectiles (arrows, shot, or
sling) shot into the backstop without spatter or ricochet. These ranges (pistol
or archery) must be in a secluded or restricted rear so as to ensure that
public life and property shall not be endangered. (1977 Code)
6-1-4: HOMELAND SECURITY:
   (A)   Purpose: The purpose of these regulations is to standardize actions to
be taken by the city of Savanna and the county of Carroll as a result of
increased terrorist levels within the United States and the state of Illinois.
   (B)   Guidelines: The guidelines attached as exhibit A to the ordinance
codified herein prepared by the Illinois terrorism task force related to the
implementation of the state of Illinois homeland security advisory system are
hereby adopted. (Ord. 1711, 3-11-2003)
CHAPTER 2
ANIMALS
SECTION:
   Article I. General Provisions
6-2-1: Definitions
6-2-2: Cruelty
6-2-3: Exhibition Of Animals
6-2-4: Noises
6-2-5: Animal Restraint
6-2-6: Killing Dangerous Animals
6-2-7: Housing
6-2-8: Impounding
6-2-9: Removal Of Dog And Other Animal Defecation From Public And Private
Properties
   Article II. Kennels And Pet Shops
6-2-10: License
6-2-11: Sanitation
6-2-12: Health Officer
   Article III. Dogs And Cats
6-2-13: Enforcement
6-2-14: Animal Bite
6-2-15: Keeping, Licensing Of Dangerous Animals
6-2-16: Limitations On Cats Running At Large
6-2-17: Stray And Feral Cats
6-2-18: Responsibilities Imposed On Those Who Feed Stray Cats
6-2-19: Responsibilities Imposed On Those Who Feed Feral Cats
ARTICLE I. GENERAL PROVISIONS
6-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
ANIMAL: Any animal, other than man, which may be affected by rabies.
FERAL CAT: Any homeless, wild or untamed cat which: a) is born in the wild or
the offspring of an owned or feral cat and is not socialized, b) is a formerly
owned cat that has been abandoned and is no longer socialized, or c) lives on a
farm.
KENNEL AND PET SHOPS: Shall be construed to include any establishment for the
raising, training, boarding or selling of dogs, cats, birds, mice, rats or
other small animals for hire or profit, or where more than three (3) dogs or
cats or other small animals are harbored for sixty (60) days or more or until
weaned.
STRAY CAT: Any cat whose owner or keeper from time to time allows the cat to
run free off of the property of the owner or keeper. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-2: CRUELTY:
No person shall cruelly treat any animal in the city in any way; and any person
who inhumanely beats, underfeeds, overloads or abandons any animal shall be
deemed guilty of a violation of this section. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-3: EXHIBITION OF ANIMALS:
Exhibitions or parades of animals which are Ferae naturae (in a wild nature or
disposition) in the eyes of the law may be conducted only upon securing a
permit from the chief of police. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-4: NOISES:
It shall be unlawful to harbor or keep any animal which disturbs the peace by
loud noises at any time, day or night. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-5: ANIMAL RESTRAINT:
It shall be unlawful to permit any animal to run at large in the city. Any
animal running at large in the defined city limits, creating a public nuisance,
may be impounded. It shall further be unlawful to picket or tie any animal on
any public owned property for the purpose of grazing or feeding. (Ord. 2122, 4-
28-2015)
6-2-6: KILLING DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
The members of the police department and/or other police authorized persons in
the city are authorized to kill any dangerous animal of any kind when it is
necessary for the protection of any person or property. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-7: HOUSING:
No person shall cause or allow any place where any animal is or may be kept to
become unclean or unwholesome. It shall be unlawful to keep or raise any live
rabbits, chickens or other fowl, cattle, horses, asses, mules, swine, sheep or
goats within the city limits if the above mentioned shall be considered a
public nuisance. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-8: IMPOUNDING:
Animals running at large in violation of the provisions of this code may be
seized by any person, as directed by the mayor, and impounded at the Carroll
County animal shelter. The owner of the animal will be charged a redemption fee
of twenty dollars ($20.00) to redeem the animal, in addition to any other
charges which the shelter may impose. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-9: REMOVAL OF DOG AND OTHER ANIMAL DEFECATION FROM PUBLIC AND PRIVATE
PROPERTIES:
An owner or person having custody of any dog or any other animal shall not
permit said dog or any other animal to defecate on any school ground, public
street, alley, sidewalk, tree bank, park or any other public grounds or any
private property within the city, other than the premises of the owner or
person having custody of said dog or other animal, unless said defecation is
removed immediately. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
ARTICLE II. KENNELS AND PET SHOPS
6-2-10: LICENSE:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to operate a kennel or pet shop anywhere within
the corporate city limits without first securing a license therefor. The annual
fee for such license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). Notwithstanding
the foregoing, the city council, at its discretion, may issue one kennel
license annually, without fee, to a not for profit corporation doing business
in Savanna, Illinois.
   (B)   No new license to operate a kennel or pet shop shall be issued unless
each of the following requirements are met:
      1.   The applicant submits to the city a signed statement by a licensed
veterinarian that he has inspected the premises to be used as a kennel or pet
shop and the premises meets the criteria of section 6-2-11 of this chapter.
      2.   The premises to be used as a kennel or pet shop contains adequate
fencing or other enclosures necessary to prevent the escape of animals to be
kept on the premises.
      3.   The use of the premises as a kennel or pet shop is in conformance
with city zoning regulations. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
      4.   The applicant establishes by the preponderance of the evidence
produced at a public hearing before the city planning and zoning board, with
notice thereof published at least one time not less than ten (10) days nor more
than thirty (30) days in a paper of general circulation within the city at the
expense of the applicant, that the proposed use of the premises as a kennel or
pet shop will not materially reduce the value of surrounding property. (Ord.
2122, 4-28-2015; amd. Ord. 2158, 4-26-2016)
   (C)   No existing license to operate a kennel or pet shop shall be renewed
or reissued unless the requirements of subsections (A), (B)1, (B)2 and (B)3 of
this section are met.
   (D)   Any license issued hereunder may be revoked by an order of the mayor
if at any time the mayor finds that the premises are not operated in accordance
with this chapter, after first giving the holder of the license due notice and
an opportunity to be heard. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-11: SANITATION:
Every place used as a kennel or pet shop shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition, and no refuse or waste material shall be allowed to remain thereon
for more than twenty four (24) hours. All animals shall be humanely treated;
and any animal having any disease shall be properly isolated and treated. (Ord.
2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-12: HEALTH OFFICER:
The health officer shall have the right to inspect such premises during normal
working hours. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
ARTICLE III. DOGS AND CATS
6-2-13: ENFORCEMENT:
The mayor shall direct the actions to be taken to enforce the provisions of
this chapter. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-14: ANIMAL BITE:
Whenever any animal bites a person, the owner of said animal shall immediately
notify the chief of police, who shall order the animal to be held on the
owner's premises or shall have the animal impounded for a period of ten (10)
days. The animal shall be examined immediately after it has bitten anyone and
again at the end of the ten (10) day period. If, at the end of this ten (10)
day period a veterinarian is convinced that the animal is free from rabies, he
shall order the animal released from quarantine or the pound, as the case may
be. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-15: KEEPING, LICENSING OF DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
This code is hereby amended to adopt 510 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11 et
seq., as amended. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-16: LIMITATIONS ON CATS RUNNING AT LARGE:
It shall be unlawful for any cat owner to permit a cat to run free outside the
residence of its owner or keeper unless the cat has been:
   (A)   Neutered or spayed to prevent it from procreating;
   (B)   Immunized against rabies and vaccinated in compliance with the laws of
the state of Illinois;
   (C)   Appropriately "tipped" on an ear to signify that it has been neutered/
spayed and immunized. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-17: STRAY AND FERAL CATS:
The city council finds and declares that the proliferation of feral cats and
stray cats poses a potential danger to the health, safety, and general welfare
of the public. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-18: RESPONSIBILITIES IMPOSED ON THOSE WHO FEED STRAY CATS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to feed stray cats, if such
feeding causes a nuisance to neighbors or creates a condition contrary to the
health, safety, and welfare of the community.
   (B)   Any person who undertakes to feed stray cats shall assume
responsibility and be liable for any damage to persons or property caused by
the cats. In addition such person shall be liable for and assume responsibility
for seeing that the stray cats are:
      1.   Neutered or spayed to prevent procreating;
      2.   Immunized against rabies and vaccinated in compliance with the laws
of the state of Illinois;
      3.   Appropriately "tipped" on an ear to signify that they have been
neutered/spayed and immunized. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
6-2-19: RESPONSIBILITIES IMPOSED ON THOSE WHO FEED FERAL CATS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to continue to feed feral cats, if
such feeding causes a nuisance to neighbors or creates a condition contrary to
the health, safety, and welfare of the community.
   (B)   Any person who undertakes to feed feral cats shall assume
responsibility and be liable for any damage to persons or property caused by
the cats. In addition such person shall be liable for and assume responsibility
for seeing that the feral cats are:
      1.   Neutered or spayed to prevent procreating;
      2.   Immunized against rabies and vaccinated in compliance with the laws
of the state of Illinois;
      3.   Appropriately "tipped" on an ear to signify that they have been
neutered/spayed and immunized. (Ord. 2122, 4-28-2015)
CHAPTER 3
CURFEW
SECTION:
6-3-1: Loitering Of Minors
6-3-2: Responsibility
6-3-3: Loitering
6-3-1: LOITERING OF MINORS:
It is unlawful for a person less than seventeen (17) years of age to be present
at or upon any public assembly, building, place, store or highway at the
following times unless accompanied by and supervised by a parent, legal
guardian or other responsible companion at least eighteen (18) years of age
approved by a parent or legal guardian, or unless engaged in a business or
occupation which the laws of this state authorize a person less than eighteen
(18) years of age to perform:
Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. Saturday;
Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. Sunday; and
Between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Sunday to Thursday, inclusive and six
o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the following day. (1977 Code)
6-3-2: RESPONSIBILITY:
   (A)   Parents: It is unlawful for a parent, legal guardian or other person
to knowingly permit a person in his custody or control to violate section
6-3-1 of this chapter.
   (B)   Owners Of Amusement Places: It is unlawful for any person operating
places of amusement and entertainment to permit any minors under the age of
seventeen (17) years to enter or remain in such places of amusement and
entertainment during the hours prohibited under this chapter; provided,
however, that the provisions of this section do not apply when the minor is
accompanied by his parent, legal guardian or other responsible companion at
least eighteen (18) years of age approved by a parent or legal guardian. (1977
Code)
   (C)   Defense Of A Violation: It is a defense to a violation under this
chapter that the child engaged in the prohibited conduct while:
      1.   Engaged in business or occupation which the laws of Illinois
authorize a person less than seventeen (17) years of age to perform;
      2.   Accompanied by the child's parent, legal guardian, custodian,
sibling, stepbrother or stepsister at least eighteen (18) years of age;
      3.   Accompanied by an adult at least eighteen (18) years of age approved
by the child's parent, guardian or custodian;
      4.   Participating in, going to, or returning from:
         (a)   Employment which the laws of the state authorize a person less
than seventeen (17) years of age to perform;
         (b)   A school recreational activity;
         (c)   A religious event;
         (d)   An emergency involving the protection of a person or property
from an eminent threat of serious bodily injury or substantial damage;
         (e)   An activity involving the exercise of the child's rights
protected under the first amendment to the United States constitution or
article I, sections 3, 4 and 5 of the constitution of the state of Illinois, or
both;
         (f)   An activity conducted by a nonprofit or governmental entity that
provides recreation, education, training, or other care under the supervision
of one or more adults. (Ord. 1767, 5-11-2004)
6-3-3: LOITERING:
   (A)   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply:
    LOITERING: Remaining in one location in a place, or at a time or in a
manner not usual for law abiding individuals.
   PUBLIC PLACE: Shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: all
places maintained by public funds such as streets, public restrooms, sidewalks,
parks, alleys, and public buildings, and all places privately owned but open to
the general public.
   (B)   Determination Of Probable Cause For Alarm, Or Disturbance Of Others:
Without limitation, the following activities may be considered in determining
probable cause for alarm or concern:
      1.   The flight of a person upon the appearance of a police officer.
      2.   Refusal of a person to identify himself or herself at the request of
a police officer.
      3.   Attempted concealment of a person or any object upon the appearance
of a police officer.
      4.   The systematic checking by a person of doors, windows, or other
means of access to buildings, houses, or vehicles.
      5.   Continuous presence by a person in close proximity to any building,
house, vehicle, or any other property when the activity of such person
reasonably manifests possible unlawful activity or reasonably presents a threat
or hazard to another person or to the security of any property in the vicinity.
(Ord. 1367, 11-28-1989)
      6.   Obstructing the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles.
      7.   Obstructing, molesting or interfering with any person lawfully in
any public place. This subsection shall include the making of unsolicited
remarks of an offensive, disgusting or insulting nature or which are calculated
to annoy or disturb the person to, or in whose hearing, the remarks are made.
(Ord. 1539, 8-8-1995)
   (C)   Loitering; Police Order To Disperse:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, either alone or with
others, in a public place under circumstances which may reasonably alarm or
disturb others after receiving an order to move or disperse by a police
officer.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, either alone or with
others, in a public place in such a manner so as to obstruct the free and
uninterrupted use of any public place after receiving an order to move or
disperse by a police officer. (Ord. 1367, 11-28-1989)
CHAPTER 4
NOISE
SECTION:
6-4-1: Definition
6-4-2: Noise Prohibited
6-4-3: Automobile Warning Devices
6-4-4: Whistles
6-4-5: Vehicles
6-4-6: Mufflers
6-4-7: Pets
6-4-8: Loud, Disturbing, Unnecessary Noises
6-4-1: DEFINITION:
"Noise" shall mean any sound or sounds which cause annoyance to residents of
the city. (1977 Code)
6-4-2: NOISE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to make, or cause to be made, any noise or sounds of such
volume or of such a nature as to cause annoyance to residents of the city.
(1977 Code)
6-4-3: AUTOMOBILE WARNING DEVICES:
It shall be unlawful to use an automobile horn or other warning device to emit
an unreasonably loud or harsh sound or whistle, except to give audible warning
to ensure safe operation of a vehicle. (1977 Code)
6-4-4: WHISTLES:
It shall be unlawful to blow, or cause to be blown, any steam whistle of any
stationary engine or steam engine in the city, except as a signal for starting
or stopping work or in emergencies to avoid injury to persons or property.
(1977 Code)
6-4-5: VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle which makes unusually loud or
unnecessary noise. (1977 Code)
6-4-6: MUFFLERS:
No motor vehicle shall be operated on any street unless such vehicle is
provided with such muffler in efficient actual working condition, and the use
of a cutout is prohibited. (1977 Code)
6-4-7: PETS:
It shall be unlawful to keep any animal which makes any noise or sounds of such
volume or of such a nature as to cause annoyance to residents of the city.
(1977 Code)
6-4-8: LOUD, DISTURBING, UNNECESSARY NOISES:
The following acts are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises
in violation of this chapter, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be
exclusive, namely:
   (A)   Noises Near Schools, Hospitals, Churches: The creation of any
excessive noise on any street near any school, institution of learning, church
or court while the same is in session, or adjacent to any hospital, which
unreasonably interferes with the workings or sessions thereof. (1977 Code)
   (B)   Noises To Attract Attention: The use of any drum, loudspeaker or other
instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of
noise and/or music for the purpose of show or display of merchandise. (Ord.
1983, 10-11-2011)
   (C)   Loudspeaker Or Amplifiers: The unreasonable use of any amplifiers or
loudspeakers in the course of any public address.
   (D)   Operation Of Motor Vehicles: The operation of any motor vehicle so as
to cause squealing of tires. (1977 Code)
CHAPTER 5
PARADES, OPEN AIR MEETINGS
SECTION:
6-5-1: Definitions
6-5-2: Permit Required
6-5-3: Application
6-5-4: Hours Parades And Open Air Meetings Allowed
6-5-5: Number Of Vehicles, Persons
6-5-6: Procedure On Applications
6-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter the following terms shall be defined:
OPEN AIR MEETING: Any congregation of citizens held outdoors and upon any
public property for the purpose of hearing speakers or discussing some matter
of common interest where the number of participants expected may reasonably be
assumed to exceed fifty (50).
PARADE: Any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of
any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public
place in the municipality. (Ord. 2068, 11-26-2013)
6-5-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall participate in a parade or open air meeting held on any public
way or on any public property unless a written permit therefor shall first be
approved from the chief of police and mayor. The chief of police shall obtain
permission as required from the Illinois department of transportation when a
state highway is utilized for parade purposes. (Ord. 2068, 11-26-2013)
6-5-3: APPLICATION:
An application to conduct a parade or open air meeting shall be submitted three
(3) weeks prior to the requested parade date and three (3) days prior to an
open air meeting to the chief of police or mayor, by a representative of the
group seeking the permit, and shall set forth the following information:
   (A)   The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the
parade chairman or chairman of the open air meeting;
   (B)   The date when the parade or open air meeting is to be conducted;
   (C)   The route to be traveled, the starting point, the termination point
and the location of speakers' platforms;
   (D)   The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which
will constitute such parade or open air meeting; the type of animals, and
description of the vehicles;
   (E)   The hours when such parade or open air meeting will start and
terminate;
   (F)   A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion
of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed;
   (G)   The location by streets of any assembly for such parade or open air
meeting;
   (H)   The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any
such assembly area or areas. (Ord. 2068, 11-26-2013)
6-5-4: HOURS PARADES AND OPEN AIR MEETINGS ALLOWED:
   (A)   All parades shall be held during daylight hours at the time other than
peak traffic periods that is determined by the chief of police.
   (B)   All open air meetings shall conclude by twelve o'clock (12:00)
midnight and shall not be held before twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on Sunday.
(Ord. 2068, 11-26-2013)
6-5-5: NUMBER OF VEHICLES, PERSONS:
Parades and open air meetings shall be limited to such numbers as will not
obstruct traffic either vehicular or pedestrian, in an unreasonable manner, and
in any event no such parade or open air meeting shall consist of more than five
hundred (500) persons. (Ord. 2068, 11-26-2013)
6-5-6: PROCEDURE ON APPLICATIONS:
   (A)   If the chief of police shall receive more than one application for a
parade or open air meeting at the same time and the same place, or on the same
day, the application filed first in the time shall take precedence. An
application shall be considered to be "at the same time" if the event is
scheduled to commence within two (2) hours before or after the holding of
another event. An application shall be considered to be "at the same place" if
the requested parade route comes at any point within six (6) blocks or any
equivalent distance from the route of another parade or if the open air meeting
is to be conducted within one-half (1/2) mile of another open air meeting. If
the chief of police receives an application for more than one parade or open
air meeting in a single day, he may set a time for the duration of each parade
or open air meeting which time shall not, without the consent of the group
seeking the permit, be less than three (3) hours.
   (B)   The chief of police shall issue permits for more than a single parade
during one day in accordance with the requirements of subsection (A) of this
section; provided, however, that he may not issue multiple permits beyond the
point at which the issuance of an additional permit would require the
continuing diversion of so great a number of police officers or other municipal
personnel so as to prevent normal police protection or other services to the
municipality. (Ord. 2068, 11-26-2013)
CHAPTER 6
ABANDONED PROPERTY
SECTION:
6-6-1: Application Of Act
6-6-2: Police Shall Have Custody
6-6-3: Sale Of Unclaimed Property
6-6-4: Contraband Property
6-6-5: Proceeds Of Sale
6-6-6: Recovery Of Property
6-6-1: APPLICATION OF ACT:
All personal property which possession is transferred to the police department
of the city under circumstances supporting a reasonable belief that such
property was abandoned, lost or stolen or otherwise illegally possessed, except
property seized during a search and retained and ultimately returned, destroyed
or otherwise disposed of pursuant to an order of court, shall be disposed of as
provided in this code. (1977 Code)
6-6-2: POLICE SHALL HAVE CUSTODY:
Property believed to be abandoned, lost, stolen or otherwise illegally
possessed shall be retained in the custody of the chief of police or principal
law officer of the police department of the city who shall make reasonable
inquiry and efforts to identify and notify the owner or other persons entitled
to possession thereof and shall return the property to said person provided
reasonable and satisfactory proof of ownership or right to possession is made
and reimbursement is made to the police department for all reasonable expenses
of such custody. (1977 Code)
6-6-3: SALE OF UNCLAIMED PROPERTY:
All property so obtained by the police department of the city which the
identity or location of the owner or other person entitled to possession has
not been ascertained within six (6) months after the police department obtains
such possession, the chief of police shall effectuate the sale of the property
for cash to the highest bidder at public auction, notice of which, including
time, place and a brief description of such property, shall be published at
least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where such
official has authority at least ten (10) days prior to such auction. If
official notice is given and property offered, but not sold at such public
auction, it may be offered and sold at subsequent public auction without
notice. (1977 Code)
6-6-4: CONTRABAND PROPERTY:
Any property received or possessed or transferred to the police department of
the city which is considered contraband property by reason of the nature of the
property or any dangerous weapon may not be sold and shall be destroyed under
the direct supervision of the chief of police of the city. (1977 Code)
6-6-5: PROCEEDS OF SALE:
Proceeds of the sale of the property at public auction less reimbursement to
the law enforcement agency for the reasonable expenses of custody and
conducting the sale and advertising shall be deposited in the treasury of the
city. (1977 Code)
6-6-6: RECOVERY OF PROPERTY:
The owner or other person entitled to possession of such property may claim or
recover possession of the property at any time before its sale at public
auction upon providing reasonable and satisfactory proof of ownership or right
to possession and reimbursement of the police department of the city for all
reasonable expenses of the custody and sale advertisements thereof. (1977 Code)
CHAPTER 7
ABANDONED, INOPERABLE VEHICLES
SECTION:
6-7-1: Definitions
6-7-2: Abandonment
6-7-3: Notify Police Department
6-7-4: Removal Authorized
6-7-5: Record Of Removed Vehicles
6-7-6: Unknown Owner
6-7-7: Identification
6-7-8: Proof Of Ownership
6-7-9: Sale Of Unclaimed Vehicles
6-7-10: Disposition Of Vehicles
6-7-11: Record Of Transactions Maintained
6-7-12: Proceeds
6-7-13: Liability For Damages
6-7-14: Penalty
6-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings
ascribed to them as follows:
ABANDONED VEHICLE: All motor vehicles or other vehicles in a state of disrepair
rendering the vehicle incapable of being driven in its condition, or any motor
vehicle or other vehicle that has not been moved or used for seven (7)
consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted. The movement of such a
vehicle shall be interpreted that such vehicle must be operated and driven from
its location of abandonment a minimum distance of five hundred feet (500').
ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLE: A motor driven vehicle with treads or wheels designed to
travel on rough or uneven ground.
ANTIQUE VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle or other vehicle twenty five (25) years of
age or older.
BOAT: A boat propelled usually by an internal or external combustion engine.
CAMPER: A portable dwelling incorporated into a motor vehicle or placed on
wheels (for example a specially equipped trailer or automotive vehicle) for use
during casual travel and camping.
INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at
least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels, or other parts have been removed, or
on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or
otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its
own motor power. "Inoperable motor vehicle" shall include any motor vehicle or
boat which is not properly licensed with the state of Illinois. "Inoperable
motor vehicle" shall not include a motor vehicle which has been rendered
temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to
perform ordinary service or repair operations, vehicles temporarily stored in
duly licensed commercial garages and storage yards; and vehicles kept inside a
fully enclosed garage or storage building.
LAWN MOWER: A motor driven machine with a rotating blade for cutting grass.
MOTOR HOME: A motor vehicle built on a car, truck or bus chassis and designed
to serve as self-contained living quarters for recreational travel.
MOTOR VEHICLE: An automobile, truck, bus, motorcycle or similar motor driven
conveyance.
MOTORCYCLE: A two (2) wheeled motor driven vehicle resembling a heavy bicycle.
TRAILER: A nonautomotive vehicle designed for transporting something or a motor
vehicle equipped with living quarters. (Ord. 1118, 5-10-1977; amd. Ord. 1162,
4-10-1979; Ord. 1657, 6-13-2000; Ord. 1995, 2-14-2012; Ord. 2047, 7-9-2013)
For purposes of this chapter reference to motor vehicle or inoperable motor
vehicles shall include all-terrain vehicles, boats, campers, lawn mowers,
motorcycles, motor homes, motor vehicles and similar motor driven conveyances
as well as trailers. (Ord. 2047, 7-9-2013)
6-7-2: ABANDONMENT:
The abandonment of a motor vehicle or the keeping of an inoperable motor
vehicle, whether on public or private property within this city, is unlawful
and subject to penalties as set forth herein. An abandoned vehicle or an
inoperable motor vehicle or any part thereof may be authorized for removal by
or upon order of the chief of the police department of the city, after at least
seven (7) days' notice to the vehicle owner and/or the owner of the private
property on which the vehicle may be located. However, nothing in this section
shall apply to any motor vehicle that is kept within a building when not in
use, to operable antique vehicles, or to a motor vehicle on the premises of a
place of business engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles. (Ord.
1657, 6-13-2000)
6-7-3: NOTIFY POLICE DEPARTMENT:
When an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle
comes into the temporary possession or custody of a person in this state not
the owner of the vehicle, such person shall immediately notify the police
department when the vehicle is within the corporate limits of the city. Upon
receipt of such notification, the chief of the police department shall
authorize a towing service to remove and take possession of the abandoned,
lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle. The towing service
will safely keep the towed vehicle and its contents, maintain a record of the
tow until the vehicle is claimed by the owner or any other person legally
entitled to possession thereof, or until it is disposed of as provided in this
chapter. (1977 Code)
6-7-4: REMOVAL AUTHORIZED:
   (A)   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part thereof is abandoned
on a highway, street, alley, city parking lot or other public property in the
city seven (7) days or more, its removal by a towing service may be authorized
by order of the chief of the police department of the city.
   (B)   When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, burned or partially dismantled
motor vehicle or other vehicle is creating a traffic hazard because of its
position in relation to the highway, street or alley, or its physical
appearance is causing the impeding of traffic, its immediate removal by a
towing service may be authorized by order of the chief of the police department
of the city. (Ord. 1162, 4-10-1979)
   (C)   When a vehicle removed from either public or private property is
authorized by order of the chief of the police department of the city, the
owner of the vehicle will be responsible for all towing costs. (1977 Code)
6-7-5: RECORD OF REMOVED VEHICLES:
When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is authorized to be towed away, the
police department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed,
listing the manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification
number and license plate year and number displayed on the vehicle. The record
shall also include the date and hour of tow, location towed from, location
towed to, reason for towing and the name of the officer authorizing the tow.
(1977 Code)
6-7-6: UNKNOWN OWNER:
When the city police department does not know the identity of the registered
owner or other legally entitled person, they will cause the motor vehicle
registration records of the state of Illinois to be searched by a directed
communication to the secretary of state for the purpose of obtaining the
required ownership information.
The police department will cause the stolen motor vehicle files of the Illinois
state police to be searched by a directed communication to the Illinois state
police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the Illinois state
police files are searched with negative results, the information contained in
the national crime information center (NCIC) files will be searched by the
Illinois state police. The information determined from these record searches
will be used by the police department in sending a notification by certified
mail to the owner or legally entitled person advising where the vehicle is
held, requesting a disposition be made and setting forth public sale
information. (1977 Code)
6-7-7: IDENTIFICATION:
When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of
a motor vehicle or other vehicle cannot be identified from the registration
files of this state or from the registration files of a foreign state, if
applicable, the police department shall notify the Illinois state police for
the purpose of identifying the vehicle's owner or other person legally entitled
to the possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by the Illinois
state police will be immediately forwarded to the law enforcement agency having
custody of the vehicle for notification of the owner. (1977 Code)
6-7-8: PROOF OF OWNERSHIP:
Any time before a motor vehicle or other vehicle is sold at public sale or
disposed of as provided herein, the owner or other person legally entitled to
its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the police department
proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the vehicle. No
vehicle shall be released to the owner or other person under this section until
all towing and storage charges have been paid. (1977 Code)
6-7-9: SALE OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES:
Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other
vehicle, seven (7) years of age or newer, remains unclaimed by the registered
owner or other person legally entitled to its possession for a period of sixty
(60) days after notice has been given as provided herein, the police department
having possession of the vehicle shall cause it to be sold at public sale to
the highest bidder. Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be posted in
a conspicuous place for at least ten (10) days prior to the sale on the
premises where the vehicle has been impounded. At least ten (10) days prior to
the sale, the police department shall cause a notice of the time and place of
the sale to be sent to the registered owner or other person by certified mail
by the police department or towing service to be legally entitled to the
possession of the vehicle. Such notice shall contain a complete description of
the vehicle to be sold and what steps must be taken by any legally entitled
person to reclaim the vehicle.
In those instances where the certified notification specified herein has been
returned by the postal authorities to the police department due to the address
obtained from the registration records of this state, the sending of a second
certified notice will not be required. (Ord. 2167, 5-10-2016)
6-7-10: DISPOSITION OF VEHICLES:
When the identity of the registered owner or other person legally entitled to
the possession of an abandoned, lost or unclaimed vehicle of seven (7) years of
age or newer cannot be determined by any means provided for in this chapter,
the vehicle may be sold as provided herein or disposed of in the manner
authorized by this chapter without notice to the registered owner or other
person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle.
When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven (7) years of age is impounded as
specified by this chapter, it will be kept in custody for a minimum of ten (10)
days for the purpose of determining ownership, the contacting of the registered
owner by the U.S. mail, public service or in person for a determination of the
Illinois state police stolen motor vehicle files for theft and wanted
information. At the expiration of the ten (10) day period, without the benefit
of disposition information being received from the registered owner, the chief
of police will authorize the disposal of the vehicle as junk only.
A motor vehicle or other vehicle classified as an antique vehicle is excluded
from this chapter. (1977 Code)
6-7-11: RECORD OF TRANSACTIONS MAINTAINED:
When a motor vehicle or other vehicle in the custody of the police department
is reclaimed by the registered owner or other legally entitled person, or when
the vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise disposed of as provided in this
chapter, a report of the transaction will be maintained by the police
department for a period of one year from the date of the sale or disposal.
(1977 Code)
6-7-12: PROCEEDS:
When a vehicle located within the corporate limits of the city is authorized to
be towed away by the chief of police and disposed of as set forth in this
chapter, the proceeds of the public sale or disposition after the deduction of
towing, storage and processing charges shall be deposited in the city treasury.
(1977 Code)
6-7-13: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES:
Any police officer, towing service owner, operator or employee shall not be
held to answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered
owner, former registered owner, or his legal representative, or any other
person legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle
when the vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by this
chapter. (1977 Code)
6-7-14: PENALTY:
In addition to being responsible for towing costs, any person, firm or
corporation violating this chapter shall be fined a sum not to exceed five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for any one offense, and a separate offense shall be
deemed committed for each and every day which a violation continues or exists
after the seven (7) day notice period. (Ord. 1657, 6-13-2000)
CHAPTER 8
VANDALISM; PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY
SECTION:
6-8-1: Definitions
6-8-2: Offenses
6-8-3: Penalties
6-8-4: Restitution By Parent Or Legal Guardian
6-8-5: Common Law Damages
6-8-6: Civil Practice Act In Proceedings Under Section
6-8-4 
6-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
MINOR: A person who is above the age of eleven (11) years but has not yet
attained eighteen (18) years of age.
PARENT OR LEGAL GUARDIAN: One or both of the natural parents of a minor and/or
any person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a circuit court of
this state or a court of foreign jurisdiction, but does not include a person
appointed guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act 1 .
PERSON: Any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind, including, but not by way of limitation, the city of
Savanna, any school district, library district, park district or fire
protection district.
PROPERTY OF ANOTHER: Any and all real estate, including any and all
improvements thereon and any and all property, personal, tangible or
intangible, in which the offender has no interest. (Ord. 1145, 3-14-1978)
 
Notes
1 1. 705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq.
6-8-2: OFFENSES:
No person, including any minor, shall, within the corporate limits of the city
of Savanna:
   (A)   Wilfully or maliciously damage any property of another person without
such other person's consent.
   (B)   Wilfully or maliciously by means of fire or explosion, damage any
property of another person.
   (C)   Wilfully or maliciously start a fire in or upon the property of
another person without such person's consent.
   (D)   Wilfully or maliciously deposit in or upon the property of another
person any stink bomb or other offensive smelling compound without the consent
of such other person. (Ord. 1145, 3-14-1978)
6-8-3: PENALTIES:
Any person, not a minor, determined to have committed an act prohibited by
section
6-8-2 of this chapter shall be fined in a sum not to exceed five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for any one offense. (Ord. 1145, 3-14-1978)
6-8-4: RESTITUTION BY PARENT OR LEGAL GUARDIAN:
The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor defendant who resides
with such parent or legal guardian shall be liable for actual damages arising
as a consequence of the performance of the unemancipated minor offender of the
wilful or malicious acts specified in section
6-8-2 of this chapter. However, no recovery under this section may exceed five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each separate and distinct occurrence of such
wilful or malicious conduct by any unemancipated minor found to have caused
such injury or damage. Such actual damage shall be in addition to any and all
court costs. (Ord. 1145, 3-14-1978)
6-8-5: COMMON LAW DAMAGES:
No provision of this code shall affect the recovery of damages in any other
cause of action where the liability of parent or legal guardian is predicated
on a common law basis. (Ord. 1145, 3-14-1978)
6-8-6: CIVIL PRACTICE ACT IN PROCEEDINGS UNDER SECTION 6-8-4:
The Illinois civil practice act, as the same may from time to time be amended
and modified, shall apply to all actions brought by and on behalf of the city
of Savanna under the provisions of section
6-8-4 of this chapter.
All damages assessed under the provisions of section
6-8-4 of this chapter shall be payable to the person or persons who have
suffered such actual damages. (Ord. 1145, 3-14-1978)
CHAPTER 9
FAIR HOUSING ORDINANCE
SECTION:
6-9-1: Statement Of Policy
6-9-2: Purpose And Scope
6-9-3: Jurisdiction
6-9-4: Interpretation
6-9-5: Construction Of Terms
6-9-6: Selected Definitions
6-9-7: Effect On Other Rights
6-9-8: Disclaimer Of Liability
6-9-1: STATEMENT OF POLICY:
   (A)   When certain individuals are treated differently in the housing market
because of racial, religious or other prejudices, the entire community suffers.
Discrimination frequently denies its immediate victims their right to acquire a
decent home in a safe and pleasant neighborhood. Discrimination also typically
causes neighborhoods to become highly segregated, and engenders instability on
the fringes of such areas. This instability seriously impairs any sense of
community responsibility and accelerates neighborhood decay. Neighborhood decay
reduces the housing supply and deflates the tax base. Concurrently, it
increases the need for government services and necessitates a higher tax rate.
   (B)   Although discrimination in housing is proscribed by the United States
and Illinois constitutions and by various federal laws, the problem is best
handled at the local level because: 1) there is no statewide enforcement
program, and 2) the federal enforcement machinery is disturbingly slow,
inadequate and sometimes simply unresponsive to local needs.
   (C)   In light of the above, the council hereby declares that it is the
public policy of this municipality to endeavor to ensure all persons an equal
opportunity to provide for themselves a home of their own choosing that is as
sufficient as their individual talents, industry and circumstances may permit.
(Ord. 1507, 8-23-1994)
6-9-2: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
The purpose of this chapter is to implement the policy set forth above by:
   (A)   Prohibiting discrimination based on race, color, creed, ancestry,
national origin or physical or mental handicap in the marketing, disposition
and financing of housing; and
   (B)   Establishing procedures for the fair and efficient administration and
enforcement of such regulations. (Ord. 1507, 8-23-1994)
6-9-3: JURISDICTION:
This chapter shall be applicable within the corporate limits of this
municipality. (Ord. 1507, 8-23-1994)
6-9-4: INTERPRETATION:
Every provision of this chapter shall be construed liberally to further the
policy and purpose of this chapter, and every requirement imposed herein shall
be deemed minimal. (Ord. 1507, 8-23-1994)
6-9-5: CONSTRUCTION OF TERMS:
In construing the intended meaning of terminology used in this chapter, the
following rules shall be observed:
   (A)   Words and phrases shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them
in section
6-9-6 of this chapter unless the context clearly indicates otherwise; terms not
defined in section
6-9-6 of this chapter shall have their standard English dictionary meanings.
   (B)   Words denoting the masculine gender shall be deemed to include the
feminine and neuter genders.
   (C)   Words used in the present tense shall include the future tense.
   (D)   Words used in the singular number shall include the plural number, and
the plural the singular.
   (E)   The term "shall" is mandatory; the term "may" is discretionary.
   (F)   The term "this municipality" shall mean the city of Savanna, Illinois.
   (G)   All time periods expressed in days shall be construed as calendar
days, not working days.
   (H)   Captions (i.e., titles of sections, subsections, etc.) are intended
merely to facilitate general reference, and in no way limit the substantive
application of the provisions set forth thereunder.
   (I)   References to sections shall be deemed to include all subsections
within that section; but a reference to a particular subsection designates only
that subsection.
   (J)   A general term that follows or is followed by enumerations of specific
terms shall not be limited to the enumerated class unless expressly limited.
(Ord. 1507, 8-23-1994)
6-9-6: SELECTED DEFINITIONS:
COMMISSION: The human relations commission of this municipality (or any other
agency designated by the council to administer this chapter).
DWELLING: Any building or portion thereof containing one or more dwelling
units, or any parcel of land offered for sale or lease for the construction or
placement of such building.
DWELLING UNIT: One or more rooms designed or used as living quarters by one
family.
FINANCIAL INSTITUTION: Any bank, savings and loan association, insurance
company, or any other person or firm whose business consists, in whole or in
part, of making or guaranteeing loans.
HOUSING: Synonym for "dwelling".
PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, organization or corporate body
acting in any capacity.
RENT: To lease, sublease, let or otherwise grant or receive for consideration
the right to occupy any dwelling not owned by the occupant. (Ord. 1507, 8-23-
1994)
6-9-7: EFFECT ON OTHER RIGHTS:
Nothing in this chapter shall prevent any person from exercising any right or
seeking any remedy to which he might otherwise be entitled. (Ord. 1507, 8-23-
1994)
6-9-8: DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY 1 :
   (A)   Except as may be provided otherwise by statute or ordinance, no
official, commission member, agent or employee of this municipality shall
render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or
property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his
duties under this chapter.
   (B)   Any suit brought against any official, commission member, agent or
employee of this municipality, as a result of any act required or permitted in
the discharge of his duties under this chapter, shall be defended by the
municipal attorney until the final determination of the legal proceedings.
(Ord. 1507, 8-23-1994)
