CHAPTER 10
PARK RULES
SECTION:
6-10-1: Regulating Use Of Parks
6-10-1: REGULATING USE OF PARKS:
   (A)   Adoption Of Park District Rules By Reference: The Savanna park
district board's park rules and regulations governing the use of parks and park
facilities are adopted as a part of this chapter. Any subsequent amendments or
revisions to the park district rules and regulations governing the use of parks
and park facilities shall automatically become a part of this code and shall be
made available for public inspection at city hall.
   (B)   Enforcement Of Park Rules And Regulations By The Savanna Police: The
Savanna police department is authorized to enforce the provisions of this
chapter.
   (C)   Penalties: Any person violating or disobeying any provision of this
section shall be fined a sum not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) in
accordance with section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 1720, 5-13-2003)
CHAPTER 11
SEIZED AND IMPOUNDED VEHICLES
SECTION:
6-11-1: Title
6-11-2: Purpose
6-11-3: Construction
6-11-4: Definitions
6-11-5: Vehicles To Be Seized And Impounded
6-11-6: Administrative Fee
6-11-7: Commencement Of Impoundment
6-11-8: Notice Of Seizure And Impoundment
6-11-9: Cash Bond
6-11-10: Admission Of Liability
6-11-11: Administrative Hearing
6-11-12: Defenses
6-11-13: Hearing Officer Fee
6-11-14: Administrative Review Law
6-11-15: Enforcement
6-11-16: Abandoned Vehicles
6-11-17: Severability
6-11-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known, cited and referred to as the VEHICLE IMPOUND
ORDINANCE OF SAVANNA. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to offset the costs incurred in the preparing,
prosecuting, hearing, and disposing of criminal and traffic cases, and recover
the costs associated with the towing, impounding, or seizing of motor vehicles
used during the commission of criminal, traffic, or other offenses within the
corporate limits of the city of Savanna. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-3: CONSTRUCTION:
The following shall apply in construction of this chapter:
   (A)   Words used in the present tense shall include the future tense; words
used in the singular number shall include the plural number; words used in the
masculine gender shall include the female gender; and such inclusive words
shall be reciprocal.
   (B)   The word "may" is permissive or discretionary.
   (C)   The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-
2015)
6-11-4: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meaning designated below, except when a particular context clearly requires
a different meaning:
CITY: The city of Savanna, Carroll County, Illinois.
LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: Every officer authorized to make arrests and issue
citations for criminal and traffic offenses occurring within the city.
LESSEE: The person authorized by a written lease agreement to possess the
vehicle and as properly registered with the Illinois secretary of state, or if
registered in a state other than Illinois, as properly registered with the
administrative agency responsible for registration in that state.
PERSON: An individual, firm, organization, public or private corporation,
government, partnership or unincorporated association.
REGISTERED OWNER: The record titleholder(s) of the vehicle as properly
registered with the Illinois secretary of state, or if registered in a state
other than Illinois, record titleholder as properly registered with the
administrative agency responsible for registration in that state. (Ord. 2127,
4-28-2015)
6-11-5: VEHICLES TO BE SEIZED AND IMPOUNDED:
Any vehicle, regardless of whether the registered owner or lessee is operating
said vehicle, within the corporate limits of the city, shall, under this
section, be subject to seizure and impoundment, any time the vehicle is used in
accordance with one or more of the following offenses:
   (A)   Operation or use of a vehicle in connection with the commission of any
felony offense; or
   (B)   Operation or use of a vehicle in connection with the commission of, or
in the attempt to commit, an offense for which a vehicle may be seized and
forfeited pursuant to section 36-1 of the Illinois criminal code of 1961, as
now enacted and as amended from time to time; or
   (C)   Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an
intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof, in violation of
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501, as now enacted and as amended from
time to time (unless the law enforcement officer, in his discretion, determines
that said vehicle may be released to a sober passenger or co-owner); or
   (D)   Operation or use of a vehicle in connection with the commission of, or
in the attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of the Illinois cannabis
control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550 et seq., as now enacted and as
amended from time to time; or
   (E)   Operation or use of a vehicle in connection with the commission of, or
in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of the Illinois controlled
substances act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570 et seq., as now enacted and
as amended from time to time; or
   (F)   Operation or use of a vehicle in connection with the commission of, or
in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of section 24-1, 24-1.5, or
24-3.1 of the Illinois criminal code of 1961, as now enacted and as amended
from time to time; or
   (G)   Driving while a driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a
vehicle is suspended or revoked pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-
303, as now enacted and as amended from time to time; except that vehicles
shall not be subjected to seizure or impoundment if the suspension is for an
unpaid citation (parking or moving); or
   (H)   Operation or use of a vehicle in connection with soliciting,
possessing, or attempting to solicit or possess cannabis or a controlled
substance, as defined by the Illinois cannabis control act or the Illinois
controlled substances act, as now enacted and as amended from time to time; or
   (I)   Operation or use of a vehicle by a person against whom a valid warrant
is outstanding for which the city of Savanna is within geographical limits; or
   (J)   Operation or use of a vehicle in connection with the commission of, or
in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of article 16 of the Illinois
criminal code of 1961, as now enacted and as amended from time to time; or
   (K)   Operation or use of a vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt
to commit, the offense of fleeing to elude a police officer, in violation of
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-204.1, as now enacted and as amended from
time to time; or
   (L)   Any other offense now codified or subsequently enacted, that directs
or authorizes a law enforcement officer to seize, impound, or tow the vehicle
in question. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-6: ADMINISTRATIVE FEE:
An administrative fee in the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00) shall be
imposed on the registered owner or lessee of any vehicle impounded under this
chapter.
   (A)   Said fee is an established fixed amount for the actual administrative
costs incurred by the city agencies as the result of towing and impounding of
vehicles, and the preparing, prosecuting, hearing and disposing of criminal or
traffic cases involving the use of vehicles.
   (B)   The administrative fee shall be in addition to: 1) any other penalties
that may be assessed by a court of law for the underlying violations; 2) any
towing or storage fees, or both, charged by the towing company; and 3) any
hearing officer fee imposed under this chapter.
   (C)   If there exists more than one registered owner or lessee of the
vehicle in question, each registered owner or lessee shall be jointly and
severally liable to the city for the administrative fee.
   (D)   Any funds collected under this chapter as an administrative fee shall
be deposited to and become a part of the general fund of the city of Savanna to
be used at the recommendation of the chief of police, or his designee, subject
to approval of the city council without need for appropriation, for law
enforcement related activities including, but not limited to, the purchase or
maintenance of police vehicles, equipment or training. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-7: COMMENCEMENT OF IMPOUNDMENT:
Whenever a law enforcement officer has probable cause to believe that a vehicle
is subject to impoundment, under this chapter, the officer shall provide for
the towing of the vehicle to a facility authorized by the city. Said vehicle
shall be impounded and held until such time as the administrative fee is paid
or the vehicle is subject to release under the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-8: NOTICE OF SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT:
Upon seizure and impoundment, the law enforcement officer shall provide notice
as directed under this section:
   (A)   Initial Notice: At the time the vehicle is towed, the officer shall
notify, or make a reasonable attempt to notify, the registered owner, lessee or
person identifying himself or herself as the owner or lessee of the vehicle, or
any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the
alleged offense, of the fact of the seizure, and of the registered owner's or
lessee's right to an administrative hearing.
      1.   Any notice under this section shall be in writing, and said notice
shall indicate that the vehicle will remain impounded pending the completion of
an administrative hearing, unless the registered owner, lessee, or a lienholder
of record posts with the chief of police, or his designee, a bond equal to the
administrative fee and hearing officer fee, as provided by ordinance, and pays
for all towing and storage charges.
      2.   Said notice shall inform the recipient of the right to an
administrative hearing, and shall provide instructions on the exercise of that
right.
   (B)   Owner Or Lessee Is Passenger Or Driver: If a registered owner or
lessee is found to be a passenger or driver of any vehicle seized under this
chapter, then he or she shall be personally served with written notice under
this section.
   (C)   Owner Or Lessee Is Not Passenger Or Driver: If no registered owner or
lessee is found to be a passenger or driver of any vehicle seized under this
chapter, then the written notice shall be served on the registered owner or
lessee, either by personal service or by first class mail, postage prepaid, to
the address as registered with the secretary of state.
      1.   All notices shall be served upon the registered owner or lessee
within five (5) days after a vehicle is seized and impounded; and
      2.   Said notice shall indicate that the vehicle will remain impounded
pending the completion of an administrative hearing, unless the registered
owner, lessee, or a lienholder of record posts with the chief of police, or his
designee, a bond equal to the administrative fee and hearing officer fee as
provided by ordinance, and pays for all towing and storage charges. (Ord. 2127,
4-28-2015)
6-11-9: CASH BOND:
The registered owner, lessee, or a lienholder of record of any vehicle seized
pursuant to this chapter may retrieve the vehicle seized prior to the
evidentiary hearing by posting a cash bond at the Savanna police department, in
addition to the payment of applicable towing and storage fees.
   (A)   The bond shall be an amount totaling the administrative fee and
hearing officer fee established in this chapter.
   (B)   Upon posting of bond, the vehicle shall be released to the registered
owner, lessee, or the lienholder of record who posted said bond.
   (C)   Any bond posted under this section shall be retained by the Savanna
chief of police, or his designee, until the disposition of the administrative
hearing held under this chapter. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-10: ADMISSION OF LIABILITY:
The registered owner or lessee of any vehicle seized pursuant to this chapter
may retrieve the vehicle seized prior to the evidentiary hearing by admitting
liability to the city for the administrative fee, and, in addition to the
payment of applicable towing and storage fees, remits the full amount of the
administrative fee established in this chapter. Said admission of liability
shall be deemed a waiver of the administrative hearing, and upon the entry of
an admission of liability, any administrative hearing scheduled shall be waived
and canceled. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-11: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
Subject to the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3, and in
a manner consistent with other statutes or ordinances regulating administrative
hearings, a registered owner or lessee may request an administrative hearing to
review the imposition of the administrative fee under this chapter.
   (A)   Request For Hearing: A registered owner or lessee of any vehicle
seized pursuant to this chapter may request a hearing within ten (10) business
days of the date of seizure and impoundment or by the service of the notice of
seizure and impoundment, whichever is later.
      1.   All requests for hearing shall be in writing and must include the
following:
         (a)   The name and mailing address of the registered owner or lessee
making the request for hearing;
         (b)   The name and mailing address of any registered owner or lessee
having an interest in the seized vehicle;
         (c)   The make, model and registration number of the vehicle seized;
         (d)   The date and location of the seizure;
         (e)   The identity of the driver who was operating or in control of
the vehicle at the time of the seizure; and
         (f)   All requests for hearing must be delivered to the Savanna police
department by personal service.
   (B)   Waiver Of Hearing: Unless the registered owner or lessee properly
delivers a request for hearing within the time allowed under this chapter, said
hearing shall be deemed waived, and any right to an administrative hearing
shall be forfeited.
   (C)   Notice Of Administrative Hearing: Upon receiving a request for
hearing, the chief of police, or his designee, shall provide written notice
that the vehicle shall remain impounded pending the completion of an
administrative hearing, unless the registered owner, lessee, or a lienholder of
record posts with the chief of police, or his designee, a bond equal to the
administrative fee and hearing officer fee, as provided by ordinance, and pays
for all towing and storage charges.
      1.   This written notice shall be served upon the registered owner,
lessee, and any lienholder of record;
      2.   The written notice shall be served either by personal service or by
first class mail, postage prepaid, to the address as registered with the
secretary of state;
      3.   All notices shall be served upon the registered owner, lessee, and
any lienholder of record within five (5) business days after the request for
hearing is received; and
      4.   The written notice shall contain the date, time and location of the
administrative hearing. An initial hearing shall be scheduled not less than
seven (7) days and no more than forty five (45) days after the date of the
mailing of the notice of hearing.
   (D)   Administrative Hearing Officer: The administrative hearing shall be
conducted by a hearing officer designated by the city, who is an attorney
licensed to practice law in this state for a minimum of three (3) years.
   (E)   Responsibility For Costs: The party challenging the imposition of the
administrative fee shall be responsible for the costs associated with use of
the administrative hearing officer, as described in this chapter.
   (F)   Appearance At Hearing: The party challenging the hearing must appear
personally or through a licensed attorney at law. A failure of the challenging
party to appear shall result in a default ruling sustaining the vehicle
impoundment.
   (G)   Opportunity To Be Heard: All interested persons shall be given a
reasonable opportunity to be heard at the hearing.
   (H)   Formal Rules Not Applicable: The formal rules of evidence shall not
apply and hearsay evidence shall be admissible.
   (I)   Burden Of Proof: The burden shall be on the party challenging the
administrative fee to prove one of the available defenses by a preponderance of
the evidence.
   (J)   Written Decision: At the conclusion of the administrative hearing, the
hearing officer shall issue a written decision either sustaining or overruling
the vehicle impoundment.
   (K)   Impoundment Sustained: If the basis for the vehicle impoundment is
sustained by the administrative hearing officer, any administrative fee,
hearing officer fee, or bond posted to secure the release of the vehicle shall
be forfeited to the city.
   (L)   Fees And Charges Paid Before Release Of Vehicle: Unless the
administrative hearing officer overturns the basis for the vehicle impoundment,
no vehicle shall be released to the registered owner, lessee, or lienholder of
record until all administrative fees, hearing officer fees, and towing and
storage charges are paid.
   (M)   Impoundment Overturned: If the administrative hearing officer
overturns the basis for the vehicle impound, the vehicle shall be released to
the registered owner, lessee, or lienholder of record challenging such fee,
provided all towing and storage charges are paid. The administrative hearing
officer shall not have the authority to waive towing and storage charges. (Ord.
2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-12: DEFENSES:
At any hearing reviewing the imposition of the administrative fee, the
administrative hearing officer shall only consider defenses recognized by this
section:
   (A)   There shall only be three (3) recognized defenses to the imposition of
the administrative fee:
      1.   The vehicle was stolen at the time the illegal item was found in the
vehicle, and the theft was reported within twenty four (24) hours after the
theft was discovered or reasonably should have been discovered;
      2.   The vehicle was operating as a common carrier and the violation
occurred without the knowledge of the person in control of the vehicle;
      3.   The vehicle was not used in connection with an offense described in
this chapter.
   (B)   Notwithstanding the limitations set forth in subsection (A) of this
section, the following circumstances shall not constitute a defense to the
imposition of the administrative fee:
      1.   The registered owner, lessee, or lienholder of record was not the
driver of the vehicle during the commission of the offense in question;
      2.   Any criminal charge related to the incident giving rise to the
impoundment has been adjudicated not guilty;
      3.   Any criminal charge related to the incident giving rise to the
impoundment has been dismissed or otherwise disposed of; or
      4.   Any other circumstances not specified in subsection (A) of this
section. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-13: HEARING OFFICER FEE:
The party challenging the imposition of the administrative fee shall be
responsible for the costs associated with use of the administrative hearing
officer. Said fee shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), and shall be
used to pay for the costs associated with the use of the administrative hearing
officer, subject to the following:
   (A)   If the party challenging the imposition of the administrative fee
posts bond under this chapter, the hearing officer fee must be included in said
bond.
   (B)   If the registered owner or lessee of any vehicle seized pursuant to
this chapter admits liability as provided in this chapter, provided said
admission occurs more than forty eight (48) hours prior to the scheduled
administrative hearing, no hearing officer fee shall be assessed. A failure to
admit liability and waive the administrative hearing in a timely manner will
result in the imposition of the hearing officer fee on the registered owner or
lessee of the vehicle in question.
   (C)   If no admission of liability or waiver of administrative hearing is
received prior to the deadline described in subsection (B) of this section, the
hearing officer fee shall be imposed on the registered owner or lessee of the
vehicle in question.
   (D)   If the administrative hearing officer overturns the basis for the
vehicle impound, no hearing officer fee shall be assessed, and any previously
posted hearing officer fee shall be refunded.
   (E)   Every registered owner or lessee of the subject vehicle shall be
jointly and severally liable to the city for any hearing officer fee imposed
under this chapter. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-14: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW LAW:
All administrative hearing rulings shall be subject to review under the
provisions of the administrative review law, as codified as 735 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-15: ENFORCEMENT:
Unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, any administrative fee
imposed under this chapter, which remains unpaid in whole or in part after the
expiration of the deadline for seeking judicial review under the administrative
review law, may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court
of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
6-11-16: ABANDONED VEHICLES:
Vehicles not retrieved from the towing facility or storage facility within
sixty (60) days after the administrative hearing officer issues a written
decision shall be deemed abandoned and disposed of in accordance with the
provisions of article II of chapter 4 of the Illinois vehicle code. (Ord. 2127,
4-28-2015)
6-11-17: SEVERABILITY:
If any provisions in this chapter or the application thereof is held to be
unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction,
such ruling shall not affect any other provisions of this chapter not
specifically included in such ruling or which can be given effect without the
unconstitutional or invalid provision or application; and to this end, the
provisions of this chapter are declared severable. (Ord. 2127, 4-28-2015)
CHAPTER 12
CANNABIS AND DRUG PARAPHERNALIA
SECTION:
6-12-1: Possession Of Cannabis
6-12-2: Possession Of Drug Paraphernalia
6-12-1: POSSESSION OF CANNABIS:
   (A)   Definitions: All terms and phrases used in this section shall have the
same meaning as ascribed to them in the Cannabis Control Act 1 , as amended.
   (B)   Possession Defined: A person commits the offenses of possession of
cannabis by knowingly possessing ten grams (10 g) or less of any substance
containing cannabis unless permitted or authorized to do so pursuant to the
Cannabis Control Act 2 .
   (C)   Penalty: Any person violating this section shall be subject to a
mandatory fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus
administrative costs, or more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), plus
administrative costs, per offense. (Ord. 2195, 3-28-2017, eff. 3-28-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.
2 2. 720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.
6-12-2: POSSESSION OF DRUG PARAPHERNALIA:
   (A)   Definitions: All terms and phrases used herein shall have the same
meaning as ascribed to them in the Drug Paraphernalia Control Act 1 , as
amended.
   (B)   Violation: It shall be a violation of this section for any person to
knowingly possess an item of drug paraphernalia which is intended to be used
unlawfully in planning, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting,
manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing,
testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing,
injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body
cannabis or a controlled substance in violation of the Cannabis Control Act,
the Illinois Controlled Substances Act, or the Methamphetamine Control and
Community Protection Act, or a synthetic drug product or misbranded drug in
violation of the Illinois Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.
   (C)   Penalty: Any person violating this section shall be subject to a
mandatory fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus
administrative costs, or more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), plus
administrative costs, per offense. (Ord. 2195, 3-28-2017, eff. 3-28-2017)
 
Notes
1 3. 720 ILCS 600/1 et seq.
TITLE 7
HEALTH AND SANITATION
CHAPTER 1
NUISANCES
SECTION:
7-1-0: Nuisances Prohibited
7-1-1: Nuisances Declared
7-1-2: Public Nuisance Defined
7-1-3: Public Nuisances Affecting Health
7-1-4: Public Nuisances Affecting Peace And Safety
7-1-5: Abatement By City
7-1-6: Abandoned Motor Vehicles (Rep. by Ord. 1994, 2-14-2012)
7-1-7: Control And Extermination Of Rats
7-1-8: Inoperable Motor Vehicles (Rep. by Ord. 1993, 2-14-2012)
7-1-9: Graffiti; Definitions
7-1-10: Graffiti; Prohibited Conduct
7-1-11: Graffiti; Abatement
7-1-12: Penalty
7-1-0: NUISANCES PROHIBITED:
No person shall possess, erect, contrive, cause, continue, maintain or permit
to exist any public nuisance within the city. (Ord. 1962, 3-8-2011)
7-1-1: NUISANCES DECLARED:
Any thing, condition or activity which endangers health, or offends the senses,
or obstructs or interferes with free use and comfortable enjoyment of life or
property and the following acts or omissions thereof are hereby declared to be
nuisances and the creation or maintenance of same anywhere within the city is
hereby prohibited. (Ord. 1962, 3-8-2011)
7-1-2: PUBLIC NUISANCE DEFINED:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
PUBLIC NUISANCE: A thing, act, occupation, condition or use of property which
shall continue for such length of time as to:
(A) Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the comfort, health or safety of
the public;
(B) In any way render the public insecure in life or in the use of property;
(C) Greatly offend the public morals or decency; or
(D) Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or tend to obstruct
or render dangerous for passage any street, alley, highway, navigable body of
water or other public way. (Ord. 1962, 3-8-2011)
7-1-3: PUBLIC NUISANCES AFFECTING HEALTH:
The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are hereby
specifically declared to be public health nuisances, but shall not be construed
to exclude other health nuisances coming within the definition of "public
nuisance" above:
   (A)   All decayed, harmfully adulterated or unwholesome food or drink sold
or offered for sale to the public;
   (B)   Carcasses of animals, birds or fowl not buried or otherwise disposed
of in a sanitary manner within twenty four (24) hours after death;
   (C)   Accumulations of decayed animal or vegetable matter, trash, rubbish,
rotting lumber, bedding, packing material, abandoned vehicles or machinery,
scrap metal or any material in which flies, mosquitoes, disease carrying
insects, rats or other vermin may breed or which create a fire hazard;
   (D)   All stagnant water in which mosquitoes, flies or other insects can
multiply;
   (E)   Garbage cans which are not flytight;
   (F)   The escape of smoke, soot, cinders, noxious acids, fumes, gases, fly
ash or industrial dust within the city limits in quantities as to endanger the
health of persons of ordinary sensibilities or any act in violation of the
Illinois environmental protection act;
   (G)   The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, river or body of
water by sewage or industrial wastes or other substances or any act in
violation of the environmental protection act;
   (H)   Any use of property, substances or things within the city emitting or
causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous, noxious or disagreeable odors,
effluvia or stenches extremely repulsive to the physical senses of ordinary
persons which annoy, discomfort, injure or inconvenience the health of any
appreciable number of persons within the city;
   (I)   All abandoned wells not securely covered or secured from public use;
(Ord. 1962, 3-8-2011)
   (J)   (Rep. by Ord. 2000, 3-13-2012)
   (K)   Any obstruction in or across any watercourse, drainage ditch or
ravine;
   (L)   The deposit of garbage, rubbish or any offensive substance on any
street, sidewalk or public place or on any private property, except as may be
permitted by ordinance;
   (M)   Any noxious weeds on private property, as defined by Illinois Compiled
Statutes chapter 505, act 100, section 2 and as further set forth in section
7-2-1 of this title; and/or
   (N)   Any and all unattended clothing donation containers on private or
public property anywhere in the city. (Ord. 1962, 3-8-2011)
7-1-4: PUBLIC NUISANCES AFFECTING PEACE AND SAFETY:
The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are hereby
declared to be public nuisances affecting peace and safety, but the
enumerations shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances affecting public
peace or safety coming within the provisions of the definition of "public
nuisance" above:
   (A)   All buildings erected, repaired or altered in violation of the
provisions of the ordinances of the city relating to materials and manner of
construction of buildings and structures;
   (B)   All trees, hedges, billboards or other obstructions which prevent
persons driving vehicles on public streets, alleys or highways from obtaining a
clear view of traffic when approaching an intersection or pedestrian crosswalk;
   (C)   All limbs of trees which project over a public sidewalk less than
eight feet (8') above the surface thereof or less than ten feet (10') above the
surface of a public street;
   (D)   All use or display of fireworks, except as provided by the laws of the
state, except the city council may grant a permit for public display of
fireworks under the conditions as it may impose;
   (E)   All buildings or structures so old, dilapidated or out of repair as to
be dangerous, unsafe, unsanitary or otherwise unfit for human use;
   (F)   All wires over streets, alleys or public grounds which are strung less
than fifteen feet (15') above the surface of the street or ground;
   (G)   All obstructions of streets, alleys, sidewalks or crosswalks and all
excavations in or under the same, except as permitted by the ordinances of the
city or which, although made in accordance with the ordinances, are kept or
maintained for an unreasonable length of time after the purpose thereof has
been accomplished;
   (H)   All open and unguarded pits, wells, excavations or unused basements
freely accessible from any public street, alley or sidewalk;
   (I)   All abandoned refrigerators or iceboxes from which the doors and other
covers have not been removed or which are not equipped with a device for
opening from the inside by pushing only with the strength of a small child;
   (J)   Any unauthorized or unlawful use of property abutting on a public
street, alley or sidewalk or of a public street, alley or sidewalk which causes
large crowds of people to gather, obstructing traffic and free use of the
streets or sidewalks;
   (K)   Any advertisements or signs affixed to any building, wall, fence,
sidewalk, street or other private or public property without permission of the
owner thereof;
   (L)   Any sign, marquee or awning which is in an unsafe condition or which
overhangs any roadway or which overhangs any sidewalk less than eight feet (8')
above the sidewalk surface;
   (M)   Any structure, material or condition which constitutes a fire hazard
or will impair the extinguishing of any fire;
   (N)   Any inscription, design, writing or drawing sprayed, painted or
otherwise placed onto property, either public or private, with the intent, or
having a tendency, to deface or mar the property; and
   (O)   Any nuisance so defined by the Illinois Compiled Statutes. (Ord. 1962,
3-8-2011)
7-1-5: ABATEMENT BY CITY:
If the nuisance is not abated within the time provided, or if the owner,
occupant or person causing the nuisance cannot be found, the director of public
works or some other city official whom the mayor shall designate shall cause
the abatement or removal of the public nuisance.
   (A)   If the inspecting officer shall determine that a public nuisance
exists on private premises, but that the nature of the nuisance is not such as
to threaten great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, peace,
morals or decency, he or she shall file a written report of his or her findings
with the mayor, who shall cause an action to abate the nuisance to be commenced
in the name of the city. (Ord. 1962, 3-8-2011)
7-1-6: ABANDONED MOTOR VEHICLES:
(Rep. by Ord. 1994, 2-14-2012)
7-1-7: CONTROL AND EXTERMINATION OF RATS:
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
    RAT: Animals of the rodent family which are known to be dangerous to the
health and safety of the community.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or permit the
existence of rats anywhere within the city and it shall be unlawful for the
owner, occupant or person in custody of any real property and any buildings
therein to permit the same to become occupied by rats.
   (C)   1. Whenever the building inspector or public works director shall be
of the opinion that any real property or any building or structure therein is
infested and occupied by rats, he or she shall file a written statement to this
effect with the city clerk. The clerk thereupon shall cause written notice to
be served upon the owner, occupant or person in custody of the real property or
structure by registered mail or by personal service.
      2.   The notice shall state that the real property or building has been
declared to be a hazard to the health and safety of the residents of the city
because of the occupancy of the premises by rats and that the rats must be
exterminated and that the extermination must be done at once.
   (D)   1. If the person receiving notice has not complied therewith or taken
appeal from the determination of the officer or employee finding the existence
of rats therein within ten (10) days from service of notice by personal service
or registered mail, the building inspector or public works director may proceed
to arrange for the extermination of rats.
      2.   The costs and expenses of rat extermination shall be billed to the
owner, occupant or person in custody of the premises and, if not paid within
sixty (60) days, a lien shall be filed against property.
   (E)   1. Any person violating any provisions of this section or permitting
rats to remain on its premises, after receiving due notice thereof mentioned
aforesaid, shall be subject to the penalty provided for violation of this code.
      2.   The penalty may be in addition to paying the cost of rat
extermination. (Ord. 1962, 3-8-2011)
7-1-8: INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES:
(Rep. by Ord. 1993, 2-14-2012)
7-1-9: GRAFFITI; DEFINITIONS:
   (A)   Definitions: For the purpose of sections
7-1-10 and
7-1-11 of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
    GRAFFITI: Any inscription, design, writing or drawing sprayed, painted or
otherwise placed onto property with intent, or having a tendency, to deface or
mar the property.
   MINOR: Any person under the age of eighteen (18) years. (Ord. 1963, 3-8-
2011)
7-1-10: GRAFFITI; PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
   (A)   No person shall sell or otherwise transfer any spray paint to a minor
unless said minor is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian at the time of
purchase or transfer.
   (B)   No minor shall, at the time of purchase of any spray paint container,
furnish fraudulent evidence of majority.
   (C)   No minor shall, except while accompanied by a parent or legal
guardian, possess a spray paint container on any public property or any private
property except with the express permission of the lawful owner or manager of
said private property.
   (D)   Absent express permission to the contrary by the owner or other person
having control thereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to possess a spray
paint container, liquid paint in cans or other containers in any public
building, or upon any public facility or private property with intent to use
the same to deface the building, facility or property.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any person to deface or mar public or private
property through graffiti. (Ord. 1963, 3-8-2011)
7-1-11: GRAFFITI; ABATEMENT:
   (A)   The owner of all houses, buildings, and property situated within the
city are required at their expense to remove graffiti from their property
within seven (7) days of notice and order issued by the police chief. The
notice shall contain:
      1.   The street address and any additional description sufficient to
adequately identify the location of the property upon which graffiti is sought
to be removed; and
      2.   An order requiring that the graffiti be removed within seven (7)
days upon receipt of the order.
   (B)   The notice and order shall be served upon the record owner of the
affected property either by personal service or by mailing a copy of such
notice and order by certified mail, postage prepaid, return receipt required.
(Ord. 1963, 3-8-2011)
7-1-12: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, or corporation violating this chapter shall be fined not less
than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00), for each offense. Each day there is a violation constitutes a
separate offense. Violations of this chapter are hereby declared to be a public
nuisance and shall be abated in the manner provided by law. (Ord. 2040, 5-28-
2013)
CHAPTER 2
NOXIOUS WEEDS
SECTION:
7-2-1: Nuisance Declared
7-2-2: Height Limit
7-2-3: Notice To Abate
7-2-4: Failure To Abate
7-2-5: Charges; Lien; Special Assessment
7-2-6: Foreclosure Of Lien
7-2-7: Penalty
7-2-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
Any weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur, or other weeds
of a like kind found growing in any lot or tract of land in the city are hereby
declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such weeds to
grow or remain in any such place. (Ord. 1418, 8-27-1991)
7-2-2: HEIGHT LIMIT:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to permit any weeds, grass or plants, other
than trees, bushes, flowers, or other ornamental plants, to grow to a height
exceeding eight inches (8") anywhere in the city. Any such plants or weeds
exceeding such height are hereby declared to be a nuisance. (Ord. 1875, 6-26-
2007)
7-2-3: NOTICE TO ABATE:
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to serve or cause to be served a
notice upon the owner or occupant of any premises on which weeds or plants are
permitted to grow in violation of the provisions of this chapter and to demand
the abatement of the nuisance within five (5) days. (Ord. 1418, 8-27-1991)
7-2-4: FAILURE TO ABATE:
If the person so served does not abate the nuisance within five (5) days, the
city may proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an account of the expense of
the abatement, and such expense shall be charged and paid by such owner or
occupant. (Ord. 1418, 8-27-1991)
7-2-5: CHARGES; LIEN; SPECIAL ASSESSMENT:
   (A)   Charges To Be A Lien: Charges for such weed removal shall be a lien
upon the premises. Whenever a bill for such charges remains unpaid for sixty
(60) days after it has been rendered, the clerk may file with the recorder of
deeds of Carroll County a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain
a legal description of the premises, the expenses and costs incurred and the
date the weeds were cut, and a notice that the city claims a lien for this
amount.
   (B)   Notice: Notice of such lien claim shall be mailed to the owner of the
premises if his address is known. Provided, however, that failure of the clerk
to record such lien claim or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to
receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for such
charges as provided in the following section.
   (C)   Treatment As A Special Assessment: In addition to the other methods
prescribed by this section for collection of said charges, and provided that a
lien has been filed of record by the city of Savanna in the office of the
recorder of deeds, then the unpaid costs may be collected as a special
assessment on the property. Upon payment of the costs by the owner of record or
persons interested in the property, the lien shall be released by the
municipality and the release shall be filed or recorded in the same manner as
the filing of notice of lien. (Ord. 1788, 3-8-2005)
7-2-6: FORECLOSURE OF LIEN:
   (A)   Property subject to a lien for unpaid weed cutting charges shall be
sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied
to pay the charges after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of
statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be in equity in the name of the city.
   (B)   The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such
proceedings, in the name of the city, in any court having jurisdiction over
such matter, against any property for which such bill has remained unpaid sixty
(60) days after it has been rendered. (Ord. 1418, 8-27-1991)
7-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating this chapter shall be fined a sum of one hundred dollars
($100.00) for a first offense occurring in a calendar year and a separate
offense may be deemed committed for each and every day during which a violation
continues or exists.
Any person committing a second offense on the same property within the same
calendar year will be fined a sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and a
separate offense may be deemed committed for each and every day during which a
violation continues or exists.
Any person committing a third or subsequent offense on the same property within
the same calendar year will be fined a sum of three hundred fifty dollars
($350.00) and a separate offense may be deemed committed for each and every day
during which a violation continues or exists. (Ord. 2174, 8-23-2016)
CHAPTER 3
GARBAGE AND RECYCLING COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
SECTION:
7-3-1: Definitions
7-3-2: Residential Collection Services
7-3-3: Residential Garbage Services
7-3-4: Curbside Recycling Service
7-3-5: Christmas Tree Program
7-3-6: Private Garbage Disposal
7-3-7: Compliance
7-3-8: Supervision Of Garbage And Recycling Collection And Disposal
7-3-9: Charges, Authorization; Computation
7-3-10: Bills; Nonpayment Of Bills, Penalty Waiver, Reinstatement Fee
7-3-11: Collection Fees
7-3-12: Solid Waste Transfer Station Fees
7-3-13: Special Privileges
7-3-14: Transporting Solid Waste Over Streets
7-3-15: Deposits Prohibited
7-3-16: Exceptions
7-3-17: Penalty
7-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this chapter:
BULKY WASTE: Rubbish such as stoves, refrigerators, water heaters, washing
machines, "white goods", furniture and other waste materials other than
construction debris, dead animals, hazardous waste, automobile parts, or stable
matter with weights or volumes greater than those allowed for approved
containers.
COLLECTION UNIT: A dwelling unit, or small commercial uses that wish to
participate in residential collection services for garbage, recyclables, and
landscape waste for a determined fee.
CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS: Waste building materials resulting from construction,
remodeling, repair or demolition operations.
CONTRACTOR: The person/company who is currently under contract with the city
for residential collection services.
DWELLING UNIT: One or more rooms which are arranged, designed, or used as
living quarters for one family unit only. Individual bathroom and complete
single kitchen facilities, permanently installed to serve the entire family,
shall always be included within each "dwelling unit".
FAMILY UNIT: One or more persons occupying premises and living as a single
residential dwelling unit, whether or not related to each other by birth,
adoption or marriage, but no unrelated group shall consist of more than four
(4) persons, as distinguished from a group occupying a duly licensed lodging
house.
GARBAGE: Wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and
consumption of food; wastes from the handling, storage and sale of produce;
ashes from fires used for cooking and for heating buildings. Waste generated in
the normal operation of a household. Not including "bulky waste" or
"construction debris".
GARBAGE CONTAINER: A trash can of standard waterproof construction of durable
metal or plastic material, with a tightfitting cover and with handles suitable
for lifting by one person, or plastic garbage bags. Except as hereinafter
provided, such trash cans and/or plastic garbage bags shall have a capacity of
not less than ten (10) gallons or more than thirty three (33) gallons, and a
full weight of not more than forty (40) pounds.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: Waste, in any amount, which is defined, characterized or
designated as hazardous by the United States environmental protection agency or
appropriate state agency by or pursuant to federal or state law, or waste, in
any amount which is regulated under federal or state law. The term hazardous
waste shall include, but not be limited to, oil of any kind, paint, unless lid
is removed so that paint is dry, lead paint, batteries, tires, chemicals of any
kind, and any other material that would constitute hazardous material as
defined in Illinois or federal statutes.
LANDSCAPE WASTE: Compostable organic material consisting of dead plants, weeds,
tree or hedge trimmings, grass clippings, and leaves, but excluding tree limbs
greater than two inches (2") in diameter and longer than four feet (4') in
length.
LODGING HOUSE: A building originally designed for and used as a single- or two-
family dwelling, all or a portion of which contains rooms which accommodate
persons who are not members of the keeper's family. Lodging or meals, or both,
may be provided for compensation for five (5) or more persons, but not more
than ten (10) persons. Rooming houses containing lodging spaces for more than
ten (10) persons shall be considered commercial units.
RECYCLABLE ITEMS: Shall include newsprint, magazines, catalogs, phone books,
softcover books, hardcover books with covers removed, file folders, envelopes,
junk mail, fliers, brochures, food boxes and cartons, wet strength beverage
packaging, cardboard boxes. All types of food and beverage containers such as
glass and plastic jars and bottles, tin and aluminum cans, aluminum foil
products, pie and cake tins.
RECYCLING: The use (collection, remanufacturing, etc.) of secondary materials
as feedstock for the production of new materials or products.
RECYCLING CONTAINER: An eighteen (18) gallon plastic container stamped with the
city approved logo, or other containers not exceeding thirty three (33) gallons
in capacity that are clearly marked for recycling.
REFUSE: Shall have the same meaning as "garbage".
RESIDENT: All persons whose residence is within the corporate limits of the
city.
RESIDENTIAL COLLECTION SERVICES: Services provided to residents for the
collection of garbage, recyclables and landscape waste for a determined fee.
Collection services will not be provided for multi-family residential dwellings
with more than five (5) dwelling units.
ROOMING HOUSE: Shall have the same meaning as "lodging house".
SOLID WASTE: Shall have the same meaning as "garbage". (Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-2: RESIDENTIAL COLLECTION SERVICES:
   (A)   Established: There is hereby created and established residential
collection services to be paid for, kept and maintained by the city through a
special tax levy not to exceed statutory limits and residential collection
service fees to be determined by the city council and contractor.
   (B)   Bids: Every four (4) years the city council shall advertise for bids
for residential collection services unless the city and the current contractor
choose to extend the contract an additional four (4) years by mutual agreement.
There shall be no limit to the number of times a contract can be extended.
   (C)   Contract: Garbage and recycling collection and disposal contract shall
be for a four (4) year period, commencing May 1 and ending April 30. Contract
shall be executed with the lowest responsible responsive bidder for residential
collection services. The contract shall set forth the terms and conditions
relative thereto, as well as residential collection service fees. The contract
shall be approved by the mayor and city council and shall be executed by the
mayor and city clerk under the corporate seal of the city. The person with whom
any such collection contract may be made shall be known as the collector.
At the expiration of said four (4) year term, the contract shall be considered
to be automatically renewed for an additional four (4) year renewal term,
unless either party shall notify the other party by registered mail, return
receipt requested, not less than sixty (60) days prior to the expiration of the
then term of the contract, notifying the other party that the party giving said
notice does not desire to renew this contract for said additional term.
   (D)   Bond: The collector shall execute and deliver to the city an official
bond in a reasonable amount to be set by the city council with sureties to be
approved by the mayor and city council. The bond shall be conditional upon the
faithful execution and performance of the contract. The bond shall be deposited
with the city comptroller.
   (E)   Commercial Collection Services: Small business and office uses may
participate in the residential collection services. However, multi-family
dwellings with more than five (5) units, as well as large business and
industrial establishments shall be required to make private arrangements for
collection and disposal of all solid waste and recyclables in a prompt and
sanitary manner.
   (F)   Residential Collection Service Accounts: Residential collection
service accounts shall be in the name of the owner of the property serviced,
and only such owner shall be recognized as the consumer, except as noted
hereinafter. The owner of the respective premises serviced shall be held
responsible for the payment of all solid waste service charges and all other
proper charges in connection with the residential collection services to said
respective premises, but such payments will be accepted from the tenant or
tenants of said respective premises if rendered by them, but the acceptance of
such payments from said tenant or tenants, shall not relieve the owner from the
responsibility of and for the payment of residential collection service fees or
service charges not paid when due.
Residential collection service accounts may be established in the name of a
tenant only after the owner has been advised of his responsibility for payment
and only after the owner has affixed his signature on an affidavit form
supplied by the city. A copy of said signed affidavit shall be provided to the
property owner.
   (G)   Termination Of Residential Collection Services: Whenever a collection
unit's water and sewer services are discontinued, it shall automatically cause
the discontinuance of residential collection services. The customer will be
billed for services rendered on a monthly basis. Services rendered for any
portion of a month shall be considered a full month's service.
Whenever a collection unit is to be vacated or closed for a period of time
exceeding thirty (30) days and the water and sewer services remain active,
application in writing shall be made at the business office on forms supplied
by the city to discontinue residential collection services, conditioned as
follows:
      1.   The owner of said collection unit shall, on an affidavit form
supplied by the city, agree to notify the city whenever the collection unit is
occupied.
      2.   The owner of said collection unit shall also agree, on said
affidavit form supplied by the city, to provide the date on which services are
to be discontinued and the estimated date to reestablish services. The date to
reestablish service may be amended in writing by the owner.
Once all conditions are met and the affidavit is signed, the services will be
discontinued. The customer will be billed for the services rendered on a
monthly basis. Services rendered for any portion of a month shall be considered
a full month's service. If it is determined that the collection unit is being
occupied during the period indicated on the affidavit to suspend residential
collection services, the owner of said collection unit will be charged
retroactively to the date that residential collection services were suspended.
(Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-3: RESIDENTIAL GARBAGE SERVICES:
   (A)   Service; Schedule: Each separate occupied residential family unit
shall use the residential collection services and pay the regular charges
therefor. The collector shall collect solid waste once weekly from each
occupied residential family unit within the corporate limits of the city
beginning May 1 of each contract year and ending April 30 of each contract year
for the per unit sum approved by the mayor and council.
Residential garbage service shall be provided on a weekly basis for the
collection of garbage to every residential dwelling within the city up to and
including multi-family units of five (5) units or less. The weekly schedule
will be approved by the city council and made available to residential
occupants by the city and the contractor. In the event that the scheduled day
for any pick up shall fall on one of the following legal holidays: January 1,
Memorial Day, 4th Of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day or Christmas Day - all
pick ups, during the week of such holiday for the day of such holiday and for
each succeeding day of said week, will be delayed one day.
A dwelling for which a bed and breakfast license has been issued by the city
and which shall have five (5) or less guestrooms shall be deemed to be a
residential dwelling. Any such dwelling with more than five (5) guestrooms
shall be deemed to be a commercial establishment and not subject to residential
garbage services.
   (B)   Quantity And Capacity Of Garbage Containers: With the exception of
recyclables, which are hereinafter provided for, each residential collection
unit shall be able to place up to two (2) 33-gallon garbage containers each
week of properly prepared household garbage, on the scheduled weekly day as
outlined in the refuse contract. The weight of each garbage container shall not
exceed forty (40) pounds. Lids shall be kept on garbage containers if
applicable. Perishable, nonstandard containers will not be emptied by the
contractor. Ashes will be collected by contractor only if contained in a paper
or plastic bag to assure that no hot coals remain.
Additional bags may be picked up by contractor provided they have attached to
them a refuse waste tag which shall be available for purchase at a price agreed
to by the city of Savanna and contractor.
   (C)   Placement Of Garbage Containers: With the exception of recyclable
items, all residential garbage for collection shall be placed in an "approved
container" and placed within five feet (5') of the traveled portion of the
alleyway. If the residence is not served by an alleyway or if the alleyway is
closed or inaccessible, the collection container shall be placed within five
feet (5') of the traveled portion of the street in front of the affected
residence.
The garbage shall be placed by six o'clock (6:00) A.M. the scheduled day of
collection. Any person who shall place, unload, pile or deposit any garbage in
or upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public place more than twelve (12) hours
prior to the scheduled collection date and allow it to remain thereon more than
twelve (12) hours after the scheduled collection date shall be guilty of
maintaining a nuisance and subject to penalties in accordance with section
7-1-12 of this title.
   (D)   Excluded Items: Construction debris, bulky waste, rocks, landscape
waste and soil shall not be included for residential collection. Residents
shall be required to make arrangements with a licensed contractor for removal
of these items and payment arrangements shall be made between residents and
contractors for these services. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-4: CURBSIDE RECYCLING SERVICE:
   (A)   Recyclable materials shall be collected on an alternating weekly
basis. Contractor will collect properly prepared materials as spelled out in
exhibit B of the garbage and recycling collection and disposal contract.
Collection will occur throughout the city on Monday. The collection of
recyclable materials will occur at all residential dwelling units. The
contractor may offer recycling to multi-family dwellings of five (5) or more
units at its own discretion. Contractor may establish reasonable rules for
placement and collection of recyclable materials and agrees to provide to the
city and each dwelling unit a written copy of all such rules.
   (B)   Recyclable materials may be deemed by contractor to be unacceptable
for collection. However, contractor is required to give written notice on forms
provided by contractor, informing the occupants of the residential dwelling
unit that recyclable materials are in an unacceptable condition for collection.
The notice shall also give instruction for proper and improper preparation of
recyclable materials. On the first occurrence, improperly prepared recyclable
materials shall be picked up by contractor. Subsequent instances of
unacceptable recyclable materials may be rejected.
   (C)   Contractor shall only pick up and dispose of recyclable materials in
approved recyclable containers. All residential customers entitled to
collection under this agreement shall be provided with a new eighteen (18)
gallon recycling bin by the contractor. These containers shall remain the
property of the contractor. The city shall provide recycling bins to new
residents and residents of territories annexed to the city. Residents may
purchase additional recycling containers from the city. In addition, each such
customer shall receive from contractor a written statement explaining the
recycling program including the material that will be accepted for recycling
and the manner in which recycling materials must be made available for pick up
by contractor.
   (D)   The city agrees that the city will provide replacement recycling
containers for a fee when notified by a resident or contractor that a recycling
container is damaged or missing. If contractor is at fault, contractor must
notify the city promptly and the city will replace the container seeking
reimbursement from contractor for the replacement container. If the resident is
at fault (i.e., a lost container, damaged container), a replacement container
will be provided by the city and the resident will be required to pay the city
for the replacement container. If the container is stolen, the resident must
report the theft to the city police department. Upon verification of theft, the
city will secure a replacement container only for the resident at the city's
expense. Residents moving into a new home within the city or residents of a
territory newly annexed to the city will contact the city for a recycling
container. Residents moving into a home previously owned will be given the bin
assigned to the existing resident as the bin will be registered to the home's
street address. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-5: CHRISTMAS TREE PROGRAM:
The collection of Christmas trees following the holiday season of each year is
provided by the contractor. Each tree will be considered as one container, or
can be affixed with a refuse sticker. The pick up is not limited to single-
family homes and also includes multi-family establishments up to five (5)
units. The collection date will commence immediately after Christmas and
continue until no more Christmas trees appear at the curb. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-
2013)
7-3-6: PRIVATE GARBAGE DISPOSAL:
   (A)   No person, operating as a waste disposal firm, unless contracting
directly with the city as its solid waste collector, shall remove waste from
any premises in the city without first having secured a license for performing
such waste disposal service from the city council. The annual license fee shall
be due on January 1 of each year and shall expire on December 31 following the
date of issuance, and when issued for a period of less than one year, the fee
to be paid shall be a proportionate part of the annual fee. The license fee for
waste collection and disposal service shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00)
annually. The city council shall have the right to reject any license. (Ord.
2053, 7-23-2013)
   (B)   Anyone placing a garbage dumpster on private property for permanent
and/or extended use (any period exceeding 30 consecutive days), must screen
said garbage dumpster from view of adjacent properties, with a fence or
landscaping, or place said garbage dumpster in accordance with the accessory
use regulations set forth in the zoning ordinance. In those instances where
environmental barriers prevent full screening, best efforts must be used to
minimize the view to adjacent properties. Any garbage dumpster placed on the
public right of way for temporary use must be approved by the superintendent of
public works prior to its placement. Permanent garbage dumpsters placed on
public property must be approved by the superintendent of public works. (Ord.
2124, 4-28-2015)
   (C)   No solid waste shall be burned, dumped or buried within the city
limits.
   (D)   In addition to the residential refuse service as set forth in this
chapter, refuse may be delivered to the municipal solid waste transfer station
for disposal at the rate set by the city council. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-7: COMPLIANCE:
   (A)   No person shall permit any solid waste to accumulate on his premises,
except in approved containers or as otherwise provided in this chapter.
   (B)   All commercial, industrial and institutional establishments shall
remove or cause to be removed all waste at least once each seven (7) days, or
more often if necessary, to protect the health and safety of the inhabitants of
the city. Waste containers for such establishments may be as defined in this
chapter or as approved by the city superintendent and the collector.
   (C)   Every person in possession of any premises in the city shall have the
duty to cause all garbage on or produced on any premises to be thoroughly
drained of all surplus liquid, securely wrapped or bound to prevent the
scattering of same by the wind and shall be deposited in an approved waste
container as prescribed herein.
All garbage of a size or nature which renders it unsuitable for deposit in
waste containers shall be considered special materials and it shall be the duty
of the person producing said waste materials to make private arrangements for
collection of said special materials. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-8: SUPERVISION OF GARBAGE AND RECYCLING COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL:
All matters relating to or affecting the collection, removal or disposal of
solid waste, unless specifically placed under the direction of the health
officer, shall be subject to and under the supervision and direction of the
superintendent of public works. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-9: CHARGES, AUTHORIZATION; COMPUTATION:
The city, in providing for service of collecting and disposing of all garbage
accumulated within the city for the purpose of preventing unsanitary,
unsightly, hazardous, unhealthful and dangerous conditions caused by the
accumulation of garbage and refuse, shall from time to time by ordinance
establish and collect a service charge fee to defray the cost and maintenance
of service and administration thereof, and to pay any person contracting with
the city for the collection and disposal of garbage and recycling, the fees and
charges provided by the contract for the collections and disposal thereof. Such
service charges and fees shall be computed, based and charged to the owners and
occupants of dwelling units as nearly as practicable upon the basis of volume
or time expended in the collection and disposal and administration thereof.
(Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-10: BILLS; NONPAYMENT OF BILLS, PENALTY WAIVER, REINSTATEMENT FEE:
   (A)   Bills: Bills for residential collection of garbage and recycling shall
be made quarterly one month after the expiration of the quarterly period by
zones established for the water department, for which service has been supplied
and the charges shall be payable within fifteen (15) days after the first day
of the month that such bill is due and payable.
   (B)   Nonpayment Of Bills: A penalty of ten percent (10%) shall be added to
the total net bill of customers failing to pay such residential garbage
collection service bill in full within fifteen (15) days after the first day of
the month that such bill is due and payable.
If said bill has not been paid within twenty five (25) days after the first day
of the month that such bill is due and payable, the customer shall be sent a
final notice that such service shall be terminated thirty (30) days after the
first day of the month that such bill is due and payable. Said service shall
not be reestablished until the service bill is paid in full.
If said service has been terminated for nonpayment and the customer is a
tenant, the owner shall be notified that such service has been terminated and
said bill is due and payable by said owner.
Failure to receive a solid waste service bill will not relieve a property owner
or customer from payment for garbage and recycling services supplied. Written
notice must be given by the owner or authorized agent to forward service bills
to any other address than the premises supplied.
   (C)   Penalty Waiver: Upon request by the customer, the city may waive the
ten percent (10%) penalty charge on the current billing period, but not more
than once each calendar year. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-11: COLLECTION FEES:
Collection fees shall be paid quarterly and shall be as regulated by the
garbage and recycling collection and disposal contract approved by the city
council. The current rate effective May 1, 2023, is $15.54 per month. Further,
the fee will increase a minimum of 3.5% annually beginning with May 1, 2024.
(Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013; amd. Ord. 2291, 6-22-2021; Ord. 2306, 4-26-2022; Ord.
2325, 4-25-2023)

7-3-13: SPECIAL PRIVILEGES:
In situations which are not contemplated or considered by the terms and
conditions of this chapter, the mayor shall have the power and the authority to
grant special rights and privileges on a temporary basis for the collection,
hauling and disposal of solid waste where such special privileges are required
in order to maintain the health and sanitation of the city and its inhabitants
or such right and privilege is required to avoid the creation of a public
nuisance. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-14: TRANSPORTING SOLID WASTE OVER STREETS:
No person shall transport waste or cause waste to be transported over the
streets or other public ways in the city unless such waste being transported is
entirely and securely covered. Garbage shall not be transported except in a
liquid tight vehicle or container as approved by the city superintendent. (Ord.
2053, 7-23-2013)
7-3-15: DEPOSITS PROHIBITED:
   (A)   Deposits In Streets Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person to pour,
empty, sweep, throw, deposit or place into or upon any street, avenue,
sidewalk, alley, parkway or public place in the city, or in the sewers or
gutters thereof, any garbage, slop, dirt, waste, wastepaper, grass, lawn
clippings, leaves or other refuse matter.
   (B)   Illegal Deposits: It is unlawful for any person to pour, empty, sweep,
throw, deposit or place within the limits of the city any garbage, slop, dirt,
waste, wastepaper, grass, lawn clippings, leaves or other refuse matter, in
such a manner that it may be carried or deposited by the action of the wind,
rain or snow into or upon any street, avenue, sidewalk, alley, parkway or
public place in the city, or the sewers or gutters thereof. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-
2013)
7-3-16: EXCEPTIONS:
If any of the language in this chapter is conflicting with the garbage and
recycling collection and disposal contract in regards to the collection and
disposal of garbage and recycling, the contract shall govern. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-
2013)
7-3-17: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise specified in this chapter, the penalty prescribed for
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or for any rules and
regulations promulgated thereunder, shall be as set out in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2053, 7-23-2013)
